Rio had taken to making quiet comments, out of Nicky’s earshot, about the limitations to a rabbit sidekick: they ranged from practical to deeply obscure and Agatha had devolved into laughter despite her best efforts.

”What is a rabbit going to do, chew the shoelaces of their enemies?” “Is the rabbit sentient? Will it shit itself constantly as it’s saving the world?” During a particular description of a combat scene from Nicky, Rio had whispered. “One kick and it’s a goner.”

Agatha had turned away from Nicky’s focused expression and grinned, biting her cheek to force away her amusement. She’d shoved at Rio.

“Stop it.”

Rio shrugged.

“I’m just saying. I’m not gonna be scared of a bunny rabbit. Their bones are tiny.”

Agatha had pushed her palm over Rio’s face to try to stop her from speaking.

“Stop thinking about how you’d defeat Nicky’s sidekick in martial combat. That is not why we’re here.”

Rio had caught her hand, pulling her in close. She’d whispered very seriously into Agatha’s ear.

“One must always be prepared.” She’d nodded against Agatha’s shoulder. “I could curbstomp a rabbit.”

Agatha had wrapped her fingers into the hair at the base of Rio’s neck, her chest shaking with laughter.

“You’re insufferable.”

“As much or more than a rabbit sidekick would be?”

The comments had become a continuous, easy joke between the two of them. The more ridiculous the comment, the more Agatha had fallen into fits of laughter, the more Rio had made them a permanent part of her vocabulary.

Agatha carefully drew the quilt from the suitcase and laid it over the bedspread. Once she’d finished unpacking, she stood in the center of the room idly, eyes unseeing.

She felt– she wasn’t certain what she was feeling. The rollercoaster of emotions that she’d been on– so different from the apathy of her time away– had left her unmoored. When she left DC, she’d felt like she’d been washed up on a rocky shore. It had been barren and cold and Agatha had taken to it and clung to the numbness it gifted her.

Coming back was like deciding to finally swim for help.The waters were rough and flashed hot and cold. She didn’t know where land was or if anyone would find her before she was lost to the tides. It felt like she was drowning, choking on lungfuls of sea water, her legs kicking uselessly and her arms losing strength. Every time she went under, she opened irritated eyes to see the shape of Rio looming from the surface and the grave of Nicky calling her to the depths.

Agatha ran her hands over her face, pressing against the tender skin around her eyes. Maybe a nap would help. Something quick to black out her thoughts and feelings and jumpstart her for the rest of the day.
_________

Agatha woke up overheated, her body smothered by comforter and quilt. She blinked, somehow the exhaustion from before having doubled, and she shoved blindly in an attempt to release herself. The sheets tangled around her legs and an irrational panic filled her until she was able to yank hearself out. She laid there and stared at the dark ceiling for several moments. She grabbed her phone from her nightstand to give herself something to focus on.

She had two texts, both from Wanda. The first was from two hours prior.

Vis is going to the store. Let me know what he can grab for you!

The next text was from ten minutes ago.

We left you a few bags on the porch! Just some basics to get you through the next couple of days.

Agatha grimaced.

She drew her rage like a comfort around her shoulders, pinning it in place and letting it simmer through the guilt and confusion and hurt. Dr. Alder had said that healing wasn’t going to be a steady path, that Agatha would falter from it from time to time even if she were trying her hardest. She never said Agatha couldn’t actively choose to side-step the path in order to give herself a respite.

Agatha stood, dazed, and made her way to the porch. She opened the door to three bags of basics sitting on top of an assortment of children’s lunchbox ice packs.

She scowled and closed the door; leaving the bags outside. She wasn’t here to be coddled and Wanda wasn’t going to win her over by ingratiating herself. Her show of kindness could rot.

Agatha walked around the kitchen, familiarizing herself with the location of the coffee mugs– just in case– and then made her wait to Senior Scratchy to let him out of his cage.

Thirty minutes later, Agatha yanked open the door and dragged the bags inside. She quickly dispersed the items between the pantry and fridge and looked at the now-melted icepacks.

She considered returning them. It would be the polite thing to do.

Agatha stuffed the collection– soccer ball, smiley face, flower, baseball, heart– into her freezer and slammed the door.

She wandered to her porch the, opening the door to let the afternoon chill seep into the space. Agatha wrapped a scarf around her neck and stepped outside, carefully settling into the hand-painted swing. She lifted her legs, the gentle rock easing back her anxiety.

She left her phone to die on her bedside table and swayed until the fireflies started their mating dances and a pair of crickets sang to one another from opposing sides of the house.

_____________

 

Sunday morning, Agatha woke up confused, the normally blazing sunlight nowhere to be found. She peeled her eyes open slowly and glanced around. She wasn’t sure what time it was, but her phone hadn’t gone off to drag her into the office and she was infinitely glad for it. She curled back into her sheets and let herself slip back to sleep.

She woke to a text from Wanda asking if she wanted to join them for lunch and she groaned loudly, ignoring her once more.

She needed to get out. She needed to breathe.

Agatha pulled on a pair of black joggers and one of her ratty, stained workout shirts that had seen its better days years prior. It was thread-bare and soft and had the name of their first volleyball team during Quantico written across the chest. Bohner Busters. They’d nearly been disqualified for the name alone but Ralph Bohner’s presence on the team had stilled the commissioner's hand. Ralph had griped against the name from the moment Agatha had submitted it for selection and his disdain for it only grew as every team he was on followed the naming convention.

She pulled on a gold-brown, waffled, half-zip sweatshirt and quickly made her way toward her car.

She was able to escape the property without any interruptions. Her plan was simply to drive until she didn’t feel the pressure of everyone’s suffocating expectations raking through her.

It went well for a solid ten minutes; her mind occupied with the decisions of where to turn and how far she could push the speed limit before it became questionable. She played music from her phone, letting the eclectic mix of her liked songs consume her thoughts.

Then she realized where her muscle memory was carrying her and she felt the relief break apart. She turned left instead of right, her decisions now colored by everything she was running from.

Agatha’s eyes fell to a familiar sign and she turned before she was able to reconsider. She drove along the two-lane street until she reached the back entrance to the major trailheads that littered the C&O. She parked next to the dozens of vehicles already littering the space and sat back in her seat.

Agatha looked at her tennis shoes and mild athletic wear; they would do. There were easier trails mixed in with the many arduous ones and she’d walked them enough to feel confident in her ability to make the correct turns.

_________

Agatha wheezed out a breath as she clambered up what felt like a cliff, her shoes slipping dramatically, sending pebbles down below her toward a person that had started climbing not long after her first step.

Her hand landed on a particularly sharp rock and she attempted to withdraw only for the motion to dislodge her stability. She slipped, hand catching on the same sharp rock as she halted her descent. She felt the tear of skin and immediately saw crimson slipping down the back of her hand to her wrist.

“Fuck.” Agatha took a steadying breath and continued to climb, her hand leaving smears of crimson along the rocks. “This is why hiking is and always will be fucking asinine. Fuck.”

Agatha rolled over the edge and lay on her back, her lungs heaving in and expelling air.

The person that came up behind her, a man in his thirties with tiny, blue shorts and two backpack straps around his shoulders, stood over her with a concerned expression.

“Are you alright, miss?”

Agatha didn’t open her eyes.

“Eat a bag of dicks.”

There was a stunned silence followed by a quick departure. Agatha laid in the sun, the cool breeze tickling the raw skin of her palm as she caught her breath.

“That was rude.”

Agatha’s blood went ice-cold, her lungs floundering. It was impossible. Nobody’s luck could be so terrible.

“You have got to be kidding me.”

She opened her eyes, peering up to see two silhouettes, one standing just-so to ensure that the full force of the sun still hit Agatha in the face. She saw one of the shadows crouch down, coming into stark clarity like an omen of the apocalypse.

Rio’s face came into view, her eyes covered by sunglasses and her hair loosely gathered in a mid-bun, her bangs framing her face.

“Hi Agatha.”

Agatha took in Rio’s practical pants and a color-blocked fleece pullover. She could see Rio’s hiking boots laced up to her ankles and she briefly considered untying them and making a run for it.

Instead, she dropped her head back down and covered her eyes with her arm. It was simply implausible that Rio was here on this specific trail at the exact same time.

“If you’re going to keep talking you might as well roll me off the cliff.”

Rio’s amused chuckle sounded far too close.

“You almost did that yourself just climbing up. Why aren’t you wearing boots? Why are you even on this trail? The one time I got you out here you complained for two straight hours and made me buy an uber to our car.”

Agatha grimaced.

“How about we skip the part where we rehash old memories and you head on your way.”

Before Rio could retort, Agatha heard a bright, perky voice cry out in incredibly unnecessary concern.

“Oh god, your hand! Are you okay?”

Agatha slowly withdrew her arm, her head turning to try and make out whomever was shrieking in her ear. She could vaguely make out tight, black leggings and a pair of light-blue hiking boots. Agatha rolled away from where Rio was crouched and pushed herself to her feet, ignoring the stab of pain that shot through her hand.

She blinked until she could take in the full picture before her.

Rio was here, yes. But she was here with somebody. A young, striking woman with long, blonde hair pulled back into two braids down her neck. She was wearing a white tank top under a sheer long-sleeved top that showed off her tits.

The woman was clearly waiting for an answer but Agatha was busy trying to process through the amalgamation of thoughts crashing into her skull. Rio was on a date? At the site of their second? Agatha felt a wave of violent nausea and chased it back with a scathing tone.

“I didn’t know you hiked with Doctor Barbie on the weekends.”

Rio gave her an unamused look and Agatha didn’t bother looking at how the dig had landed with the woman herself.

Rio held out a hand.

“This is Rebecca Wagner. She–”

Agatha held up a hand.

“I genuinely do not care.”

She looked around, attempting to remember which direction she’d need to take to return to her original trail.

Rio tilted her head but it was the blonde, Rebecca, who spoke. She smiled airily, her pale blue eyes squinting against the sun.

“You should walk with us. We have a first aid kit.”

It was a collective, a claim denoting ownership, and Agatha bristled.

“Oh, goodie. Maybe you can help me remove the splinter from my ass.”

Rebecca seemed reticent but she nodded slowly, voice questioning as she glanced between Rio’s exasperated expression and Agatha’s sharp tone.

“Okay. . . I can take a look.”

Agatha offered Rio a deadpan look before shaking her head and offering a tight, overly-sweet smile.

“This has been so enjoyable but I have to run.” She turned, her teeth clenched around the next words. “I hope you both drown.”

Agatha confidently chose to go left and she tried to disregard any of the roiling emotions that were zipping through her. Rio sure split from pattern with this one. Rebecca seemed dumber than a sack of rocks and had the personality of a soggy paper plate. Agatha rolled her shoulders to attempt to shrug off the discomfort when she heard footsteps approaching from behind.

She felt a touch to her shoulder and about launched the woman by her baby-pink manicured hand into the dirt.

Rebecca turned Agatha’s body towards her, eyes showing sternness about as well as a newborn kitten.

“I’m not letting you keep going without cleaning your hand. It could get infected!”

Agatha took in Rio’s amused face over Rebecca’s shoulder before responding.

“It’ll be fine, Reba.”

Rebecca’s brows furrowed then smoothed, an amused grin taking over her face.

“Oh! It’s actually Rebecca.”

Agatha allowed her eyes to go wide, her patience reaching its already tenuous limits.

“Oh!”

She turned on her heel and kept walking.

Rio called out behind her.

“Do you know where you’re going?”

Agatha kept moving.

“Of course.”

“Okay.”

It was the way Rio said it. The knowing, smug undertone that had Agatha pulling to a stop. Just because she was proud did not mean she was willing to risk being stuck on this overlay of trails for the next four hours. Agatha faced Rio.

“What?”

Rio looked unbothered at the bite there, her shoulders shrugging.

“Nothing.”

Agatha could see the glimmer of amusement dancing behind her dark eyes.

“Just–” Agatha cut herself off, wincing as she squeezed her bloodied fist too tightly. She leveled out her voice. “Let’s not do this, yeah? Just tell me which direction and I’ll be out of your hair.”

Rio was enjoying this too much.

“Sure, but I think you should let Rebecca bandage up your hand. She’s really concerned.”

Agatha stared at Rio, testing her resolve to play her game, and Rio looked back, deeply pleased.

If Rio were alone, if this wasn’t some incredibly uncomfortable third-wheel situation where she was forced to consider, not for the first time, that her ex-wife had been dating other people, Agatha would have bled out before giving in.

But here, her alternative was to let the pair hound her footsteps as she bumbled her way out of the forest.

Agatha grit her teeth to clamp down on her rage and shoved her hand in the direction of Rebecca.

“Hurry up.”

Rebecca appeared at her left and circled behind Rio, reaching easily for the backpack on her shoulders. She dug through it like Rio being her packmule was the norm and they’d done this a thousand times. Agatha’s mouth was acrid, her teeth aching with the pressure on them.

Her eyes didn’t leave Rio’s. She wasn’t going to give her the satisfaction of being the first to retreat.

Agatha’s body felt like a conveyor belt system as it carried the weighted surges of pain and insidious jealousy through her chest before it churned out into rage. With nowhere to go, Agatha felt the pressure of it building beneath her sternum and seeping into the muscles of her shoulders.

Rebecca popped from behind Rio with a broad smile. She wiggled the first aid kit in her hand.

“This will probably be easier if we’re not standing.”

Rio’s head tilted.

“Agreed.” She nodded toward the bench. “Sit down.”

It was said innocently, but Agatha could see the upturn at the corner of Rio’s mouth; a clear reminder of their moment in the office. But it rang wrong, a clang of disconnect in Agatha’s chest as she vaguely considered whether Rio had changed so much that she would be actively dating someone and still torment Agatha. She brushed aside the disparity of it because this was Rio and she refused to give her the benefit of the doubt.

When Agatha didn’t move, Rio’s head tilted and she offered a grin.

“Sit down, please.”

Agatha huffed, goosebumps flaring across her skin, and walked over to a bench that looked out over the river.

Rebecca followed her, her perky tits shoved in Agatha’s face as she sat beside her. Rebecca picked up Agatha’s hand and gave her a little pout.

“This looks so painful.”

She opened a water bottle and started to turn it over Agatha’s palm.

Just before it hit, Agatha yanked her hand back.

“Ow, be careful, man hands.”

The water ended up splashing across the ground and Rebecca’s cheeks blazed.

“Sorry!”

Agatha wanted to gut punch her. She clocked Rio’s knowing stare and offered a look in return. Her? Really?

Rebecca set to work again, turning the water bottle slower like somehow the action of it had caused Agatha pain before. The cool liquid splashed across the drying wound in the middle of Agatha’s hand, catching on the flakes of blood and loose skin. It did sting but Agatha kept it to herself.

Rebecca washed the blood from her wrist and palm far more efficiently than Agatha expected. The movements were practiced, concise, and she tried to piece together who the hell was sitting next to her.

Rebecca smiled at her brightly.

“You have such soft skin.”

Agatha looked to Rio, intent on passing judgment, but she found her ex-wife watching Rebecca as she worked. It made her stomach roil.

Rebecca placed Agatha’s hand on her leg and started opening a few antiseptic wipes.

“This will sting a bit.”

Agatha did hiss this time, her palm flexing at the burn.

To her utter shock, Rebecca lifted her hand and blew gently on the wound. Agatha stared at her and Rebecca’s eyes turned up with a sincere smile.

“It works on the kids.”

Agatha felt her cheeks burn with a myriad of embarrassment– though she wasn’t sure what for– and confusion. Her anger stuttered, stopped, then reignited as she processed through the feelings. Maybe the woman was a fucking idiot but there was something there, Agatha could see the draw.

She sat still, eyes averted, as Rebecca pasted a topical antibiotic into the wound, pressed gauze against it, and then wrapped it expertly with medical tape. Agatha felt a soft squeeze on her hand and drew it away instantly, standing and putting distance between herself and the blonde.

“Great, so appreciated. Where the hell am I going?”

Rio’s expression turned from pensive back to her prior glee. She tilted her head toward the same direction Agatha had already been walking with a stupid little smirk pulling at her lips.

Agatha curled her hands into fists, ignoring the dull pain as she curbed her desire to scream.

“I loathe you.”

She stalked off and felt certain her fury was visible in the form of steam sizzling off her overheated skin. She had only made it ten feet before she heard boots on gravel behind her.

Rebecca’s perky voice felt like screeching as she jogged up to Agatha.

“We’re going this way too!”

Agatha tried to remember if there was any portion of the trail where they’d be close enough to the river for her to accidentally push the woman in.

“Fantastic.”

The abrasive edge in her voice carried right over Rebecca’s head and Agatha reconsidered the words she’d spoken to Lilia. She’d said karma would have her dead, but now she wondered if this might be worse.

She ignored the pair at her side and back for the better part of ten minutes as they carved between large boulders and pretty shrubbery. The sounds of the river below felt like they should be cleansing. The trails in Potomac were like the paintings people hung in their homes; idyllic and near-unbelievably beautiful. Agatha couldn’t enjoy any of it as Rebecca droned on and on about the mountains she’d climbed and which were her favorite.

They passed several other hikers, some alone, others in groups. She didn’t respond to their friendly greetings but Rebecca seemed to think it a responsibility. She made comments and offered compliments, earning warm, pleased smiles and bursts of conversation.

It reminded Agatha of her time undercover when Wanda had been playing the part of a drug mule. She’d been subjected to hours of vapid, high-pitched conversations from the surveillance van as Wanda worked her way up toward their target. Agatha had complained to Rio about for the month-long span Wanda was ‘Chastity,’ so much so that they’d taken to calling Wanda her undercover name whenever her voice reached a certain octave. Wanda had taken it in stride.

Now, without a bigger purpose or target, the voice grated Agatha’s eardrums to shreds.

As they reached a fork half-a-mile later, the right leading toward a valley and the left back toward the river, Agatha slowed.

Rio drew to a halt, standing beside Agatha for the first time. She’d been allowing Agatha to take the brunt of her date’s attention for the better part of thirty minutes.
“Which way are you thinking?”

Agatha wanted to strangle her with her bare hands. The only thing that stayed the action was her certainty that Rio would enjoy it too much.

She had two options. Three if murder was on the table. She could guess and start walking in the hopes that she wasn’t wrong or she could play whatever game Rio had decided to waste her time with. One of them ended this much faster.

“What do you want?”

Rio feigned surprise but it looked far too much like gloating. When Agatha’s expression didn’t veer away from fury, Rio looked to Rebecca.

“I think we should play twenty questions.”

Rebecca looked thrilled.

Agatha glanced between them, face twisted in distaste. What kind of fucked-up foreplay was twenty questions and why was she being forced participate?

Rio smiled.

“I’ll go first.” She started down the path to the right. “Why are you out here without any gear? You don’t even have water.”

Agatha tried to decide if she should bite the bullet or eat one.

“I clearly wasn’t planning on being on this trail.”

“It looks like you weren’t planning on hiking at all.”

Agatha huffed.

“Thanks for that incredible insight.”

The path under their feet began to turn to jagged stones and sloping boulders and Agatha slowed. She took her time maneuvering her sneakers into the proper places to avoid breaking her ankles.

Both Rio and Rebecca eased ahead, their boots gripping the rocks and keeping their ankles stable. Rio moved with purpose but remained light on her feet, graceful in her steps. Rebecca looked like she was simply floating over the uneven surface.

Rebecca turned back, eyes laced with concern.

“Do you want to hold onto me?”

Agatha nearly bit through her tongue as her sneaker slipped. She offered Rebecca a faux-hopeful look while walking through her offered arm.

“Are you a valued family heirloom?” She continued at Rebecca’s confusion. “A pack of cigarettes?” Agatha placed her foot gingerly. “Maybe a bottle of absinthe to pour into my ears?”

Rebecca stuttered, trying to find the right question to ask.

“I don’t— what?”

Agatha’s amusement vanished as she nearly bashed her skull in. Her tennis shoe slid into a particularly deep crack and she yelped as she began to fall.

Rio’s arm wrapped around her stomach, tugging her upright.

Agatha could feel the shape of Rio against her back, the earthy familiar scent of her, her cologne, the sweat on her jaw and arms and throat.

She extricated herself quickly, shoving Rio’s arm away as she marched onward. She twisted her ankles four times as she beelined for the stable ground several yards away.

She was nearly panting as her feet found stable ground.

Rio joined her a moment later, voice mocking.

“Try not to overreact, Agatha.”

Agatha ran her hands over her sweatshirt and continued on.

Silence fell, minutes passed, and Agatha thought she may have escaped the adolescent game. She could hear a quiet conversation happening behind her and she ground her teeth together as Rebecca giggled at something Rio said.

Agatha studied the wilderness on either side of her, judging her ability to survive off-path. She could just start jogging, but there was something that shriveled inside of her at the idea of literally running away from the situation.

There was a person coming her direction from below, a woman in her early twenties, and Agatha made no effort to create space as she passed. The woman’s shoulder slammed into hers and Agatha feigned outrage.

“Etiquette doesn’t matter as much as it used to.”

The woman had stumbled, throwing Agatha a shocked glare, before moving forward carefully around Rio and Rebecca.

Rebecca looked hesitant before she spoke and Agatha counted that as a win.

“Anyone coming uphill has the right of way.”

Agatha mouthed the words mockingly to herself before turning back. Her expression was one of sickly-sweet apology.

“You are so right.” She shook her head. “Silly me.”

Rebecca, for the first time, didn’t seem to completely buy into the act. She glanced over toward Rio and Agatha did the same, brows lifting in challenge.

Rio had been too quiet for the duration, her small comments meant to poke and prod and cause Agatha discomfort. Now, she met Agatha’s challenge with her own, eyes knowing.

“She’s just masking her discomfort.”

Rebecca didn’t seem to notice the stare-off happening in front of her, nor the ratcheting tension.

“Oh, I totally understand. When I’m out of my element I definitely talk way too much.”

Agatha let her eye roll to Rebecca.

“Only then, huh?”

She turned around and started walking. Agatha felt like she’d come out on top of the situation, pride sitting tall on her shoulders. She began to maneuver down a steep ravine, taking three steps before the soles of her shoes skidded against the loose dirt. She slid several paces but kept her balance.

She didn’t let it humble her, her chin up even as she slid and stumbled her way down. As they reached the bottom, Rebecca seemed keen to release her awkwardness.

“So. Twenty questions, right? I’ll go.” She caught up to Agatha and let out a chuckle. “I already know so much about Rio so I’ll ask you.”

The statement gutted Agatha, scraping at her organs with jagged talons. She waved out a hand.

“Pass.”

Rebecca sighed and turned her attention to Rio.

“Fine. Rio, how do you two know each other?”

Agatha’s skin prickled. She spoke at the same time as Rio.

“I’m her electrician.”

“She’s on Wanda’s new team.”

That caused an uncomfortable twist in Agatha’s stomach. This woman knew about Wanda? She knew about Rio’s job? How long had this been going on? How did she not know about her?

A sickly series of images played through Agatha’s skull and she sped up her pace.

Rebecca let out a confused laugh.

“So you’re an electrician? On Wanda’s team?”

Agatha nodded.

“Yep.”

Silence fell over the group and Agatha could tell her steps were more forceful, her posture rigid and tight.

Rebecca piped up again.

“Your turn, Agatha.”

Agatha slowed. She could not do this. She was about to stuff a handful of dirt down the throat of Rio’s new pet.

“How about this:” She turned expectant eyes to Rio. “You tell me how to get back to my car and I will leave you two to play your cute little date-game.”

Rebecca looked startled.

“Oh, that’s—“

Agatha snapped.

“Can it, cabbage patch.” She turned expectant eyes on Rio. “Just tell me where to go.”

Rio studied her, eyes curious, surprised. She shot Rebecca an apologetic smile.

“Excuse us for a minute.”

Rebecca had crossed her arms, the action somehow making her tits even more prominent. She nodded and walked ahead a few feet.

Rio refocused on Agatha, eyes searching, smug.

“Jealousy looks good on you.”

Agatha seethed.

“Try embarrassed. Does she have a brain in there or were the tits enough to catch your attention?” Agatha’s eyes shot toward Rebecca and she scowled. “She has to be cold. What’s the point of wearing a shirt if it doesn’t cover a single part of your body?”

Rio’s eyes widened, lips turning up further.

“Agatha, Rebecca is my assistant.”

Agatha’s stream of vitriolic comments stemmed to a halt, her lips parting, closing as nothing came out. Every bit of rage that had collected seemed to fizzle out and die. She looked away.

“Classic work affair. Are you going to tell me where I need to go?”

Rio stepped closer, expression and tone dangerously low.

“Do you think I would talk to you like I did in my office if I had taken up with my assistant?”

Agatha drew in an unsteady breath and started to turn.

“This has been an absolute pleasure but I’m—“

Rio caught her arm as Agatha tried to pass her. Her fingers were rough, pressing into the muscle of Agatha’s arm.

“Answer me.”

Agatha drew in a weak wisp of air, the pressure of Rio’s fingers pulsing through her nerves to her core. She tilted her head toward their path companion that was very obviously trying not to watch.

“Unless you’re planning to fuck me in front of your assistant, I think you’d better let go.”

Rio’s tongue rolled over her teeth, her heavy expression lifting to heated amusement.

“Exhibitionist.”

Agatha smirked.

“Coward.”

Rio’s grip loosened but did drop, her features softening.

“Are you parked on McArthur?”

Agatha relaxed a little, nodded.

Rio slowly released her, fingers trailing to her elbow before withdrawing.

“There’s a split ahead. You can take the left path and it’ll get you on the right trail.”

Agatha straightened her sleeve and stepped back.

“It’s weird to hang out with your assistant.”

Rio rolled her eyes.

“We’ll see you at work, Agatha.”

She returned to Rebecca’s side and continued down the path.

Rebecca turned back, offered Agatha a hesitant wave, then followed.

Her voice carried back to Agatha as they disappeared around a bend.

“She’s kind of hot in a scary way...”

Rio’s responding groan was enough to put Agatha in a better mood even through the hour-long trek it took to reach her car.

She was covered in a fine layer of dirt and her shoes were filthy. She sat down and slumped into the driver’s seat, a tired laugh leaving her throat.

Agatha looked back toward the trail entrance, made a face, and flipped the bird at the entire concept of hiking before driving away.

Chapter End Notes

I'm so not ready for tomorrow. I can't believe it's almost over.

Chapter 7

Chapter Notes

OOF on that finale :/ Disappointed is a perfectly apt word but I appreciated aspects of it. Let me know your thoughts because maybe I should be looking at it differently.

Sorry that only flashbacks of Rio are in this chapter but that's more than episode 9 gave us lol. Hope you still enjoy.

See the end of the chapter for more notes

“Intern!”

The boy sitting at his desk, eyes glued to the screen, jumped about two feet from his chair and spilled a portion of his coffee across the papers in front of him.

With panicked eyes, he dabbed at the mess with his sleeve.

Agatha walked to the filing cabinet behind her desk and lifted a brand new plant for his viewing.

He had the intelligence to at least feign guilt as he continued to ruin his shirt.

“It was on sale.”

Agatha shoved it toward him.

“Great. You have a nice side table there to keep it.”

The intern grimaced and made no move to take the pot from her.

“But your side is kind of a huge bummer.”

Agatha scoffed and was ready to snipe back when Wanda called them to the war room.

The intern moved first, fiddling with the wet arm of his sleeve, lips pulled back in distaste. He seemed relieved by the interruption and avoided eye contact with Agatha as he slipped out.

Agatha put the Ivy down and followed.

Wanda had pulled up the kidnapping case in Greece, the evidence displayed on the screens.

Agatha took a seat beside the intern as the others gathered around them.

Wanda nodded toward Agatha.

“William and Agatha have been working the case to the extent possible while stateside. The local police have questioned all identified attendees that engaged with the victim and suspect except one.” She flicked the screen to an image of a man with a large belly and a full, brown beard. “Ramus Bauer. He was visiting from Germany, and had been there for approximately a week and a half. He flew out the day after and we haven’t been able to locate him.”

Wanda moved to the next image, this one of the suspect and victim exiting the club.

“There has been no ransom request despite the prominence of the victim. It is looking like a trafficking case and the local law enforcement doesn’t have the resources to extend this investigation further.”

Lilia frowned.

“What about the family? Have they been spoken to?”

Wanda looked to Agatha and Agatha took the cue. She stood, hands spreading over the table.

“The Hartwells have been less than forthcoming.” She flipped through to a picture of the parents. “Arthur and Mazie Hartwell. The wife is a lush and completely under her husband’s thumb. Arthur is a crackhead. Metaphorically.” She tilted her head. “Maybe literally. He is convinced that this is a ploy by the US government to gain access to his Advanced AI.”

Alice scoffed.

“He’s willing to risk his daughter’s life on that theory?”

Agatha shrugged.

“So far, yes. Our inquiries and requests have all been denied by his horde of lawyers. I think we should go knocking, but–”

Sharon squawked.

“Now, now, without a warrant–”

Agatha held out a hand.

“We get it, Sharon.” She switched to the posts pulled from Georgie Hartwell’s Instagram, TikTok, and Twitter accounts. “The intern poured through her posts and found a few that could have connections to her disappearance.”

When she looked at the intern to pick it up from there, he seemed surprised. Then excited. He slid the remote to himself and clicked.

“It wouldn’t have been hard for somebody to locate her. She posted everything with her location and it was clear she was traveling alone. There were dozens of messages from her massive following but these four drew my attention.” He pulled up a short message that read It’s dangerous to travel alone so far from home! “I thought at first it might have just been a concerned fan. There are a few others with similar messages. But if you look at the history here, the user has no identifying information and only started following Georgie within the past month. Yet they’ve sent twelve messages showing concern for her safety.”

He showed the other three messages. Two of them seemed like a stretch, their profiles public and incredibly widespread. But their messages were detailed and inappropriate enough to warrant concern.

The last message was from an account with no picture and no posts. It read It was so nice to meet you tonight, Georgina.

The intern frowned.

“I was able to trace the middle two accounts to IP addresses in California. They are mildly connected to Georgie and are likely uninvolved. These other two have led me to dead ends so far.”

Jen flicked through the documents provided on the tablet in front of her.

“Are there any connections to the local gangs? The government has been working to combat trafficking there but they’re still a significant hub.”

Agatha shrugged.

“They say there’s no connection to any of the usual suspects. It’s hard to know if they’re lying from five thousand miles away.”

Wanda nodded.

“Exactly, which is why you’ll be taking a trip to Athens.”

That was news to Agatha. She watched as the rest of the team took in the information, trying to figure out her own feelings about it.

Jen tilted her head, weighing the statement.

“There are definitely worse places to go.”

Lilia frowned.

“How quick is the turnaround?”

Wanda leaned back in her chair, eyes looking over the group.

“Tomorrow morning. Six.”

Agatha groaned loudly.

The intern leaned forward in his excitement.

“So, like, does this mean I can go?”

Wanda considered it, eyes narrowing.

Sharon shook her head.

“It’s far too dangerous. He’s not technically protected by the Legal Attache Program.”

Agatha waved her hand.

“Get him temporary immunity.”

Sharon looked appalled. She mimicked Agtha’s wave, her tone becoming painful.

“Temporary immunity! Just throw together temporary immunity in fifteen hours. Of course!”

Wanda placed a hand on Sharon’s shoulder, her smile placating.

“If he stays within the Embassy he should be safe, right?”

Sharon heaved in a breath, calming herself.

“It’s an option.”

Agatha grimaced, her eyes rolling as she stood from her chair.

“If he breaks any local laws we just let him rot in jail.” She looked to the intern. “Work for you?”

He looked at her with wide eyes, hesitant.

“Yes? Maybe. I don’t want to go to Greek prison.”

Agatha huffed, voice drenched in condescension.

“Then don’t do anything illegal.”

Alice caught the intern’s attention.

“We can go over the biggest no-nos on the jet. Sound good?”

Agatha clapped her hands.

“Great. It’s settled!” She looked to Sharon. “Your help is, as always, so incredibly pertinent. Such a delight.”

Agatha walked back to her office to the huffing and puffing from Sharon and Wanda’s consoling words.

The intern followed her a few minutes later. He stood awkwardly by her desk, rocking back on his heels.

“Thank you.”

“For what?”

He waved back at the war room vaguely.

“Making sure I could come along.”

Agatha scoffed, eyes glued to her screen.

“I don’t care if you do or don’t. I just didn’t want to hear the whining.”

The intern rolled his eyes, a pleased smile on his face.

“Nah. You like me.”

Agatha’s eyes fell to him, appalled. She pointed at his desk.

“Go away.” Her tone did nothing to remove his grin as he headed back to his chair. She called after him. “And stop buying plants!”

____________

Agatha arrived back at Wanda’s around seven, the sky already dark. The leaves had all but fallen from the trees, their cold, empty branches standing out against the gray sky.

She’d stayed late delving into the Hartwell financial records they were able to access. Georgina’s last transaction was at the club just before she was spotted on the CCTV. At least it was up until four hours ago when the card was used to make a purchase at a hotel on Crete. There were no cameras on site and the police had found no trace of the victim or suspect.

Agatha had scoured the rest of Georgina’s records to find any connection to the hotel or businesses in the area. Nothing.

The only other person in the office when she departed was Alice.

The woman was in the war room with dossiers on the known trafficking networks active in Greece and the surrounding countries. She looked up as Agatha approached.

“Anything good?”

Agatha shrugged.

“Police found nothing at the hotel. The victim had no other transactions anywhere close to the hotel.” Agatha tilted her head toward the files on the table. “You?”

Alice pushed a file toward her.

“Bulgarian Networks have been incredibly active for the past six months. They’ve also claimed two prior high-profile abductions.”

Agatha flipped through the first two pages. They were both women in their very early twenties; one deceased, one still missing. Agatha pushed to the next page and quickly looked away. She cleared her throat.

Alice glanced at the first page of many with images of suspected or known victims. So many were children. She carefully closed the document in front of Agatha and slid it away, eyes on Agatha’s face.

Agatha straightened, throat tight.

“What?”

Alice frowned, shrugged.

“Just trying to piece together the woman in front of me with the stories my mom told.”

Agatha scoffed out a laugh.

“I’m sure she had wonderful insights.”

Alice nodded, her sincerity cutting through Agatha’s deflection.

“She said she met you at the start of your career; that you were like a storm.”

For the first time in Agatha’s recent memory, she kept her mouth shut. She needed to know, to hear about the woman she used to be.

Alice smiled distantly.

“She said you were disharmonious; that your spirit was unyielding, intelligent,” Alice chuckled. “Dangerous. And kind. Too willful. Too curious. She said it could destroy you.”

The words felt like a brand, steaming and searing into her heart. Agatha tried to smile, to mask the impact, but it crumbled and left her bare. She looked away.

“It did.” Agatha slid her teeth together. “Tell her she was right next time you visit her grave.”

She wanted the words to cut, wanted a way out.

Alice just watched her.

“But she wasn’t. You’re still here.”

Agatha’s cheeks warmed, her heart swollen in her chest. She shook her head.

“No. No, that woman was swallowed by the storm.”

Alice had said nothing and Agatha had left.

Now, sitting in her car, she stared blankly at the darkening sky, seeing nothing. It took her several moments to gather the energy to open the door. As her feet hit the ground, she heard the sound of grass being pressed, crushed.

Her eyes fell on Billy; he had on a small, denim jacket and a bright red t-shirt. His head was covered by a too-large beanie and his jeans were tucked into red, rubber boots.

She stared at him. He stared back. Then he smiled.

It was like a sunrise.

Agatha desperately needed the night.

“Aren’t you too small to be outside alone?”

Billy giggled.

“No! I’m actually big.”

His mouth didn’t form properly around the words, the edges of the L’s rounded into W’s.

Agatha scowled.

“You’re small enough to be snatched by a bird.”

Billy laughed, his breath fogging in the cold air.

“That’s silly, Agatha. Mom said you were really funny.”

He mangled her name; said it with two F’s. She breathed through the tightness in her throat.

“I’m a real delight.” She shooed him toward his house. “Your parents are definitely looking for you. Time to go.”

Billy shrugged and walked toward her.

“Okay.”

There was no warning before he stuck his little hand in her own and began to pull her toward the house. She stumbled over her own feet, trying to decide if it was too dramatic to cling to the handle of her trunk.

Agatha’s heart pounded in her ears. She felt like she was being dragged by a ghost, near certain at any moment the small hand would disappear from hers.

It took her until they’d reached the brick path to draw to a halt. She pulled her hand away

“Off you go.”

Billy pouted.

“I wanted to show you my new Legos. It’s a Spider-Man set.”

Agatha started to back away.

“I have to feed Señor Scratchy.”

Billy’s eyes lit up, sparkling blue under the yard lanterns.

“Your bunny!” He bounded toward her, erasing all of her efforts to escape. “Can I come see him? Please!”

His excitement was crushing.

Agatha felt like she’d been cornered by a wild animal instead of a four year old boy that seemed certain they were already friends.

“No.” His face fell, eyes watering slightly, and Agatha panicked. “You can take care of him. While I’m gone.”

Billy rebounded with shocking ease.

“Really!?” He frowned. “Where are you going? Can I put him in my room?” His eyes grew alarmed. “Do you think he’ll like me?”

Agatha had never been more grateful to hear Wanda’s voice.

“Billy?”

Agatha’s eyes flicked toward the patio doors backlit by the warm lights from within. Wanda looked concerned as she looked around the yard, then she landed on the pair of them.

Billy pointed excitedly at Agatha.

“Agatha said I could watch her bunny.”

Wanda’s widened in surprise but she masked quickly.

“Wow, that’s very exciting, baby. I’ll make sure your dad gets the instructions and you can do it together.” She half-turned to the door. “Come inside, your brother has been looking for you.”

Billy nodded, took a step, then looked at Agatha.

“I’ll be really careful.”

Agatha’s throat swelled.

“He’ll like that.”

Billy sprinted inside and Wanda looked torn between following and trying to speak to Agatha.

Agatha waved her off.

“I need to pack. I’ll see you in the morning, Maximoff.”

____________

Agatha had finished an entire bottle of wine by herself sitting on the porch swing, only going inside at the threat of mild frostbite.

When her alarm blared at four-thirty the next morning, Agatha had regrets.

She rolled out of bed, freezing, and tried not to puke in the beside trashcan. Agatha drank three glasses of water and downed Advil before she stuffed her legs into corduroy, gray-green pants, hissing at the cold of the fabric on her skin. She tugged a simple, black sweater over her head and slid her arms into a black topcoat.

Her packing the night before had consisted of stuffing three pairs of pants, five shirts, and two sweaters into a suitcase with her necessities. She brushed her teeth, bagged her toothbrush, and stuffed it into the pocket with the rest of her hygiene products.

Agatha nearly dropped her suitcase down the round steps as she felt a wave of sickness crash through her. She clenched her teeth and maneuvered herself down the steps.

She’d just reached the landing when there was a knock at her door.

Agatha yanked her sunglasses from the coffee table and shoved them over her eyes. She flung the door open to Wanda looking perfectly put together despite the fact that it was still dark outside.

“I wanted to offer you a ride.”

If there had been a logical reason to say no, Agatha would have. Her normal stubbornness was lost somewhere in her hangover and she didn’t want to undermine any argument she could come up with by puking in the middle of it.

“Whatever, let’s go.”

Wanda stepped back as Agatha rolled outside, nearly barreling her over.

Agatha walked to Wanda’s already running car that she’d pulled around the house and flung her suitcase on top of Wanda’s in the trunk.

As soon as she’d closed herself inside, she pressed her now-overheated forehead against the chilled glass.

Wanda climbed in beside her, holding out an unidentified object in a napkin.

“Vision made scones.”

Agatha nearly flinched away.

“I know I’ve been a bitch but attempted murder is a new low.”

Wanda rolled her eyes.

“He’s really improved! I promise. It’s been ten years!”

Agatha carefully took the napkin and revealed the scone. It didn’t look horrendous. Then again, neither had the one that almost put Agatha in the grave.

...

Wanda held out the tray of scones with a look on her face like she was being held hostage. She whispered to Rio and Agatha.

“Just please try them? He is so hyper focused on perfecting baking that we haven’t had sex in a week and a half.”

Rio let out a severe sound.

“That’s unacceptable. Have you already drafted the divorce papers?”

Agatha positioned Rio between herself and the scones, hands on her wife’s hips.

“Wanda, this is coercion. We have to risk food poisoning or be subjected to hearing about your sex life?”

Rio laughed.

Wanda shot her a glare.

“Exactly.” She held one out and shoved it past Rio’s head toward Agatha’s face. “Eat it, Harkness. Or I’m telling Rio what you pulled in New York last month.”

Agatha snatched the scone and backed away as Rio whirled around, a dangerous look in her eyes.

“What happened in New York, Agatha?”

Agatha kicked out lazily as Rio approached, shooting a betrayed look to Wanda. She stuffed half the pastry in her mouth to keep from talking and began to chew.

Pure flour collapsed out of a pocket in the poorly mixed bread, coating her throat and teeth and gums in a sticky glue.

She coughed, spewing white powder across Rio’s chest, and then proceeded to choke for the better part of five minutes.

Vision ran into the room at the following cacophony of Agatha dying and Rio and Wanda sobbing with laughter.

His hopeful look melted into alarm and he passed her his glass of wine.

“I’m so sorry, Agatha. Oh dear!”

He patted her roughly on the back and Agatha downed the wine.

She wiped the tears in her eyes and heaved in lungfuls of air, throat burning.

“You’re all dead to me.”

...

Agatha took a small bite of the scone. If she got waylaid by flour she would definitely be ruining the floor mat in Wanda’s car.

It was amazing.

“It’s passable.”

Wanda smirked like she knew Agatha was lying and Agatha did not prove her wrong when she ate the rest of the scone.

“Vision will be so happy to be redeemed.”

Agatha didn’t respond. The warmth of every memory was tainted and dwelling in any too long would tatter them further.

They rode in silence to the airport. After a series of turns, any relief Agatha had felt churned away. She curled over her stomach as subtly as possible and took long, deep breaths.

Wanda noticed anyway.

“Are you hungover?”

Agatha groaned.

“I’m car sick from your driving.”

“Right. Notwithstanding my perfect score in our driving test.”

Agatha rolled down the window and stuck her head out.

___________

Jennifer was already present and overdressed. She had a coffee in her hand and a suitcase at her feet.

Wanda parked and Agatha forced herself out of the vehicle.

Jen raised a brow.

“You look like shit.”

Agatha smiled.

“At least for me it’s a rare occurrence.”

Wanda leaned around the back of the car as she pulled out their suitcases.

“Play nice.”

Agatha pointed lazily.

“She started it.”

Jennifer had the grace to nod.

“That’s true.”

Alice pulled in beside them, Lilia in the front seat and the intern leaning between them from the back.

He waved at Agatha and she grimaced.

“I’m getting on the jet.”

___________

They’d been in the air for an hour, Agatha having claimed a seat in the center so she could sleep on the table between the cushioned, leather seats. The intern had sat across from her but hadn’t said anything more than a quick “hello” to which she had grunted in response.

She was beginning to feel marginally better and she finally sat up, eyes blinking tiredly behind her sunglasses.

The intern was speaking across the row to Alice, their conversation revolving around a video game Agatha had never heard of.

Lilia was seemingly asleep across from Alice, her mouth slightly open as she snored.

Jen and Wanda had taken the two remaining seats behind Alice and the intern and were both looking out the windows of the plane.

The intern saw she had awoken and adjusted himself in his seat to face her.

“Are you okay?”

Agatha dropped her head against the headrest.

“Just dandy.”

Alice chuckled.

“Drinking before an eleven hour flight is a bold move, Harkness.”

The intern leaned forward.

“Were you at a party?”

Agatha’s lips twisted in disgust.

“I’m over forty. You think I waste my time partying?”

The intern shrugged.

“Parties are fun.”

Alice nodded.

“I still party.”

Agatha rolled her eyes.

“You're in your late twenties at best.”

Alice lifted her water bottle like a champagne glass.

“Thirty-two.”

Lilia was no longer sleeping, apparently, as her eyes pried open and she interjected.

“I’m fifty-five and I can still let loose every now and then.”

Agatha waved dismissively and Wanda chose then to interject.

“Don’t let her scowl fool you. Agatha has seen her fair share of parties.”

Agatha shot her a look but Wanda pointedly ignored her.

The intern looked beyond thrilled.

“You guys worked together, right?”

Wanda chuckled.

“We were at Quantico together.”

Agatha could feel the oncoming questions and her nausea returned in force.

Jen scoffed.

“What a surprise in career trajectory. Wanda is a Senior Agent, Agatha’s just come back from– what was it? Enforced sabbatical? Who did you kill to set yourself back so far?”

The temperature in the space dropped noticeably as Agatha felt her lips press together tightly, her jaw clenching.

Wanda’s tone was measured, forceful, when she intervened.

“That’s enough, Kale.”

Agatha wanted to launch across the cabin and throttle the woman. She pulled in a heavy breath and turned away, grateful to her past self for keeping her sunglasses on. She couldn’t speak because whatever came out would be too revealing and none of these people deserved to see her pain displayed so openly.

Silence sat stale and heavy, nobody sure how to ease the sudden tension.

Agatha’s history with Rio, her son, wasn't common knowledge for anyone that hadn’t been at the WFO. They’d done the proper paperwork and kept things professional in their careers; each being placed on separate teams, separate task forces.

Agatha retreated to her mind entirely, letting the rest of them figure out how to ease back into normality.

It was the intern, several minutes later, that quietly cleared his throat and asked if anyone needed a water.

—————

Six hours into the flight, Agatha felt a strange sense of deja vu. She hadn’t left the country since her last assignment with Wanda.

It was two months after Nicky’s death, her first case back. They had flown to Phuket, Thailand in pursuit of a fugitive they’d been hunting for two years. Elias Caldwell, a hacker that had wreaked havoc on the East coast; targeting infrastructure and triggering power outages. They’d been close to an arrest a few times but he’d always managed to disappear.

Agatha and Wanda had landed and spent two agonizing weeks following a digital trail to a secluded villa outside of the town.

The whole time, Agatha had been bitter and angry and she’d chafed against Wanda’s care and questions until her soul was raw. By the time they’d raided the man’s home, Agatha’s mind had become a slave to her grief and fury.

There had been a standoff against hired guards at the entrances to the property, automatic-weapon fire spraying into the police vehicles and kicking up dirt on their boots.

Something had felt wrong to Agatha as the Royal Thai Police returned fire, eradicating the threats. There was an impending sense of tragedy, the weight of horror to be revealed.

They’d moved in, checking the downed guards, and Agatha had noticed their small forms– thin and gangly– with a pit in her stomach. She’d pulled the mask of one and found a teen, no older than fourteen. The one beside him had been even younger. Caldwell had hired children, had promised to care for their families, and had let them die.

Agatha didn’t remember much of what happened in the duration of that raid. Something in her, already fragile, had snapped. She’d been near mindless, a vicious, primal thing.

She’d been the first to find Elias. She’d lost all sense of self-preservation, all awareness beyond the intent to break and hurt and destroy. He’d sliced at her with a machete, cut ribbons across her shoulders and arms as she pursued him.

She remembered his terror; remembered how good it had felt to wrap her hands around his throat and squeeze.

Wanda had pulled her off after he was already gone, so angry and so afraid for Agatha. She’d stared at Agatha like she was a stranger, but she’d protected her like family.

Wanda had relayed the fight, pointed to the many wounds on Agatha’s body, and claimed self-defense. It had been easier there, less restrictions placed on law-enforcement in using lethal force.

The flight back, Wanda had sat in front of her with a severity she rarely showed. She’d given Agatha an ultimatum.

”You can’t be in the field, Agatha. You aren’t ready and you are going to get yourself or someone else killed. If this had happened stateside there’s no telling how long the internal investigation might have taken. You could lose your entire future by pulling a stunt like that.” Agatha didn’t respond, nearly catatonic. Wanda picked up her hands. “Relegate yourself to desk duty or I’ll go over your head.”

Agatha hadn’t argued. She hadn’t had the strength to fight or persuade the SAC that she was fine. And Rio… They’d been nearly silent to one another since Nicky’s funeral, a simmering anger and a shared grief that had driven them apart instead of into one another’s arms. Agatha had been staying in Nicky’s room, had clung to his clothes that still smelled like him and cried into his pillow.

When Agatha had gone home after the mission to Thailand, she could see on Rio’s face that she’d known. Could see that Wanda had called her.

But Rio had remained silent, eyes passing judgment she had no right to feel.

The next months had been torturous, spending days with her head buried in paperwork, letting her relationships drift away inch by inch until she was stranded. She’d quietly moved out when Nicky’s things no longer carried any trace of him.

Agatha blinked, pushing away the memory. The others on the flight were in various stages of quiet; the intern was reading a horrendously large novel, Alice had headphones wrapped over her head, and Lilia had somehow fallen back asleep. She didn’t seek out Wanda, worried she’d find her watching.

Agatha closed her eyes and pretended to sleep.

___________

After landing, their team was greeted by a crowd. Two members of the Hellenic Police, Interpol and Europol agents, and a legal attaché from the Embassy were ready and waiting upon their arrival.

Greetings were quick, somewhat terse, and then they were packed into SUVs with diplomatic plates and ferried to the Joint Operations Center that had been established for the remainder of their stay. A small force of Hellenic Police would be working with them side by side until the case was solved or stalled.

Their driver spoke English with a thick accent. She explained that they would meet the other task force on the case and then they could be taken to the consulate house to get settled.

They traveled for thirty minutes into the heart of Athens and pulled up in front of what they were told was an old government office that had recently been renovated to incorporate modern security measures. It wasn’t obvious at first glance that there was anything special about the building. But if one looked closer, they’d see the dozens of security cameras and a handful of security personnel in plainclothes that were staying close to the building.

They were approached as they climbed out of their cars, a woman in her mid-forties with a severe face and jet-black hair. She stood rigid, like she was at attention, but her eyes were hard, laced with a mild contempt.

“Welcome to the Aegis Center. I am Major Daskalakis. My team will be leading this investigation in the coming days. We look forward to your input.” She turned. “Please follow me.”

Agatha grimaced, already dreading the hurdles they’d have to bound in order to complete the task. In her experience, joint task forces were either efficient– each part working together to complete the case– or brittle– filled with competing egos and suspicion.

Wanda was the first to follow, disregarding the slight of not being able to introduce herself or her team.

“Supervisory Special Agent Maximoff.”

Daskalakis glanced at her.

“Not the Director.” She pursed her lips dismissively. “Seems this case is not nearly as important as your constant harassment of my team has made it seem.”

Agatha’s brows raised. She could tell the entire team was paying close attention to the conversation as well. Alice’s hackles seemed raised and Jen looked offended. The intern looked like he expected to be arrested at any moment.

Wanda answered levelly.

“I assure you that this case is of highest priority.”

She didn’t argue the comment about harassment or attempt to convince Daskalakis of their intentions.

A small part of Agatha, the part that hadn’t written Wanda out her heart, was proud of the woman she had become. She truly embodied the disposition of a leader; her emotions regulated and kept under control when necessary.

The doors of the building were opened to them and the next twenty minutes had them being methodically entered into the security database as protocols were read to them like a criminal sentence.

Soon they were passing into an expansive room with dozens of screens and a large, oval table that could fit up to sixteen.

The Major nodded toward the space.

“Central Command.” She pointed to a door to the right. “Cyber Hub.” She pointed to an open hallway to the left. “Operations Wing. There is also a rest area down that hall.”

Wanda took it all in.

“I’d like to introduce the teams.”

The Major turned to look at her.

“I’m sure that can be arranged after you’ve dropped off your luggage.”

It was as close to a dismissal as the Major could get without outright shooing Wanda away.

Wanda offered a polite smile.

“Thank you for your consideration but we’re ready now.”

Agatha wanted to laugh. Dick measuring competitions were always more fun when they were between women.

Major Daskalakis tensed but said nothing else as she guided them into the Operations Wing. There were four others gathered, their eyes all falling to the door as it opened. The Major introduced her team in short order.

“Captain Markou. He’ll lead when I am away.”

A man with brown, mid-length hair and a full beard nodded toward them.

“Lieutenant Vassilakis.”

A woman in her thirties with long, dirty-blonde hair pulled into a tight ponytail and slicked to her scalp focused her attention but did not offer a greeting.

“Corporal Kallistratos.”

The last member present was older, around the Major’s age. He had the warmest greeting, his stubbled cheeks pulling in a smile. His hair was short and slicked back, his skin deeply tanned.

The Major focused her attention on Wanda.

“Constables will be at their disposal when necessary.”

Wanda nodded and wasted no time returning the introduction.

“I’m Agent Maximoff. These are Agents Harkness, Wu-Gulliver, Calderu, and Kale.” She looked to the intern. “William is not an agent and will remain in the JOC for the duration of our time here.”

The Major offered a false smile.

“Great. Please let us know when you’re settled and we can get started.”

Chapter End Notes

Thanks for reading!

Also, I'll be changing the summary of this story but the title will remain the same!

Chapter 8

Chapter Notes

This was very challenging to finish after the election results, but fanfic has been an escape for me for a long time and I wanted anyone from the US that needed one to have this chapter.

I spent a lot of today crying and didn't edit anything, so if it's not up to snuff, I apologize.

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Agatha was sitting in the common room of the consulate house with her brow furrowed in thought. They’d been here for three weeks. Three entire weeks without anything new cropping up to give insight or direction on the case. Working with the Hellenic unit had been nothing short of infuriating. Their efforts felt lackluster at best, nearly disruptive at their worst. They questioned, pressed, and argued every suggestion by the team. ”There is no evidence to suggest she was ever on Crete. Credit cards are stolen constantly. We have local constables on high-alert and nothing has come back. Going there would be a waste of time.” “The nightclub has offered everything they are able within reason. We are not going to rip into their finances on the whim of an intern that they may have dirty dealings.” “We’ve already interviewed every witness and we’ve provided the information we gathered. Are you dead set on wasting our time?”

Agatha was growing restless, antsy. She missed Senor Scratchy; the blurry photos Billy was sending her from Vision’s phone were ridiculous but she found herself waiting on every one. Often he was sitting on the ground, the bunny in his lap and a toothy smile on his face so reminiscent of Nicky that it killed her just a tiny bit every time.

The rest of the team wasn’t faring any better with Jen’s frustration making her snappy and Alice, the intern, and Lilia trying to keep some semblance of peace and productivity.

If they didn’t find a lead within the next week they would be packed up and sent home. Yet here she was, relegated to the walls of the consulate house. Her and Alice were given a rotational day off while Wanda, Jennifer, and Lilia worked from the ROC. Jen and Lilia would be taking theirs the next day and the intern was being forced to take both days despite his complaints.

Agatha had never been good at days off and now she was staring at the only provided television in the entire house, her eyes locked on the hours and hours of footage from the club the night of Georgina’s disappearance.

Something felt wrong. She couldn’t place her finger on the why, but it seemed as if the Hellenic unit was aiming to close the case as cold, as unsolved.

A clip from around two in the morning played out across the screen. Agatha squinted, her eyes narrowing in on a pair of oxford dress boots that appeared on the screen, the legs wearing them in gray slacks and– Agatha blinked, waited for the rest of the body to come into frame, but even the shoes had vanished.

She rewound, played it again. Shoes, ankles… nothing.

“Intern!”

It only took a few seconds for the intern to fly into the room, his eyes wide in excitement.

“Did you find something?”

She didn’t ask how he knew she’d been watching, nor did she complain when Alice walked in after him. At least in this case, the more eyes, the better.

“Look at the shoes.” The intern blinked helplessly and Agatha pointed. “Top left corner of the screen. Watch.”

The intern moved closer and watched as Agatha replayed the scene. It was clear as day now, impossible to miss once found.

The intern seemed perplexed but Alice let out a huff.

“Holy shit. The footage has been doctored.”

Agatha replayed it once more and the intern finally caught it. He whirled, face pensive.

“I’m so sorry, I should have seen this. I watched the footage so many times.”

Alice waved him off, eyes calculating.

“Agatha has been here for three hours watching this film. Whoever did this is very good. They probably hoped that the cloudy image would make it near impossible to see.”

The intern frowned.

“Why not just remove the boots entirely?”

Agatha pointed.

“Look. There’s a strobe light that’s changing the exposure of the camera on a repeating
pattern. Whoever doctored this had to find the closest matching clip to patch it together.”

Alice nodded, anger simmering in her expression.

“If there is one lie, there are many. This can’t be the only thing they’re hiding.”

The intern looked stumped.

“Why would they do this?”

Agatha suddenly stood, her eyes sharp with determination.

“Because there’s somebody or something important they are protecting.” Agatha pulled out her phone and pulled up the hotel’s phone number. “Short of flying to Crete and seeing this for ourselves—” she held up a finger. “Which I’m keeping in consideration— We can try to leverage the information out of the hotel management.”

The intern tried to peer over her shoulder at the screen.

“How would we do that?

Agatha grimaced at him and regained her personal space with a sidestep, searching the hotel’s name in google.

“We may not have access to anything remotely helpful outside of the ROC, but certain fines and legal cases are accessible by the public.”

The first page of links that appeared were relatively useless: labor disputes, several suicides, media coverage of a mild sex scandal. Agatha looked at the last link with a grin tugging up her lips.

“Gotcha.”

She clicked and began reading, eyes pouring over the new article from fifteen years prior.

“In 2009, Paradise Bay was shut down due to severe environmental law violations including the allowance of gray water into nearby natural water sources. It was reopened in 2013 and named The Seaside Retreat.”

Alice typed the name into her phone.

“Seaside Retreat has almost nothing connected to it. If they’ve had any legal issues they haven’t been made public.”

The intern looked over Alice’s shoulder and she let him.

“Is the new hotel owned by the same company?”

Alice searched and shook her head.

“Not that I can see, but that doesn’t mean that there isn’t a connection.”

Agatha stared at the frozen image on the screen, her eyes narrowed in thought. She looked at Alice.

“Call Jen. Have her look into the ownership.”

“Why don’t you call her?”

Agatha offered her an incredulous look.

“Just call. Make sure she’s alone; tell her not to search the current name. It’ll raise all sorts of flags. Just have her look for Paradise Bay.”

Alice was already dialing.

___________

The intern had been the designated note-taker as Alice remained on the phone with Jen and Agatha pulled information on the original owner.

Things came to a head an hour later.

Agatha pointed at the intern.

“Summit Investments. Shell corporation connected to the original owner Fotini Karagianni and many of his businesses.”

Alice swung around from her pacing, eyes wide.

“Eleni Michailidi is the current owner of Seaside Retreat. She had connections to Summit Investments in her previous organization before leaving to purchase and reopen the hotel.”

The intern was scribbling words across the page in the most atrocious handwriting Agatha had ever seen.

Agatha snatched the phone from Alice’s hand.

“Thanks so much for your help, Jen. I hope it rains on your day off.”

She hung up the phone and turned with an untrammeled amount of glee.

“What are the odds that Fotini and Eleni are still connected?” Agatha tugged the intern’s notebook into her hands, looking at the contact information Jen had been able to provide. “If we can put pressure on the right people we can get the information we need.”

Alice’s eyes widened, hand catching Agatha’s wrist.

“You can’t just blackmail a Greek citizen for information, Harkness.”

Agatha scoffed.

“It’s not blackmail! It’s just applying a bit of pressure.”

Alice didn’t let go.

“Pressure? You’re going to get us fucking fired!”

Agatha dislodged Alice’s grip and walked through the house until she located the additional gear provided by the FBI. She withdrew a burner phone and powered it up before returning to the common room. She made eye contact with the intern.

“Go. When they ask about this, tell them I made you leave before we ever started asking questions.” He attempted to argue but Agatha shook her head, expression stern. “Kid, you do a good job. You’re smart. You need plausible deniability in order to keep your job.”

He slumped but sighed.

“Fine. But I want to be there when you break the news. Captain Markou really pisses me off.”

Agatha waited until he was gone before turning her attention to Alice.

“You don’t have to be here either.”

Alice rolled her eyes but dropped into the nearest chair.

“That is leagues outside of protocol and I think Sharon might apparate just to strangle you.” She pressed her fingers into her temples. “We’re going to get arrested.”

Agatha put in Eleni’s contact information.

“That’s not usually the case. I mean, I’ve been detained…” Agatha dragged out the word, implying there may be more to it. “But normally there’s a slap on the wrist and a really pissed off SAC that yells at you in public and gives you the nod in private.”

Alice peered at Agatha from over her hands. .

“You’ve done this before?”

Agatha waved dismissively.

“Sure. Hundreds of times.” At Alice’s look, she shrugged. “Twice. One and a half times. Canada doesn’t count because we work with them constantly. Germany was a shitshow but when you’re right, you don’t normally get the book thrown at you.”

Agatha pressed dial and put the phone on speaker. It rang twice and was answered.

“Seaside Retreat, how may I assist you today?”

Agatha did her best impression of an American news anchor, removing the lilt in her accent, sounding as straight-line as possible.

“Hello, this is Clara Ashford! I’m a freelance journalist here looking into—“

The attendant responded quickly.

“We are not interested, good d—“

Agatha returned the interruption.

“Oh! I think Miss Michailidi will want to get ahead of the story I’m about to break.”

There was a long pause, then:

“Can I place you on a brief hold?”

Agatha waggled her brows at Alice. They only had to wait a minute before the other line reopened.

“If you’re calling to threaten me, I would advise against it.”

Agatha laughed lightly.

“No, no, of course not. I’m offering a trade of favors.”

Eleni’s voice was terse.

“I can’t imagine what I could need from an American tourist. You are severely lacking in negotiating power.”

Agatha tssked, her voice remaining light. This was where she hedged her bets. She’d either get what she wanted or a laugh.

“That’s where you’re wrong. Unfortunately for you, the clean-up of your hotel’s waste disposal was simply redirected and not corrected.”

“You’re speculating.”

Agatha heard the subtle turn in the woman’s tone like a victory bell. Alice had heard it too if the way she leaned forward in her seat was any indication.

“Sure. Let’s say I don’t have any evidence ready to put Karagianni back into a tangle of legal trouble. It makes sense that I would call before gathering that.”

Her mocking became more apparent near the end but the name drop had the effect she hoped.

Eleni remained quiet, thinking, before biting out:

“What do you want?”

Agatha wanted to laugh, her adrenaline spiking, but she remained calm.

“I need the hotel’s CCTV footage from November 13th.”

Eleni scoffed.

“That’s it? What could possibly be—“

Now it was time to redirect.

“My husband recently took a trip with his college friends and somehow ended up on Crete. I’m confirming a few things. You understand.”

Eleni did huff out a laugh now, her tone less terse. She breathed out “stupid fucking American” in Greek before reverting to English again.

“I will send the footage. Tell me where.”

Agatha provided one of a hundred unconnected email accounts that agents had access to only through the use of a VPN. Silence followed, the file being located and transferred.

After several minutes, Eleni spoke.

“It is done.”

Agatha grinned.

“Excellent. I’ll parse through to make sure you didn’t play me for a stupid American and return the favor. You can expect no mention of your name in my exposé.”

Agatha hung up the phone, her hands nearly vibrating with the heady thrill of being so fucking good at her job.

Alice was staring at her in mild awe and stunned disbelief.

“There’s no way that worked. There’s no fucking way.” Her arms crossed over her chest. “We just committed a crime.”

Agatha grinned like a shark.

“Isn’t it exhilarating?”

She disconnected her computer from the television and logged into the protected email. There, sitting in her inbox as promised, was a massive zip file.

Agatha impatiently allowed the dozens of folders to be scanned and cleared of viruses before she opened the first one.

Sure enough, Seaside Retreat had four security cameras active at any given time. Agatha reconnected the computer and sat down with a warm buzzing under her skin.

__________

 

The Captain, Markou, was standing with his arms crossed, looking at her as if she were insane. Agatha refrained from raising her voice only because of the delicate nature of the case, but she slapped down the manilla folder in her hand loud enough to draw attention.

“Is this the kind of methodology you practice in your own investigations or are you simply a poltroon with a switch constantly at your heels to keep you in line?”

She could see his lips thin in the mess of his beard. He leaned toward her, trying to tower, trying to intimidate.

“I hope you’ll remember that you are a guest here, Agent Harkness.”

Agatha sneered.

“I thought it was a general practice to put a good foot forward with one’s guests?”

Captain Markou bit out a sharp response.

“Only when those guests are invited.”

Agatha chuckled, her words laced with the frustration and venom she felt coursing through her veins.

“Ineptitude often requires correction by a large force.”

Markou stepped even closer, his chest nearly aligned with Agatha’s. He was taller but his constant posturing was feeding Agatha’s ego. Before he could snap back, he was interrupted by Wanda’s voice.

“Agent Harkness, Captain Markou.”

Agatha didn’t retreat. She had the upper hand and she held onto it with an iron grasp. Captain Markou backed away like a churlish child.

Wanda made her way to them, eyes on Agatha.

“Explain.”

Agatha shrugged.

“They kept footage from us.” She nodded to the screen Markou was not-so-subtly trying to cover with his body. “We’ve been here for weeks with no new leads.” Agatha reached into the Captain’s space to push the screen into Wanda’s view. “But there were cameras on the property. This is footage from the same day that the victim’s card was used.”

The Captain looked to be shaking with anger.

“You are not permitted to perform investigatory work without an escort or explicit permission.”

Wanda’s expression was severe as she looked over the blurry image of a woman getting into an old-school Porsche. There was no way to identify her as Georgina, but the height, hair color, and body were similar enough that it should have been entered into evidence.

Alice stepped in.

“This car is a vintage Porsche 911. I’d put the total number of these cars from the seventies and eighties in Greece at about fifty to one hundred models. But this isn’t just any model. This is the Porsche 911 Carrera RS 2.7. Only fifteen-hundred were made and I would bet my badge that there are only one or two of these actually in the country.” Alice shot a glare at the Captain. “One or two means easy identification of the owner. It means that they looked, identified a name, and buried the lead.”

Wanda took everything in with a level expression before narrowing her attention on the Captain.

“Bring in Major Daskalakis.”

Markou bristled.

“You don’t give me orders.”

Wanda nearly snarled, the first time Agatha had seen her truly lose her cool since they began working together again.

“The fallout from this is far above your pay grade, Captain. I expect your Major here within the hour.”

As he turned– petulant– he called back.

“You better detain your agents to the ROC, Maximoff.”

Wanda watched him leave before her attention fell to Agatha. She was seething.

“Harkness, get your ass into interrogation room two. Claderu, ensure she doesn’t take the scenic route.”

Alice stepped forward.

“Agent Maximoff, I was also—“

Wanda cut her off sharply.

“I am fully aware, Agent Wu. You and I will be speaking.”

Alice didn’t shrink away. Agatha could see she had already decided that the consequences of their actions had been worth it.

Lilia and Jen had watched this unfold with perfect poker faces. Now, as Agatha allowed herself to be dismissed, she felt Lilia’s hand on her back.

Lilia leaned in and whispered.

“You didn’t get William into the middle of all of this, right?”

Agatha huffed.

“Of course not. He’s at the consulate house reading his encyclopedia.”

They walked through the halls of the ROC and Lilia patted Agatha’s back and laughed.

“Good on you.” She continued laughing. “And they said I was crazy.”

A strange and warm sensation curled in Agatha’s chest at the somewhat backhanded praise. She wasn’t sure how to respond to it. She didn’t need or want the validation of her peers; it had never been of any importance to her. Even so, she had to fight a smile that threatened to split her face.

“I’ll be fine.”

Lilia snorted.

“Oh, I know.”

Agatha shot her a look as they reached the door to the interrogation room.

“That was layered.”

Lilia’s brows raised at Agatha.

“I’ve been around a long time, Agatha. I’m not nearly as hot-headed as Jennifer and I’m far more nosy than Alice.” She reached for the handle and offered a smile. “I know history when I see it. You and Maximoff have it. It’s in the fabric of every interaction you share. But you and Director Vidal?” Lilia blew out a breath. “I am in the business of knowing people. It’s always been my gift. You don’t get a personal visit from the SAC for something as small as a conflict of interest. You don’t get a slap on the wrist for putting your hands on them.” Lilia leaned into Agatha’s growing discomfort. “And you definitely don’t have such an effect on their emotional output that they are particularly incensed after a single conversation. That kind of anger feeds off of deep knowing.”

Agatha swallowed, the pleased feeling that had eased into her chest entirely gutted out.

“This is fun.”

Lilia shrugged.

“You have a habit of causing discomfort. I think you could use a dose of it yourself every now and then.”

“I’ll take a hard pass.”
