Lilia chuckled again and the sound was beginning to grate.

“I’ve never seen you give others that option.”

Agatha didn’t respond because there was no defense for it. She slapped her hand over Lilia’s to swing the handle open and let herself into the interrogation room. She slammed it behind her before Lilia could offer any more insights into her past.

As soon as she was alone, a tired laugh escaped her throat and the adrenaline crash had her slumping into the metal, bolted chair and closing her eyes.

_____________

She was woken to the sound of the door flinging open and turned her attention to– Agatha rolled her eyes– Major Daskalakis.

“What an honor.”

The Major planted herself across from Agatha with a very similar disposition to the one she’d held the first time she introduced herself. Dismissive, annoyed.

“Please, make a mockery of your situation. It’ll aid my intent to prosecute.”

Agatha huffed.

“You need sufficient evidence to prosecute even your own citizens. How do you plan to prosecute an American citizen without it?” Agatha tilted her head in thought. “I guess you could be hiding evidence?” She pressed her hand to her chest. “But your team would never do that.”

“We’re not discussing my team.”

Agatha smiled.

“We’re not discussing anything until I have a legal rep here.” Agatha looked toward the door. “I don’t think you’re supposed to be in here right now, Major. Where’s your Chief of Police? Where’s our liaison? Agent Maximoff?” Agatha tssked and allowed the woman to sit in the building tension before leaning forward and adding in a whisper. “I think your Captain Markou is going to be sitting before a judge far sooner than me.”

God, Agatha loved twisting people into knots. She watched the Major’s expression flicker and partially hoped she was about to get slapped. It would help her case.

Instead, the Major stood.

“Enjoy sleeping in this chair, Agent Harkness. Your SAC won’t be getting here until tomorrow.”

Agatha bit back the immediate question that wanted to follow. A strange mix of trepidation and anticipation buzzed in her chest. Agatha stared at the stainless steel table and pursed her lips.

Rio was going to be so mad.

The anticipation made itself more prominent and Agatha settled in for an agonizing wait.

______________

 

Agatha’s body positively ached from hours of being stuck in the interrogation room. Wanda could easily have gotten her out and placed in a more comfortable confinement room, but Agatha was pretty certain she was playing politics, building trust. She also likely thought Agatha deserved it.

Agatha wondered how Alice was fairing, surprising even herself with the mild consideration. Wu was tough. And she was smart. She wouldn’t say anything at all and both of them would be back in action once things were sorted.

Near midnight, Agatha was finally taken to a solitary room with a cot and lights that turned off. She sat against the wall and thought about the first time she’d gotten into a situation like this.

Wanda had been just as angry; they’d both been detained at the US Embassy in Berlin for two days while the situation was sorted. Granted, it hadn’t been as dicey a situation at the time. And the BKA officers working with them had been amused rather than enraged. The Criminal Director had pushed for their release within hours.

Agatha grinned.

It hadn’t even been her fault. Not really. They’d completed a raid and Agatha had followed a suspect out because they’d taken a hostage. She was alone and protocol was to stay put and wait for back-up. Agatha had pursued them through the warehouses and waited for the right moment to take her shot.

When she’d gotten home, Rio had cracked the cap of a beer and pressed it into her hands with words of exasperation and love intermingled.

Agatha fell asleep with the memory of Rio’s smile pressed against her mouth.

——————

Early the next morning, the room still dark in the pre-dawn light, there was a knock on her door. It opened moments later and Agatha saw Wanda’s red hair reflected in the light over the silhouette of her.

Wanda flicked on the light and Agatha hissed, eyes closed against the shock.

“Jesus Christ, Wanda.”

Wanda seemed serious but her anger had dissipated into acceptance. She gave Agatha a tired look.

“Let’s go, Agatha.”

Agatha licked the front of her teeth in disgust.

“Can I at least brush my teeth?”

Wanda walked out without an answer and Agatha groaned as she stood.

She saw Alice walking out of a room down the hall and winked at her. Alice chuckled and shook her head.

Agatha was able to clean herself up and change clothes before being walked to one of the larger conference rooms. Major Daskalakis was sitting beside a woman Agatha had not met. She was in her late fifties and had short white hair. From her uniform, Agatha assumed she was the Chief.

There were an array of other representatives attending from Internal Affairs on either side to legal counsel of the HPD to members of the US Embassy. Nobody looked happy.

Alice and Agatha sat down in the center of the table, Wanda on Alice’s left.

After an enduring silence, Agatha leaned forward.

“So where’s your guy, Markou?”

The Major’s face turned a bright red but a hand from the Chief kept her silent. The Chief rattled off the same list of prosecutions the Major had the day before.

Agatha huffed and was about to respond when Wanda cleared her throat pointedly.

“Let’s wait for the remainder of our delegation before proceeding.”

The Chief gave Agatha her full attention as the door opened at their back.

“You seem inclined to make this difficult, Agent Harkness.”

A voice Agatha had tried to prepare for slithered up her spine, circled her throat, and pooled into her ears.

“I assure you all of my agents will exhibit decorum through the remainder of these proceedings.”

All eyes on the room besides Agatha’s turned to Rio, taking her in, weighing her. Agatha knew what they’d find.

Rio, when it came to her job, was a force of nature. She carried herself with the self-possession and assurance of somebody who believed they were the most powerful person in any room. Agatha had watched many shrink in her presence.

At least the Police Chief kept her composure. She stood and reached across the table.

“Director Vidal, welcome to Greece. It’s unfortunate it’s under such unpleasant circumstances. I am Chief of Police, Ariadni Koutsou.”

She introduced the major and her legal team but Agatha could only focus on the hands that settled on the back of the chair beside her.

Rio responded.

“You know my team, meet our Legal Counsel, Sharon Davis.”

Agatha turned for the first time in disbelief, her eyes catching on strong cut of Rio’s suit and the soft turn of her mouth on their to the short PTA mom taking a seat two chairs away. She looked like she was ready for a bake sale, not like the lawyer that would drag Agatha away Scott-free.

Sharon began to recount the circumstances of the case for her own understanding as Rio took the chair beside Agatha. She didn’t look over.

Agatha straightened in her seat.

For the next several minutes, Sharon recounted the events as had been delivered to her.

“...Agents Harkness and Wu-Gulliver identified alterations in the CCTV footage provided by your team. They then acquired a file with footage dated November 13th–”

The Major across the table interrupted.

“Illegally obtained.”

Sharon’s brows lifted, a disappointed look on her face.

“Now, I know it is not polite to interrupt. You also should be aware that there is no evidence at this time to suggest criminal activity on the parts of these Agents. To imply such without that evidence is going to make this more difficult for your own legal team.” She paused for effect. “As I was saying. This footage depicts an unidentified individual entering a distinct vehicle at the Seaside Retreat Hotel, a location where the victim’s card had been utilized. This information was withheld from the knowledge of the FBI, and it has been confirmed that it was also withheld from the greater position of the Hellenic Police Department. Captain Markou is the primary suspect in this matter and is currently being prosecuted on charges of Evidence Tampering, Obstruction of Justice, Official Misconduct, Perjury, and Conspiracy. Please confirm if this understanding is accurate.”

The legal counsel, a man in his early forties with dyed-brown hair and thin glasses, cleared his throat.

“That is correct. However, it should be stated that both Agents, Wu-Gulliver and Harkness, will be under investigation for the foreseeable future until it can be proven whether there was a breach of sovereignty and law.”

Agatha sighed.

“We’re wasting valuable time–”

A hand landed on Agatha’s leg, squeezing in warning, as Rio’s head turned.

“Agent Harkness, please refrain from speaking unless you’re asked a direct question.”

Agatha’s mouth snapped shut, her body locking up at the touch.

Major Daskalakis huffed.

“At least you can keep a gag on your Agents.”

Rio’s focus returned across the table, her dark gaze landing on the Major.

“Due to the actions committed, by Markou’s own admission, there is a real possibility that your victim is dead, gone, or has suffered greatly at the hands of her captors. While I will permit an investigation into my Agents out of respect, I will tolerate very little in terms of their degradation. Am I clear?”

Throughout Rio’s sharp address, her hand had squeezed tightly around Agatha’s thigh. She slowly released her grip but kept her hand in place.

The Chief placed a hand on the table.

“We will keep the interactions civil.”

__________

Two hours, countless questions, and a quickly unraveling sense of self-preservation later and Agatha was reaching her limit. She felt wrung out, overheated, and violently irritated.

Rio’s hand had remained in place, the warmth of her palm radiating into Agatha’s leg. Every time Agatha had even begun a sentence with a tone Rio didn’t like, there was a biting pressure of blunt nails into her skin. The thin layer of fabric did nothing to diminish the sensation. Agatha had mixed feelings of agitation and desperation. She knew that Rio was intent on keeping things respectful, calm. It was the best method to reach a peaceful conclusion.

It was working too. Agatha couldn’t function with Rio’s hand on her, couldn’t form snide remarks, couldn’t goad the Major, couldn’t offer underhanded insults about Markou. Even Wanda seemed to be looking at her every few minutes like she expected Agatha to mouth off.

Alice answered the many questions monotone and without hesitation or stumble. Agatha felt jealousy at the fact that she was allowed to complete this interrogation without their Director’s talons in her leg.

The Chief of Police listened closely, intently, as they both answered similarly.

“I was not aware of any law that I might break by procuring this information.” “Yes, I knew that I was acting without the direct permission of the HPD.” “Our actions were not taken until we discovered the doctoring of the CCTV footage.” “I did not alert Agent Maximoff due to her position and responsibility.”

Agatha tried to pull her leg away after a particularly sharp press of nails. She hadn’t even done anything! She was thinking about doing something but it’s not like Rio knew that. Instead of Rio’s hand falling off, it slid higher, her fingers against her inner thigh, her knuckles brushing the other leg. Agatha bit her lip tightly.

The Chief of Police cleared her throat.

“I appreciate your candidness and civility in answering these questions. While I expect we are not being told full truths, I will be suggesting that this situation be handled internally by your organization. We will request disciplinary action but otherwise settle this diplomatically.”

Rio nodded.

“I believe that returning our attention to the case is the best decision. Thank you for your forbearance and rest assured that both Agent Harkness and Agent Wu-Gulliver will receive proper reprimand and corrective discipline.”

Agatha was boiling over. Her lungs and throat hurt from the amount of times she’d held her breath, the amount of times her words got caught in her chest because of Rio’s fucking audacity.

Rio’s hand withdrew from her leg and she stood.

“Keep me informed if the decision changes after an internal discussion. I need to have a conversation with my Agents.”

Rio walked out because she knew she would be followed. Sharon trotted happily at her heels and Alice and Wanda were close behind. Agatha took a deep breath, the last to stand, and bit back the slew of comments one more time so that she didn’t give them a reason to reconsider. She let her eyes fall on the Major and allowed a single smirk, the smallest lift of her lips, before turning heel and walking toward her reckoning.

As soon as she stepped outside she felt Rio’s eyes. She pointedly ignored her and turned to Alice.

“See. Slap on the wrist.”

Wanda looked like she was about to snap again.

Rio spoke quietly.

“Agent Maximoff, please take the team back to the consulate house. I’ll be there after I tie up some loose ends.”

Wanda nodded, leaving, and Agatha followed because even the chance to breathe outside of Rio’s orbit for a few moments might allow her to clear her head for whatever was coming.

____________

The ride back to the consulate house was eerily quiet. Upon their arrival, Wanda was out first, her face set, her eyes locking onto Agatha as she addressed the entire team.

“Living room. Now.”

Agatha raised her brows but followed the order with little protest. The sooner the beratement occurred, the sooner she could sleep in a real bed.

She’d barely sat in one of the chairs, Jen, Lilia, and Alice taking the couch, before Wanda started in.

“The actions taken by this team today put every one of your careers in jeopardy. It put a strain on the relationship we have with law enforcement here in Greece. It risked the resolution of this case.”

Agatha sighed.

“Wanda, their withholding of evidence was–”

“Agent Harkness, their actions do not provide validation for your decision to break the law. The doctored footage was enough to launch an investigation. If you had come to me, I could have done this the right way.”

Agatha threw up a hand.

“The right way can take weeks that we do not have. They would have walked you around in circles until our only chance of finding the victim was eradicated.”

Wanda focused the force of her attention on Agatha.

“Are you questioning my ability to do my job?”

Alice attempted to intervene.

“It’s the red tape. You have to follow–”

Wanda’s head tilted sharply toward her and Alice fell silent.

“Every single one of us is subject to the red tape you so recklessly bypassed yesterday. Your lack of seniority does not remove that responsibility from your shoulders.”

Jen held up a hand.

“Can I just say, I didn’t know what the hell they were doing when they called asking for information.”

Agatha groaned loudly.

“You’re spineless, Kale.”

Jennifer’s hands pressed into her thighs as she leaned forward.

“I’m simply stating the truth. Some of us hold respect for our position and power.”

Lilia scoffed. She’d been silent until now, taking everything in.

“I’m not saying I condone this, but claiming that Alice and Agatha do not respect their position when they were attempting to right an injustice is simply absurd. Whether they were right to do what they did, they were correct.”

Wanda seemed to lose some of her fight then, her hands pressing tightly into her temples.

“You’re dismissed. Get some rest. We’re still on this case until further notice but stay prepared for a quick departure.”

Agatha pushed herself to her feet slowly, a slinking sense of guilt in her chest as the others left the room. She stopped beside Wanda.

“It wasn’t a lack of respect.”

Wanda sighed as she met Agatha’s eyes.

“I know. But you made the wrong call, Agatha. You’re lucky they have no way of prosecuting.”

Agatha didn’t agree. It had been a calculated risk. One that had paid off. They always paid off.

“I am prepared for the consequences of it.”

She left then, making a beeline for her room. She just wanted to smash her face into the soft pillow and pass out for twelve hours. As she unlocked the door and pressed it open, Agatha stilled.

Rio was standing at her window, her suit jacket tossed over Agatha’s bed, her leather cross-harness still on her shoulders but sitting empty at her ribs.

“Close the door, Agatha.”

Agatha did.

“This seems like an inappropriate setting for a disciplinary conversation.”

Rio turned around, eyes landing heavy on Agatha, body leaning back against the wall. Her feet crossed at the ankles.

“Do you want to lose your job?”

Agatha tugged off her jacket and tossed it over Rio’s on the bed, her memory of Rio’s hand so demanding on her leg, the continual press of nails, pounding through her skull.

 

“If that’s what you’re actually threatening here, you’ve wasted a lot of fucking Bureau time and resources on me.”

Rio didn’t try to mask her anger like she had in her office. She was burning with it, bristling with it.

“It’s not a threat. It’s the outcome if you don’t get your fucking act together.” Rio moved toward her. “You’re damn lucky they don’t have anything to hold on you.”

Agatha rolled her eyes.

“It isn’t luck. We didn’t leave a trail.”

Rio sneered. She slipped her phone from her pocket and held it out.

“Press play.”

Agatha didn’t reach out to take it. Rio pressed it for her.

Agatha heard her own voice ring through, repeating back the conversation she had with Eleni. “No, no, of course not. I’m offering a trade of favors.”

Rio paused the recording.

“You blackmailed a Greek citizen into providing you information.”

“Well,” Agatha tilted her head back and forth. “A Greek criminal, technically.”

It was the wrong thing to say. Rio closed her eyes, sheer exasperation taking over her face.

“You’ll be suspended without pay upon return to DC. Pack your bags.”

Agatha’s heart crawled into her throat, her anger breaking through her body, tensing it, burning it. She stepped closer to Rio.

“What about you, Rio? I’m certain Wanda wasn’t manhandling Alice under the table to control her. Is that the behavior we can expect from our all-powerful SAC?”

Rio shook her head, eyes craving through every line of Agatha’s face looking for answers. She swallowed tightly.

“You’re right.” Rio’s eyes dropped away. “I shouldn’t have brought you back.”

The statement was a fist to Agatha’s left temple, a near-knockout blow that had Agatha locking her knees to keep from staggering. ”I shouldn’t have brought you back.” The events of the past two months replayed like a reel, acidic in her brain.

Agatha let out a near-feral laugh.

“You?” Rio’s jaw clenched tightly, her composure slipping away as Agatha took over her space. Agatha’s hand moved in rage, fingers gripping Rio’s jaw, yanking her head up. Agatha could barely speak for her fury. “You dragged me back here like I had no choice. You said it was Wanda!”

Rio’s eyes were dark and deep and devastated, the muscles of her jaw clenching and unclenching against the press of Agatha’s fingertips.

“You were drowning.”

Agatha’s breath was coming in heavy, pained drags. Her eyes burned, her vision blurred.

“I was fine!”

Rio’s hand wrapped around Agatha’s wrist.

“You were fine? Fine?!” Rio’s voice broke as it rose, her words wavering. “You were alone! You were suffocating in your apathy. You were dying, Agatha!”

Agatha couldn’t breathe. She raised her voice to match Rio’s.

“Then let me!” Agatha shoved Rio by her jaw, sending her back into the wall. Rio stumbled but righted herself. Agatha gasped out a wet breath. “You should have let me die.”

Rio’s expression broke, the tears in her eyes finally falling. She shook her head.

“No.” She shrugged helplessly. “I won’t. I can’t.”

Agatha stared at the woman who had been her entire world for the best parts of her life. She saw the woman from before Nicky’s death. Saw the impassioned determination, the dedication, the adoration— all of it so naive in its purity. No matter the limits they tested with one another, Rio had always believed in them. Seeing it here, written in the eyes of the only person who held her heart, Agatha trembled.

And because Agatha could not handle the truth of it, the horror of Rio’s continued love, she allowed her sorrow to corrupt itself.

Agatha stepped into Rio’s body and slid her hands into Rio’s hair, nails scratching against her scalp.

“Then make me feel something else.”

Rio’s hands fell to her because what else could she do. Her hands slid against Agatha’s shoulders and up her neck

Rio kissed her like she knew it wasn’t real. Rio’s throat vibrated with a muffled sob as she pressed her body as tightly as she could against Agatha’s and broke her own rule.

Agatha kissed her back like it was real because admitting the cruelty of it would destroy her. She buried the truth and pressed Rio into the wall as their mouths slanted together, the familiar taste of her a salve to Agatha’s shredded heart.

She bit harshly against Rio’s bottom lip and did not ease the sting. Her tongue slid against Rio’s, dragged along the line of her teeth, commanded her mouth with a hand on her throat and knee pressed between her legs.

Rio’s nails dug desperately into her back, clinging and piercing as she rode Agatha’s leg. The pain of it crawled up and down Agatha’s spine, the pleasure of it coiled lower.

Agatha broke away, panting against Rio’s mouth as she yanked her belt loose. She didn’t bother with Rio’s pants, the waistline loose enough for her hand to slide under the hem. She pressed her mouth against Rio’s throat to muffle her moan as her fingers pressed against the thin, warm, soaked fabric over Rio’s cunt.

She bit the soft skin of Rio’s throat and cupped her firmly, middle finger finding purchase on Rio’s clit.

The absolutely wretched whine that left Rio’s mouth, the slight slip of her back against the wall as her knees gave out, had stars breaking on the backs of Agatha’s eyelids.

Agatha’s chest squeezed in warning and she ignored it because if she stopped now she would never recover. Just this one time she would fuck her ex-wife. She would burn it out of their systems. In the cold light of the aftermath, Rio would see Agatha’s actions for cruelty, and she would hate her for them.

Agatha caught Rio’s mouth in an open, heated press of lips. She adjusted her hand, tugged Rio’s underwear to the side and let her fingers slip through her slick folds with lazy strokes.

Rio’s head dropped back and Agatha made the mistake of looking. Rio’s eyes were closed, the mascara from her eyes streaking down her pretty, red cheeks. Her lips were swollen, the lower one bleeding lightly where Agatha’s teeth had dug in too far.

She was so beautiful. The masterpiece of an artist who loved and hated her work in equal measure. Agatha’s lips closed over Rio’s bottom one and pulled it into her mouth, tongue tasting iron as it slid across the cut.

She focused her attention, her fingers curling, pressing inside.

Agatha overwrote her desire to take her time, let her fingers drive roughly into Rio, felt the way Rio’s walls fluttered, tightened around her fingers as if to hold her in place.

Agatha pressed her forehead into Rio’s neck, buried herself there as Rio’s body grew taut, heavier in her arms. She pressed her tighter to the wall and added a third finger to her next thrust, working Rio up too quickly so neither of them could sit in the way even doing this wrong felt so right.

Rio’s nails dragged, tore skin, but she remained silent, stubborn except for the hopeless gasps that fell from her lips when Agatha pressed just right against her front wall.

Agatha felt the first shudder, the jolt of Rio’s hips into her hand, and then Rio’s back arced, her body locking as her head slammed into the wall, eyes closed tightly.

Agatha fucked her through it until the sight of Rio coming down made her never want to stop. She withdrew before Rio could open her eyes and took a full step back. She stared at Rio as she was breathing against the wall with fresh tears on her cheeks. Agatha turned around before she could say words she couldn’t mean and fled her own room.

Nobody was in the hallway when she opened her door and made her way to the small balcony at the end of it. She needed air, needed to wipe away the scent of Rio on her body and hands and mouth. She slid the door open and found Alice outside already. Agatha hesitated, debated fleeing the house entirely, when Alice’s hand reached back toward her, offering a freshly lit cigarette without question.

Agatha took it in her left hand and breathed in.

Chapter End Notes

Thank you to the people who have commented on this story. It's truly been such a joy to read your thoughts and discuss the show. I love this fandom.

Chapter 9

Chapter Notes

Okay I'm not saying this chapter is happy, but I really, really enjoyed writing it.

All of the wonderful, beautiful comments you guys left on the last chapter were so uplifting and needed in the past couple days. I am so happy to be a part of this community. I'm still in the process of responding :)

ALSO, I created a playlist for this story but wasn't sure if anyone would be interested haha. I'll probably tack it onto the next chapter if I can figure out how to hide my full name.

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Agatha had stood on the narrow balcony with Alice for a time, letting the bitter smoke of the cigarette burn away the taste of Rio in her mouth. She tucked her right hand, now sticky, into the pocket of her coat. Every shift of her fingers reminded her of where they’d been, of what she’d done. Her own underwear was ruined from her body’s response but she would not be finding relief.

It felt like a dream. Like a liminal space that crafted itself into existence the moment Rio or her crossed a line, like both knew if they could go to such a place, they wouldn’t be held accountable to the damage they caused each other.

Alice hadn’t tried to start any kind of conversation for the first several minutes, her eyes watching the slow passing of cars below.

Agatha was grateful. She couldn’t think about anything but Rio. The taste, the smell, the warmth of her after five years with nothing. She felt sick; a roiling guilt clanging a punishment against her ribcage, a cutting disappointment squeezing at the base of her neck. She thought of telling Dr. Alder and grimaced.

Agatha heard the front door of the house open and kept her eyes peeled on the gate at the edge of the small yard out front. Most of it was cut off from her view but she could see a patch of green and the wrought-iron spikes of the entrance.

Rio appeared, completely remade, the streaks of tears wiped clean and the mess Agatha had made of her hair drawn neatly back into a low bun. Her blazer sat perfectly on her shoulders as she pushed through the gate, the squeal of it echoing into the surrounding area.

Steps behind, Wanda appeared. She turned to speak with somebody behind her, likely Embassy security, and motioned to the gate before following Rio out.

Agatha watched them turn down the sidewalk, Wanda’s hand pressing between Rio’s shoulder blades in an offer of comfort.

Agatha hissed, dropping the cigarette in her fingers as the smoldering end singed her skin. She clenched her teeth, eyes falling to the butt ashing and smoking on the patio tiles.

Alice offered Agatha another, retrieving a second for herself. She lit her own and held out the lighter for Agatha to take.

“You three were at Quantico together, weren’t you?”

Agatha flicked the lighter, blocking the wind with her now-dry hand as she took a drag. She grunted her affirmation.

Alice leaned against the white railing.

“Huh.”

And that was it. She didn’t pry, didn’t root around Agatha’s past like a messy junk drawer or make commentary on their career paths. Besides Alice’s recount of her mom’s perception of Agatha, she had never shown any kind of interest in understanding her.

Agatha handed back the lighter and sat down on the rickety, wooden chair. She looked at Alice’s profile for several long seconds before deciding she wasn’t quite interested in understanding her either.

They remained silent for the duration of their cigarettes, Agatha snuffing hers out in time. She sank into the nicotine buzz and rode it out until she was once more left with the empty ache that had created a home for itself in her chest. She slapped a hand on her knee and stood.

“Thanks for your generosity, Wu.”

She walked back into the hallway, down it, and stopped in front of the door to her room. A visceral replay of Rio falling apart against her dried out Agatha’s mouth. She turned toward the bathroom instead to wash her hands and took the stairs down to the first floor. It was quiet but for a muted conversation from the kitchen. Agatha turned into the living room and found the intern a significant way through his heinously large book.

Agatha groaned but collapsed on the couch anyway. She grabbed a pillow and pressed it over her face.

The intern dove directly into the thousands of words he’d likely been building up since she’d banished him.

“Agatha! Holy shit, Alice said you guys were in some hot water.” He lowered his voice conspiratorially. “I totally saw Director Vidal here. I can’t believe she flew out for this. Do you think we’ll stay on the case?” He paused for her to answer but continued when she didn’t. “Are you guys getting fired? That would like, suck. You’re both my favorites.”

Agatha rolled the pillow off of her face so she could give him a disbelieving look.

“I don’t even know your name. Why are you lumping me in with Wu?”

The intern laughed.

“You know my name. You’re just grumpy. Besides, I’ve learned a lot from you and about you. You’re not as scary as you try to seem.”

Agatha groaned louder than before and reburied herself in the pillow. It smelled like old people. Her voice was muffled when she spoke.

“I’m napping. Don’t bother me unless god suddenly becomes real and is here to smite me.”

Agatha closed her eyes, her ears picking up the subtle sounds of the home and the rhythmic pattern of the intern flipping his pages. She let herself drift off, relieved at the prospect of a few hours without thought or feeling.

____________

There was something to be said about your mind betraying you in the worst possible moments.

Agatha dreamed.

She saw a Nicky that wasn’t really Nicky. He was older than her baby had ever gotten. He had long, brown hair and his blue eyes were bright with tears. He was being dragged away by a cloaked figure, the hand on his arm made of bone and nothing else. She was trying to run for him, trying to scream, but her legs were moving like they didn’t belong to her and her voice was too hoarse to be heard over Nicky’s cries.

Agatha fell, her knees scraping against stone, her hands scrabbling, sliding into a rough gouge.

She crawled into the dip and climbed out to find Nicky almost out of her sight. Panic choked her and she pushed herself to her feet as the cloaked figure looked back.

Rio. Her eyes were black, lines of crimson cried down her cheeks as she continued to walk Nicky away from her.

Agatha was struck still, her bloodied hands and knees dripping on the ground beneath her. When Rio turned away, Agatha found herself able to move. She sprinted but never gained ground.

Her feet hit forest floor and she stumbled, leaves kicking up around her as her body hit the floor. She tried to stand and spun, trying to catch sight or sound of her son. Her eyes passed over the stone and stilled.

It was large, so massive in its size, but Agatha could see the shape of it from here. Square at the bottom, round at the top. Letters etched into the face of it to be read and wept over until they eroded away.

Agatha couldn’t read most of the inscription but the name at the bottom was in sharp clarity. She pressed a hand against her mouth and curled over.

Agatha blinked awake as a hand gently shook her shoulder. Her heart was pounding in her chest. She focused her blurry sight on the intern as he leaned over her with a worried frown.

“God isn’t here to smite you but you were crying.”

Agatha wiped angrily at her cheeks as she sat up.

“Allergies.”

The intern frowned.

“I don’t think dream allergies are a thing.”

Agatha groaned and leaned into the back of the couch.

“How long did I sleep?”

The intern shrugged.

“Thirty minutes. I think Lilia is cooking a meal for everyone so I figured you’d want me to wake you before somebody else… saw.”

Agatha looked around the otherwise empty room. She could hear the clanging from the kitchen now and the smell of garlic and onion and tomatoes being cooked caught in her nose. Agatha rubbed her forehead and tried to shake off the groggy film in her head. Her heartbeat was slow to settle as anxiety set in. She hadn’t had nightmares about Nicky in two years.

The intern sat next to her and hesitated.

“Um, do you– who– you said a name while you slept.”

Agatha bristled, voice sharp.

“Don’t mention it.”

The intern nodded awkwardly.

“Okay, yeah. I’m sorry.”

Footsteps sounded from the hallway and Jen appeared at the arched entrance of the living room.

“Lilia wants to know if anyone is allergic to nuts.”

Agatha grimaced but latched onto the change of subject.

“Incredibly so.”

Jen rolled her eyes.

“The food.”

The intern shrugged.

“Some people like the other kind in their mouth too.”

A laugh ripped from Agatha before she could stuff it down, her eyes flying to the intern’s blushing cheeks. It would have been funny if he’d said it to be funny. Saying it offhand was so so so much better.

Jen looked appalled.

“Aren’t you a child?”

The intern sighed helplessly.

“I’m twenty!”

Jen gave him a once over, face still twisted in shock.

“Still. I’m telling Lilia no nut allergies.”

Agatha puckered her lips but it didn’t stop her laugh.

“No nut.”

The intern’s face burned brighter and Jen groaned loudly as she walked away, calling out behind her.

“Dinner in twenty! Don’t go anywhere or Lilia will leave sardines in your beds. Her threat, not mine.”

Agatha stood to leave.

“That’s my que.”

“For what?”

Agatha straightened out her incredibly wrinkled outfit.

“To hide. Enjoy family dinner.”

The intern looked startled.

“What about the sardines?”

Agatha huffed.

“Our rooms are locked for security reasons.”

She saw movement before she heard Wanda’s steps.

Wanda walked into the living room alone— to Agatha’s relief.

“I can give her access.”

Agatha feigned a smile. She was feeling overwhelmed and she would either find a way to escape or she’d make it everyone else’s problem.

“Looks like we’re all willing to break the rules.”

Instead of raising to the bait, Wanda tilted her head.

“Agatha, can I speak with you?”

Agatha felt a thud of dread in the pit of her stomach.

“You’re framing it like a question but I don’t feel like I can say no.”

Wanda rolled her eyes.

“Please stop making things so difficult.”

Agatha groaned, head falling back dramatically. She touched the interns shoulder as she walked toward Wanda.

“Nobody lets you have fun when you’re old. Keep that in mind.”

He smirked.

“I think you find your ways.”

Agatha winked back.

“True.” She breezed past Wanda into the hall. “Where do you want me, boss?”

Wanda motioned toward the front door.

“It will only take a moment.”

Agatha followed her outside, past the two security officers, and to the far side of the little yard where an old fountain sat broken and unused. There was a bench but Wanda didn’t assume to sit.

Agatha looked around them, her anxiety jumping.

“You have a secret to tell me?”

Wanda shook her head.

“No, Agatha, I wanted to talk about the case. About us working together.”

It felt like a strange kind of pity and Agatha’s skin crawled.

“Don’t bother, Wanda. I’ll make sure my penance looks really sincere.”

Wanda reached out and gripped Agatha’s arm, her eyes soft.

“No, I believe I made the point I needed to make.” Wanda released her, twisting her hand dismissively. “Ultimately, it got us to the next mile marker and I’m not going to sit here and pretend it didn’t.” She held up a finger. “Not that I want you doing it again. We got lucky.”

Agatha huffed.

“I was smart. There was nothing to get lucky about.”

Wanda rolled her eyes.

“Agatha, you made an educated guess– no, you played on a hunch– and happened to be right. If the new owner had been on the up and up, this situation would look very, very different.”

Agatha fidgeted with her fingers trying to ground herself. From the moment she’d found Rio in her room she felt as if she was having an out of body experience.

“We were wasting so much time, Wanda.”

“I know. Can you meet me halfway here? You found the doctored footage. If you had given me that information I could have put pressure where it was needed to get us on track. If you had spoken to me before making your calls, I could have pushed for a visit to Crete or gone over the Captain’s head. There were other options than you running off half-cocked.”

Agatha grimaced.

“I’ve never done anything with a cock.”

“Shut up, Agatha.”

Agatha chuckled and looked away, her eyes finding anything to look at besides Wanda. This heart to heart was a little too much to top off the day. She stared at the empty bird feeder with peeling, blue paint and rusting metal lacework.

“What happened to your neck?”

Agatha’s chest iced over, her lungs freezing, her body stilling. She remembered Rio’s nails digging into the skin of her neck, her shoulders, her back.

“I–” She didn’t know what to say. A bird tried to carry her off? The intern swung at her with a fireplace poker? She continued to fidget, her thumb and forefinger twisting around her finger. She pursed her lips. “I made the mistake of playing with a feral cat.”

It was silent for long enough that Agatha had to look. She found Wanda staring intently at the movement of her hands and only then realized what she was doing. It had been a habit before, when she still wore her ring, a slow, soothing twist of warm metal over skin. Agatha stilled, her hands falling to her sides as she watched whatever pieces of the puzzle Wanda had placed on her board start to lock in place.

Wanda’s head shot up.

“Oh my god, did you guys fuck?!”

Agatha’s eyes shot wide, her hand slapping over Wanda’s mouth like they were still in high school.

“Shut the fuck up, Wanda.”

Wanda stared– agape– her mind buzzing through possibilities.

“You really did a number on her lip–”

Agatha held out a hand.

“If you don’t stop talking I’m going to shoot you.”

Wanda spoke softer, her shock turning to concern.

“She did not seem happy when she left.”

Agatha grimaced.

“Nobody is happy. It was a mistake.”

Wanda’s expression fell.

“Agatha–”

Agatha shook her head, her guilt crashing back into her and turning her words bitter and harsh.

“Listen, we’re not friends, Maximoff. You’re my boss. I’m the fuck-up on your team that also happens to be staying in your guesthouse. Don’t get confused.”

Wanda didn’t flinch at the force of the words. She took a step back.

“I’m sorry, Agatha. I shouldn’t have pried.” She moved to pass Agatha but slowed at her shoulder. “But you’re wrong. I’ll be here when you’re ready to talk about it.” She called back as she walked to the house. “You’re not getting out of dinner. I’ll see you inside.”

____________

Dinner was a strange affair. Agatha had poured herself a heavy glass of wine and finished it within minutes as they all gathered at the round, wooden table in the kitchen. Chairs scraped on hardwood floors and there was a round of ceramic clinks as Jen and Lilia placed dishes in the center of the table. The intern had waxed poetic about the food like he’d never eaten a meal in his life and Alice and Wanda thanked them graciously.

Agatha had drank.

The food was undeniably good. A penne pasta with tomato sauce, sauteed and sliced eggplant, ricotta salata, basil, and pine nuts as the main dish. They’d added sides of mixed green salad and marinated olives and artichokes. Agatha ate as much as possible to ensure her mouth was always filled with food or wine so the popcorned questions were never turned toward her.

By the time she’d finished half of her plate she was on her way past a healthy buzz.

It was jarring. So many faces of people she hardly knew, that hardly knew each other, sitting around and talking like they cared. It felt uncomfortably warm, achingly happy. It was the kind of space she couldn’t relax in.

Lilia had kept pace with Agatha’s wine intake but her flushed cheeks fed into the open joy she was showing. She laughed loudly at Jen—absurd—her eyes watering as she patted the table.

“There’s no way!”

Jen nodded repeatedly, her lips pulled into a grin.

“I literally delivered this woman’s baby after being shot by her husband. He was handcuffed, screaming from the bathroom, and my partner at the time had belted a brand new stuffed animal against the bullet wound in my calf to stop the bleeding.”

Wanda was chuckling along, her head tilting to look down at Jen’s leg.

“How long were you waiting for help?”

Jen sighed, her smile softening a bit.

“Thirty minutes. The most stressful minutes of my entire life.”

The intern seemed deeply shocked, his face held in his hands as he listened.

“It sounds like a movie script.”

Jen laughed.

“Wait until you hear the husband's profession.” She paused for dramatic effect, then, “Obstetrician.”

There was a collective wail of laughter and Jen seemed to soften before Agatha’s eyes as she looked around the table in quiet awe.

Agatha looked down at her plate and shoveled a stack of leaves into her mouth.

Agatha heard the front door and tensed just as Jen directed a question at her.

“What about you, Agatha? Craziest scar?”

Agatha looked up as two figures stepped into the room.

Sharon shuffled quickly to the open chair by Alice and sat down.

“Oh my god, what a lovely meal. Lilia, you’re a saint.” She picked up the bottle in front of her. “Wine! Goody.”

Rio looked like marble, her lines carved to perfection. She smiled at the gathered group like her face hadn’t been painted with salt and makeup hours before. Like she hadn't been panting, riding Agatha's fingers.

Agatha felt her approach like an executioner as Rio walked to the only remaining spot available.

She hadn’t expected this. Hadn’t expected Rio to push back. She gave Jen her full attention knowing that it had already been too long without an answer.

“I have a few.”

The intern leaned forward eagerly and Agatha felt nauseous as all eyes fell on her sitting next to Rio. Wanda looked particularly interested and Agatha wished magic were real so she could disappear.

Rio’s tone was goading.

“Don’t leave us hanging, Harkness.”

Agatha cleared her throat, turning slightly in her chair so she could reveal the long scar at the back of her elbow.

“Knitting needle.” The memory of it brought an unbidden smile to her lips. “There was an extremist group, Daughters of Liberty. They were hellbent on bringing women back to their proper places in society and in the home. I know, the name doesn’t make sense.” She fought the urge to look at Rio. “My partner at the time was one of those guys that wasn’t overtly a piece of shit but he hadn’t seen the women as a credible threat.

“We’d been placed on a task force meant to clear what was falsely reported as a storage facility. It had felt strange from the jump but it was early in my career and my voice didn’t hold the weight it needed to. These women had left an array of honest-to-god booby traps on every floor of this building. My partner had seen a trip-wire and laughed, made a comment about the opacity as he stepped over and had promptly landed on a pressure plate.

Agatha shook her head. “I reached out and yanked him back by his neck and got a great souvenir. They’d sharpened the needles and stuck them in an air-pressured PVC pipe.”

The intern looked enthralled.

“Did he apologize?”

Agatha scoffed.

“No. He wrote in his report that I gave him whiplash. Thank fuck for bodycams.”

Wanda chuckled.

“I remember him. Ralph, right? You named every single one of our volleyball teams after him.”

Agatha grinned because that had likely been the sweetest revenge of her life.

“When you act like a dick and have a surname like Bohner, things aren’t going to pan out.”

A round of laughter surrounded her and Agatha noticed the warmth of the room beginning to seep into her chest. She chafed against it.

To her surprise, Rio spoke from beside her. She hadn’t touched the food on her plate and she was sitting rather relaxed against the back of her chair.

“I’ve got a scar.”

Agatha knew every single one. The puckered circle from a gunshot in the back of her shoulder, the jagged crescent on her ribcage from being thrown into a crushed, steel drum, the one on her forearm from the compound fractured she’d gotten as a kid in a hellish foster home. Rio was littered with stories and memories written across the panes of her skin.

Agatha’s mind careened back into her room, back into the pained, ragged break in time when she’d run her hands across Rio’s neck and jaw and scalp.

Rio chuckled.

“It’s actually from my eighth week at Quantico.”

Agatha stilled. She wouldn't.

But Rio seemed inclined, her elbows resting on the table very close to Agatha’s silverware.

Agatha would just need a quick flash to grab the knife and jam it in her arm. She’d create a new scar for Rio to talk about. Instead, she gripped the edge of the table.

“We were in the Hogan’s Alley training facility and the simulation was a bank robbery turned car chase.”

Agatha’s jaw clenched and she felt Wanda’s eyes on her.

“I was paired up with another agent and we were told to give chase. I was the driver, she was the passenger.” Rio laughed. “At some point in the chase, I was meant to complete a J-Turn and continue the pursuit. My companion saw a different opportunity.

“At the very start of the turn, she flung herself out of the car and rolled, firing two rubber-tipped rounds into the tire of the fleeing vehicle. In an effort not to drive a three thousand pound car over her, I had to yank the wheel the opposite direction. I ended up running straight into the side of the closest building and getting absolutely covered by pieces of the windshield. Getting hit at 220 by an airbag while you’re covered in shards of glass isn’t entirely pleasant,” Rio tilted her head to reveal the razor-thin scar that started at the bottom of her chin and trailed down to the start of her throat. “I fell out of that car covered in my own blood and all training was called off for the day.”

There were various looks of amused horror at the table and Agatha tried to keep her face free of any emotion.

The intern leaned forward.

“What happened to the agent?”

Rio grinned, Agatha could see the sly little smirk from the corner of her eye and she prepared for the reveal.

“She was in a lot of trouble until I said I’d been in on it. I told them I’d fucked up, not her. Instead of probation, both of us clocked the fastest time to complete. She became one of the most accomplished agents from our class.”

Jen huffed.

“She sounds like a lunatic.”

Rio laughed.

“Oh, she was.”

Agatha saw Alice’s head turn to her, her eyes narrowed in thought as she glanced between Agatha and Rio.

Agatha felt like she was walking a tightrope made of thorns coated in battery acid. She was torn between crashing her finished plate over Rio’s head and making a run for it.

Wanda saw it too and intervened.

“A record that I beat the next week.”

Rio rolled her eyes.

“We made the blueprint.”

Wanda pushed her plate away from her and chuckled.

“Semantics.” She gave Rio a near-reproachful look and turned to the rest of the group. “Lilia, Jen, thank you for the meal. This was really lovely. I’m going to show our Director to her room and then I’ll be happy to do clean-up.”

Nobody made a comment about the fact that Rio had barely eaten as she stood, her napkin set on her empty plate.

“Of course, thank you. This was lovely.”

There was a beat of silence as they left the room and it continued until their footsteps were heard on the second floor.

Then Jen was leaning forward conspiratorially.

“Do you think they fucked? You know, when they were in training together?”

Agatha was so struck by the statement that she nearly choked on the eggplant in her mouth. Sharon gasped, the intern went red, and Lilia wagged her finger.

“That is so crass, Jennifer.”

Jen rolled her eyes, head shaking.

“Oh please, you know what Quantico is like. It’s so high stress and you’re on base for weeks without much outer-world contact. You’re telling me you didn’t sleep with a bunch of your fellow agents in training?”

Lilia huffed.

“I didn’t say that. Who doesn’t?”

Jennifer pointed.

“Exactly. It’s a fair question. Do you think they fucked?”

Agatha drank four large gulps of her wine as the intern of all people pitched in.

“I did a lot of research on the WFO before I joined. And I’ve talked to a lot of agents that have been there a while. I’m pretty sure the Director was married at one point.”

Agatha wanted to puke.

Alice frowned at the intern.

“Why do you say that?”

He touched his sternum.

“The necklace she wears.”

Alice frowned.

“The knife-looking thing?”

He shook his head.

“No, she has two chains. Once I was at the WFO early to try out their gym and she was there. She was getting into the sparring ring with a Senior Agent and she took both off. The other looked like a ring.”

Agatha felt her heart shifting, breaking and grinding like tectonic plates in her chest.

Jennifer shrugged.

“Could’ve been. Although that doesn't negate my previous question." She pursed her lips. "It’s hard to keep a relationship in a job like ours.” She motioned around them. “Look at us. We’ve been here for almost a month. That’s always going to strain a relationship.”

Lilia pitched it with a lazy, drunken guffaw.

“My first and second marriages were not successful for that very reason. And also because they were jealous pricks.”

The blanket of booze brought out a ring of laughter and the conversation turned easily to Lilia’s first husband.

Agatha took that as her opportunity to stand.

“Well, this has been a pleasure, but I think it’s time for me to sleep.”

She carried her plate to the sink and rinsed it quickly. She did not offer to help clean as she headed for the hallway to a chorus of ‘goodnights.’

Agatha took the steps two at a time, stumbling near the top as the wine sloshed sickly in her stomach.

Rio wore her ring? Even now? Agatha’s head was spinning and she felt herself slipping back into her memory without resistance.

Rio’s fingers stroked at the soft skin of Agatha’s hip, her eyes lidded with alcohol and the lateness of the night. Agatha’s legs were on either side of Rio’s waist as she knelt astride her, their conversation giggled and mumbled between long sips of cheap beer.

Agatha rested the bottom of her bottle on Rio’s stomach where her shirt had ridden up and Rio hissed at the cold.

“Did you see that Bohner proposed to his girlfriend?”

Rio’s eyes rolled back as she laughed, her throat bared to Agatha’s hands if she were so inclined to place them there.

“I can’t believe she said yes. Do you think he’ll take her last name?”

Agatha feigned shock, her hand resting on Rio’s chest instead as she took another sip.

“And lose his greatest chance at a legacy?” She watched the way the lamp light glittered in Rio’s eyes. “He wouldn’t dare.”

Rio laughed and tried to find a way to drink, shifting and twisting under Agatha before collapsing back and whining drunkenly:

“I’m dying of thirst.” She tossed her head dramatically, the back of her hand pressed to her forehead. “It has been a pleasure knowing you. I bequeath to you my entire record collection and the pile of dirty socks in our hamper that you refuse to wash.”

Agatha cackled, her heart brilliant and alive and filled with a joy she had only ever found with Rio.

“I missed them one time!” She finished her beer and set it to the side before taking Rio’s. “Open your fucking mouth, I’m going to quench your thirst.”

She started to tilt the beer over Rio’s head as Rio nearly screeched, her hand coming up to block it.

“Unhand me!”

The struggle that followed was sloppy and filled with tired laughter. It ended as the beer dropped to the floor and rolled a trail of amber across the shitty carpet in their living room.

Agatha collapsed onto Rio’s chest and burrowed into her neck as she continued to laugh. Rio’s arms wrapped around her, her own amusement quieting as they sank into one another.

Minutes later, Agatha mumbled.

“I bet Ralph got his girlfriend a heart-cut diamond.”

Rio hummed her agreement.

“I’ve always liked the men’s rings more.”

Agatha nodded, her lips pressing a kiss into Rio’s jaw.

“I think I do too. They’re not in the way. They don’t cripple your finances for years, they’re stronger.”

Rio was silent for several seconds, her hands drawing slow patterns on Agatha’s back. Her voice came out softly, hesitant.

“Would you marry me? If I asked, I mean?”

The words didn’t scare Agatha. She didn’t sully the question with a joke. She was hopelessly, desperately in love with the woman below her.

“In any lifetime.”

Agatha bit her lip to draw herself back from her delirious stupor. She wiped the tears on her cheeks with a heavy-handed palm and walked to her door to lean against it.

Her hands were shaking, uncoordinated as she tried to unlock it. She looked down, felt the pull of the fresh scabs on her neck, and felt a scream boiling in her chest.

With forced focus, Agatha shoved her key in the lock and let herself inside. She breathed heavily, resting against the wall, before stumbling toward the bed.

Agatha drew to a sharp halt as she took in the bright red Hyacinth sitting in the center of her comforter.

Chapter End Notes

Red or Pink Hyacinth: Sport, Game, Play

Chapter 10

Chapter Notes

Hello! I'm so blown away by the support I've received for this story. Your comments are so uplifting and motivating; the amount of time I spend every day at work writing this story instead of doing my job has become criminal. Thank you all so so much. I will try to get to responding as soon as I can. The past few days have been hectic.

I'm attaching the link to the playlist. The beginning is pretty chronological and then it becomes more of a vibe. If you have any suggestions please share! Just remove the spaces.

https: // open.spotify.com/playlist/ 4F8izxvVBJGmnHRf046ASf?si=dlx5sjO2R4OTlA3iFtyFLw&pi=u-iwqDB3D0QkC2

I'm also considering commissioning art for this story. What would you guys want to see depicted? Also, if anyone knows an Agathario artist they like, please send me their instagram/twitter/tumblr. I want to support other artists in this fandom.

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Agatha rubbed her temples in irritation, her eyes closed to block out her own image reflecting back at her as she waited for Dr. Alder. She’d put off the session for as long as she could for the past week, claiming complications with the case. Alder had accepted her excuses until just an hour prior when she had sent Agatha a Zoom link with no other message.

Agatha had taken one of the private meeting rooms at the ROC and was waiting for it to connect.

The past week had been complex.

To her surprise and the surprise of the team, Alice and her had been kept on the case. Apparently, Sharon and Rio had developed and profferred a written disciplinary plan with an addendum that they remain on the case. The Chief of Police had accepted with minor amendments.

Agatha had not been privy to what the document contained, but to be allowed to remain, she was certain she wouldn’t like it. They’d been able to track the Porsche to a shipping magnate named Alessandro Veridi. He had few knocks on his record, likely due to his influence in politics and local law enforcement. Inspections on his vessels had come back sparkly and clean for the past ten years; far too clean.

By the time they had his name, Veridi had disappeared with whatever evidence connected him to their victim, likely warned by the Captain before his arrest.

But Agatha had a feeling that the remainder of the case, in some ways, was inevitable. The only malleable factor beyond the depth of Veridi’s involvement and how long he spent in prison would be whether or not Georgina had been disposed of to eliminate loose ends.

Agatha groaned. She needed this to be over.

After her moronic behavior with Rio, Agatha had been distracted. Rio hadn’t returned to DC when Sharon had left. She’d said it was to facilitate diplomacy— whatever the fuck that meant— and to ensure compliance.

Agatha might have believed those to be the only reasons if Rio hadn’t become painfully impossible. She was suddenly everywhere, always.

If Agatha was pouring herself a coffee, Rio would flit into the room like an obnoxious little wasp and treat her like a troublesome subordinate. ”Good morning, Agent Harkness. Plan to break any laws today?”

At one point, Agatha had attempted to search through the HPD database in an effort to locate Veridi’s leverage-able connections. She’d found her access blocked.

In approaching Wanda, she was given a bemused frown and told to check with the Director.

Agatha had been forced to hunt down Rio, who had been provided a personal space to work. The conversation had gone as expected.

”Why am I locked out of the system?”

Rio’s eyes lifted to her with a distinct lack of consideration, her mask firmly in place.

“Agent Harkness. I believe knocking would be appropriate for any future visits.”

Agatha’s hands curled into fists and she placed them behind her back.

“Cut the shit. Why don’t I have access?”

Rio returned her attention to her computer.

“You have clearly shown a lack of self-control since arriving here in Athens. I’ve witnessed it personally. Until I believe you are capable of following orders, I am expecting you to keep me in the loop of your specific pursuits.”

Agatha breathed through her clenched teeth. She was aware that Wu was expected to do something similar and, on paper, nothing was amiss. But she knew every form of Rio fucking Vidal. From her unwavering dedication to her vicious, scheming mind, Agatha had experienced it all.

Rio’s tells were in the simmering lights in her eyes, the subtle lilts and emphasis in her words, the harsher lines of her suits and composure. Her button-downs were no longer rolled at the elbows, her jackets never came off, every wrinkle had been ironed out. Agatha hated it.

Rio had never been made for clean lines. She wasn’t meant to be buttoned up and tucked away. It had been a daily ritual when they were married. Rio would fasten the buttons on her shirt, perfect herself in front of their bathroom mirror, and Agatha would undo the top two, sometimes three if she could get away with it.

Rio would smirk or laugh or roll her eyes like she was surprised.

Agatha groaned and pressed her palms into her eyes. What a fucking bitch.

“I was waiting for you to finish your internal struggle but I think it might last for the entirety of the session.”

Agatha dropped her hands and blinked at Dr. Alder’s icy blue eyes staring back at her. She wasn’t sure what to say and so she said nothing.

Alder smirked.

“Ah, okay. Why don’t you start by telling me what happened.”

Agatha huffed.

“A lot of things happened. Do you want the list?”

“No. I want to hear what caused you to postpone our session for an entire week.”

If Agatha was capable of pouting, she’d expect that was the face she made then.

“I’m not ready to talk about it.”

Alder had the audacity to chuckle.

“I may insist as I believe you are. You are wearing it quite plainly on your face.”

Agatha was so tired. She dropped her chin onto one hand and looked over the computer screen to stare at the blank wall.

“I fucked my ex.”

To her credit, Alder’s brows only slightly raised.

“That is a development.” She studied Agatha’s face. “Am I getting that you did not mean it?”

Agatha scoffed.

“I barely thought it. I feel so— so helpless with the way she talks to me.”

“How does she talk to you?” When Agatha didn’t answer, Alder tilted her head. “Like she cares?”

Agatha sighed, her fingers twisting together.

“Sure.”

Dr. Alder hummed.

“It seems like you struggle when anyone shows care for you. Have you considered why that is?”

“I generally try not to consider anything.”

Alder pursed her lips.

“We’ll disregard that non-answer. I’m going to ask you a question and I’d like an honest answer. Even if that answer is a yes or a no.” She paused then, “Do you feel guilty when they care?”

If one could be punched in the heart, Agatha imagined this is what it would feel like.

“Yes.”

Alder took down notes before lifting her notebook and flipping back several pages.

“When we did your intake you said you were not experiencing any suicidal ideation. Is that still the case?”

Agatha shifted uncomfortably.

“Yes? I mean, I make jokes, but even in some of my more… terrible moments, I never thought I would kill myself.” She tilted her head back and forth. “I would have been okay dying, maybe. But never by my own hand.”

Alder flipped her pages back.

“Why do you think you feel guilt when others show you how they care?”

Agatha tossed out a hand.

“I don’t fucking know! What does any of this have to do with anything!”

“Lower your voice, Agatha. Think. Answer as best you can.”

Agatha wanted to be difficult. She wanted to plead the fifth like she’d done so many times before. But the weight of the ache crushing her chest and ravaging her head were becoming rather untenable. If she could just get some relief…

“I just don’t understand.”

“Understand what?”

Agatha thought about the efforts she’d gone through to distance herself. She’d left, for fucks sake. She’d ignored texts and calls and letters and the one or two or three times people had actually shown up. She’d been a vicious, unforgivable cunt.

“They won’t just give up!” It sounded pathetic, a waver in her voice as it gave out at the end. She sucked in a breath. “Have some fucking self-respect. Stop trying. Stop thinking things can go back to the way they were before, that I can be the person I was before.” She felt her rage and grasped for it. “It’s embarrassing to watch them grovel.”

Alder scribbled in her notebook and every scratch stoked Agatha’s anger. She dug her nails into her palm.

Alder looked up and seemed pleased.

“You’re an asshole because you think they’re pathetic for caring?”

Agatha groaned.

“I hate everything you’re saying to me.”

“You don’t like that we’re looking past your defense mechanism.” Alder tapped on her notebook. “I am going to say something that will hurt you. It will make you angry.”

Agatha scoffed out a laugh but her anxiety peaked.

“What if you didn’t do that?”

Alder grinned.

“I’m going to do it. You deserve the truth even if you don’t want it.” Alder paused, then, “People loving you through difficulty is a strength. It speaks to their character. With what you’ve told me about your behavior, they would have every right to step back even though your actions are born of grief, of unhealed trauma. It’s impressive they have stayed this long. It doesn’t mean they will stay forever.” Alder held out a hand to halt Agatha’s interruption. “You may claim to want that, fine.” She shrugged. “Then do the work. Do the healing. Tell them you have no interest in maintaining your connection. Leave.”

Agatha’s rebuttals died out at the thought of, after everything, leaving again. She stared at Alder and said nothing. Every word felt like the slow slide of a dull blade through her skin and between her ribs.

Alder finished driving the knife in.

“Something has to give, Agatha. The manic, destructive way you are existing in the world is not sustainable. The suffering you’re inflicting on the people around you, on yourself, it will write its own ending if you don’t take control.”

Alder was right. Agatha was angry. The words hurt. They clawed and ripped and pried until she was bare and bleeding. She could hardly swallow the lump in her throat. Her eyes were blurred by a thin film of tears.

“I don’t know how.”

Alder offered a gentle smile.

“That’s what we’re here for. When I told you that you had to want your own healing, I didn’t just mean I needed you to show up to our sessions and bare your soul. This is a single step up an incredibly steep incline. Stop pushing away the people that are offering you a hand.”

Agatha sniffed, her throat clearing. Fear clung to her ribs and begged her to bite. She pushed through.

“I’m—“ She nearly bit through her tongue. “What if it doesn’t work? What if I lose more?”

Alder raised her brows.

“What else do you have to lose now? Can you honestly tell me that the love you’ve had in your life wasn’t worth it? That you would change a single thing if you knew what would come after?”

Agatha felt the answer in the enamel of her teeth, the muscles of her jaw, the press of her tongue on the roof of her mouth.

“No.” She started to tap her heel into the floor. “But I’m not the same. I can’t be the same. She doesn’t exist.”

“Who? You talk about yourself like you died, Agatha. It may have felt like that, it might still feel like that. But you are right here. You are alive and you are just as capable and worthy of love now as you were before.”

It rang false, but Agatha didn’t want Alder to think she was being difficult.

“I’m not— it’s not like—“ She shook her head. “How? How is it possible that who I’ve become deserves their patience? Deserves their empathy?”

Dr. Alder shrugged.

“Our worst moments don’t define us. We make mistakes. Our greatest harms are often inflicted on those we care about the most. It’s a human condition.”

“I’m going to fuck up so much.”

Alder laughed. Too loudly if Agatha was allowed to have that opinion.

“Oh god, of course you are. Everyone does. It’s unfortunate that your reflex to conflict is so pointed, but edges can be dulled.” Alder pulled her computer closer and began to type. “I’m going to send you a document. I want you to go through it at the end of every day. If you notice a pattern, write it down and bring it to our next session.”

Agatha grimaced.

“Homework seems a bit excessive.”

Alder pushed her laptop back after sending.

“I can add more if you’d like something to complain about.”

Agatha crossed her arms over her chest feeling like a kid in the principle’s office.

“That’s not necessary.”

Alder smirked.

“Great.” She sobered and gave Agatha a serious look. “Don’t beat yourself up when your defenses come out. Just because they’ve grown teeth doesn’t mean that their original purpose wasn’t good. You have every right to protect yourself, just not from everything. If you bite, recognize it and do better the next time.”

Agatha felt the buzz in her pocket, likely Alder’s email.

“Sure. Yeah. Okay. Are we done?”

Alder made a point of looking at her watch.

“We still have twelve minutes. I’d like you to tell me what you plan to do about Rio.”

____________

 

”Try not to feed into any kind of competition. If you want to pursue her, you have to do it the right way. If you need to walk away, she deserves to know that.”

Easier said than done. She and Rio had never done anything the right way. They’d never been good at taking things slow or thinking through their actions. From Agatha’s first introduction to the woman, she had been enthralled. She’d launched herself out of a moving car without thought to impress her for Christ’s sake.

Rio had taken a risk to defend her after Agatha had nearly broken her perfect face. And that was before they’d even held a full conversation.

They had never existed in spaces of half-effort. Agatha shook her head and stood, folding her laptop in her arms.

What happened with Rio was like breathing. It happened without thought, without awareness, until something changed. Until easy breathing turned into a gasp or a sob or a silence so enduring it felt like death. Trying to make herself aware, trying to control it… it felt wrong.

Agatha could give a little leeway to Wanda. Maybe. The team. If the timing lined up.

She stepped from the room and walked back toward the command center with a gnawing pit in her stomach.

The intern waved at her as soon as she entered.

“I’m sorting through Alessandro Veridi’s property records. We’ve pinpointed several possible locations of interest that might be large enough to operate out of.”

Okay. She could be less of a bitch. Totally.

“Well done, William.”

Five sets of eyes fell to her at once, shock and confusion swarming her. Agatha nearly vomited.

She waited for anyone to say something to break the deeply awkward silence in the room. She sat in deep embarrassment until she was forced to do it herself. She snapped, giving him a look.

“Are you going to read me in or stare like a trout? Fish don’t have a lot of qualities that make a good agent.”

He blinked as the rest of the team began to relax.

“Um, sorry, yes!”

He began to walk her through what he’d found and Agatha tried to listen through her incredibly loud discomfort. Being kind was overrated.

____________

Rio sat before the team in her perfectly buttoned dress shirt and Agatha had to force her gaze away from the collar. It looked suffocating,

Wanda nodded toward the intern.

“William, please.”

He stood, his eyes eager as he pulled up an image of the first location. It was an overhead of a large industrial building set against the water. Three docks protruded from it.

“This is a small dock that belongs to Veridi. It’s our highest point of interest due to the easy means of transportation and general isolation. It’s not one of his company’s shipyards and it is marked for personal use. The closest building is four miles away and it’s a holiday home. The owners spend most of the year traveling.”

He flipped to the next image. A side view of a partially constructed building with metal siding and exposed beams.

“This is a plot of land Veridi purchased four years ago with the intention of putting in a sports facility. Building was started and never completed so it’s sitting as mostly a frame with sections of outer wall completed.”

The intern moved to the next, a building with large windows and red panels that mimicked a barn.

“This is a location on-site of Veridi’s house. It’s a barn-type structure—“

Agatha interrupted.

“It’s not going to be his private shed.”

Wanda gave her a look.

“Why don’t we finish the briefing before we offer rebuttals.”

Agatha sighed.

“It’s a waste of time. He’s not going to commit crimes on his own property.”

Lilia shrugged.

“I’d have to agree. He’s in this position because he’s smart.”

The intern pulled up several documents with strings of numbers and codes.

“There’s an exorbitant amount of electricity funneling into the secondary structure.”

Agatha waved it off.

“He’s a wealthy bastard. Think of any other reason he might want a separate space from his wife and family? Work? An at-home theater? A place to take his affair partners?”

Rio interrupted cooly.

“Forgive me if I’m not willing to rely on your hunches when making calls on the remainder of this case, Agent Harkness.”

Agatha met her head-on, jaw tight. She could have used Lilia’s backing to push her point. She did not.

“Maybe wear a tie if you’re going to have such a long stick up your ass.”

Rio’s dark eyes narrowed slightly and Agatha could see Wanda press her forehead into her palm. The remainder of the team held their breath.

Rio looked at the intern, completely disregarding Agatha’s comment.

“Please, continue.”

He did, pushing through the thick tension in the room, his gaze flicking toward Agatha and Rio intermittently.

He explained their findings, the puzzle-work that had revealed the why behind each location and the easiest access points for an infiltration team.

Throughout, Agatha kept her eyes on the blank desk in front of her. Her hands were clammy where they were clenched on her thighs. Every time she looked up she kept finding the crisp lines of Rio’s collar, the way it covered too much of her throat. She was going crazy. That had to be it. There was no other reason her fingers would itch to act on such an absurd compulsion.

She didn’t listen to the follow-up questions Rio presented, nor did she take any notes on the list of details Rio wanted hammered down before they delivered this information to the HPD.

Their newly appointed team had been working on Veridi’s financial records in a separate space to keep the peace.

She was so stuck in her thoughts that Rio’s next words were jarring.

“Agent Harkness, a word.”

Agatha looked up and met Wanda’s tired expression. She blinked, looked to Rio.

“Just one?”

Rio’s head tilted in the direction of her temporary office and Agatha looked toward the exit of the ROC with longing. She stood and followed Rio from the command center with anticipation heavy on her tongue and curious eyes at her back.

They walked silently through a string of hallways but Rio stopped them before they reached anywhere that could be considered truly private. But nobody else was around them; it seems this hallway was rarely used. Agatha’s stomach dropped.

Rio turned, her expression muted, but she easily moved a step too close.

“Agent Harkness, your suspension is still on the table.”

Agatha broiled. A echo of warning clanged in the back of her skull as she took the bait.

“Did a quick orgasm still your hand last time? I can provide my services again.”

To her disappointment, Rio offered a bland smile.

“That won’t be necessary.” She turned, started to walk away. “Please do keep in mind that your continued presence on this case is only at my permission.”

Agatha caught Rio’s arm without thought, her fingers curling tightly around the blazer and half-turning her. She stared at the way Rio’s jaw flexed, how Rio didn’t turn her head, how Rio’s eyes fell to the hand on her arm.

Agatha should have seen the threat, should have felt the walls closing in. Instead, she let her hand move without much thought, her fingers dipping into the groove of Rio’s collarbone to her throat. She brushed the sensitive skin before trailing to the plastic button at the top.

With deft movement, the memory in her muscles and tendons worked in tandem, Agatha undid the top button, then the second, her own chest raising and falling too quickly.

She moved to the third and Rio caught her hand like she always used to. Now, instead of a pleased laugh or a gentle shove of Agatha’s arm, Rio’s fingers locked around her wrist tight enough to sting. She met Agatha’s eyes with vicious triumph sitting in her expression.

“Watch yourself, Agent. Desperation isn’t always pretty.”

Agatha’s teeth ground tight. She was on her back foot now. She’d overstepped, showed too much, and Rio had been waiting for it.

She yanked her hand free of Rio’s grip. She turned to leave but stilled, not wanting to leave in this deficit of power. There were so many things clamoring to fall from her mouth, to cut and tear, and then Rio’s fingers grazed her spine.

Agatha’s lips parted, her eyes closed, and none of those words came out.

Rio’s fingers touched her hair, sending shivers through her. A second hand pressed against the back of Agatha’s ribs. Rio was the one to speak, arrogance laced in every word.

“I expect you’ve been ready for me for days.” Her voice carried that tone, the one that dragged Agatha’s mind into the pits of hell. Rio breathed in. “I expect if I were to touch you…” She let out in a heavy sigh, “you’d be dripping for me.”

Agatha bit the inside of her mouth to remain silent. She was under no illusion that this was the start of a very dangerous romp at the ROC. Rio would give her nothing after Agatha’s power grab at the consulate house. Still, the thought of walking away before Rio got her point across wasn’t one she could entertain.

Rio’s fingers twisted strands of hair together, tugged lightly.

“I know if you touch yourself, it won’t be enough. I know that you’ll think of me when you try. You’ll hate me when you can’t quite get there.”

Agatha felt exposed, like every nerve in her body was at Rio’s command. She didn’t breathe. Her losing option would be to give in, to turn and let herself be picked apart. God, she wanted to.

Rio’s fingers sifted through Agatha’s hair, touched the nodules of her spine, then closed around the back of Agatha’s neck.

“When you’re entirely out of options, when you’ve tried everything, you can call me. You can beg me.” She sunk her nails in. “You’ll find that you hate me even more when I give you exactly what you need.”

Rio released her and Agatha heard her footsteps fade.

She stood in the hallway for several moments so the harsh blush she knew to be on her cheeks would settle. She glanced around but, as expected, Rio had stopped them there for a reason. The single camera in sight looked to be under repair, its wires loose, the lense aimed at the floor.

Agatha sucked in lungfuls of air, shook her head, and made her way back toward the command center.

It was almost comical. It had been three hours since her conversation with Dr. Alder and she was sure that every action she’d taken had gone against the wise suggestions of her therapist.

She slowed as she neared the room, trying to ground herself. Her thighs were slick against one another, the tight coil of want in her belly pulsing in time with her rapid heartbeat. She pressed her head against the wall for a moment to cool down.

The problem, Agatha considered, was that Rio wasn’t wrong. Agatha had already tried twice to relieve the building pressure in her chest and between her thighs. It felt like a poor substitution, like she’d lost the ability to connect with her own body.

She tried to imagine what Rio would do to her if she could allow herself to stoop so low. The options were endless, consuming, and Agatha drew in a sharp breath.

She was so fucked.

____________

 

It took two days to gather the information Rio had requested. Two days of being stuck in the same building with Rio’s words held over her head like an anvil. She hadn’t tried to touch herself again; a part of her certain that if she never attempted it, the need would dissipate.

It didn’t. Agatha was grumpy and irritable and she definitely hadn’t opened the worksheet Dr. Alder had sent her. How could she focus on her own patterns of toxic behavior when she was agonizing over the moment she gave in.

It was a foregone conclusion. No matter the efforts made in the coming days, weeks if she found some self-respect, Agatha would falter. She would summon the devil to give her relief and the devil would provide further torture.

Agatha fell asleep with an ache between her thighs, she dreamed of domineering hands, of harsh words, and she woke in the morning cursing Rio’s name in the mirror as she brushed her teeth.

Now that Rio had thrown the gauntlet, she seemed to have disappeared. She’d released her tight, controlling grip after placing the ball firmly in Agatha’s court, knowing Agatha wouldn’t be able to walk away.

Rio had given Wanda the task of monitoring Agatha’s use of the database. She no longer appeared just to ruffle Agatha’s feathers, she no longer walked around buttoned up with her crisp suit jackets sitting on her shoulders. She spent a significant amount of time in her office and left the case to Wanda and the team.

Near the end of the second day, Agatha was trying to focus on the case.
