She was twisting in her office chair, the seat rocking side to side as she dug through the organizations tied to Veridi’s private dock, noted persons of influence that might throw a wrench in their plans if they moved in. William was beside her, his thick brows furrowed in thought as he did the same for the half-crafted sports facility.

He nudged Agatha with his foot.

“What contractor did you say worked on the dock?”

She looked at his foot beside her calf and rolled her chair away, shooting him a look.

“For one, keep your dirty shoes off of my pants.” She shoved a document into his face. “Two, it was Viron Holdings.”

He rolled his eyes as he took the paper.

“You don’t have to pretend I’m annoying you. I bet you like working with me more than the rest of the team.”

Agatha grimaced.

“I like that you’re too inexperienced to outshine me.”

William grinned as he looked idly through the file.

“Get ready to be blinded, then.” He leaned forward and set two separate work orders in front of her. “Viron Holdings was responsible for two of Veridi’s other projects.” He pointed at the first. “That’s the sports facility.” His finger shifted to the second. “That there is his ‘private shed,’ as you put it.”

Agatha pursed her lips, looking over the documents. She chuckled.

“I bet if you looked a little further, you’d find Viron Holdings was hired for a good portion of his projects.” Agatha pushed the pages back toward him. “Not every similarity means there is correlation.”

His head tilted down, lips pulling into an embarrassed frown.

Agatha felt a twinge of something in her chest and tapped the table.

“If something in your gut is telling you that barn is important, the worst thing you can do is listen to somebody telling you it’s not. Even if that somebody is me.”

William offered a wry smile.

“You said it would be a waste of time.”

Agatha shrugged.

“It could be. But you’ve got a lot of jaded people on this team and fresh eyes are always a good thing. The key to pursuing a flimsy lead is keeping it to yourself until you know you’re right. Until you have the proof and you can smash everyone’s faces in the proverbial cake.”

William laughed, his self-doubt erased, and the twinge in Agatha’s chest eased away.

“Is that what you did with the footage and the hotel?”

Agatha scoffed and looked back to her own work.

“No. That’s the common lesson of asking for forgiveness, not permission.” Agatha offered him a wink. “And I don’t usually ask for either.”

He grinned and looked back down, expression turning to consternation.

“I don’t actually know where to start with my flimsy lead.”

Agatha turned toward him fully, kicking his legs so he spun away and had to right himself. She slumped in her chair and steepled her fingers across her stomach.

“What about the barn is setting off your instincts? Start there.”

He slumped to match her pose, even going so far as to mimic her hand placement.

“Okay.” He frowned. “It’s the type of building. Why shape it like a barn when you already have a building for storage in use on the property. Why not just create a second home?”

Agatha loved playing devil’s advocate.

“Personal taste? It’s noted that Veridi grew up on a farm. Touch of history.”

“Okay, but what about the security measures? We can’t access the full building plans, but we know that he used state of the art systems to secure it.”

Agatha shrugged.

“Veridi has wealth. Why wouldn’t you protect what you own?”

William sighed as he shuffled through pages to find the image of the barn.

“I don’t know. Maybe it’s nothing. It’s just–” He stared at the page. “It feels wrong.”

Agatha reached over and took the picture, her eyes searching, studying.

William kept talking.

“The blueprints for the shed stated it was going to be two stories but they built it as one. Why?”

Agatha hummed.

“Changes are made in the midst of construction pretty regularly. Most projects aren't completed exactly as expected.”

“What about the windows? They’re reflective.” He paused and answered his own question with a sigh and a wave of his hand. “Could be anything. Privacy from the public, from his family. I get it.”

Agatha grunted her agreement to his self-rebuttal and narrowed her eyes, sitting up a little straighter. She pulled the image closer, eyes stuck on the odd blocks of cement that circled the barn.

“Well I’ll be fucking damned.”

William leaned forward.

“What?”

Agatha looked up and met his eyes with raised brows.

“Off the top of your head, why do you think barns don’t have basements?”

William’s head tilted in confusion.

“Stability? They’re pretty open structures.” He shrugged. “Usually they’re used for livestock. Anything needed is kept on the same floor or in the loft.”

Agatha pulled the file from his hands to sift through the construction plans. In the original two-story space, a massive pillar rose up from the center of it. It was rather unseemly but necessary to uphold a second floor. Agatha turned around the finalized blueprint so that it faced him.

“In the finished construction, they kept this support beam even though they decided against the second floor. Why?”

He deserved to put the pieces together himself.

William’s eyes widened, a brilliant smile appearing on his face.

“Because they didn’t change their plans. There are two floors.”

Agatha grinned.

“Bingo.” She set the picture of the finalized barn in front of William on the table. “Look.” She touched the concrete reinforcements spaced around the outside of the barn. “You saw these and it didn’t look right because, despite their commonality in most buildings, they aren’t needed for single-space structures.” Agatha crossed her arms, surprised nobody else had noticed the oddity. “That’s incredibly irritating.” She collected the evidence and held it all out toward William. “Go steal the spotlight.”

___

Agatha watched as William made his way across the large room to Wanda, his hands tight around the folders. She made a show of returning to her own task but kept her eyes on the interaction. William looked so proud and Wanda was clearly stoking that ego boost if her smile was anything to go by.

She was a good leader.

Agatha caught the easy compliment and frowned, trying to stomp it out before any more drifted into her mind.

Within the next hours, the rest of the team had been updated and a meeting was called for that night despite the lateness.

By nine-thirty, both the HPD and FBI were gathered in the command center to debrief and decide on next steps. The air was frosty with distrust but the Chief of Police for the HPD seemed to carry a deep respect from her subordinates.

Facts were presented by both teams and patched together over the span of multiple hours.

Apparently, Veridi’s shell-corporations, once found, had damning financial records with bribes and repeated sums of money pouring out toward political figures, members of the Hellenic Police Department, the Primary Regulatory Authority, the Port State Control, and multiple Classification Societies. It explained his spotless record and why he hadn’t been flagged in any system as a person with possible criminal intent.

Wanda presented their findings in return with multi-faceted breakdowns on the suspicious properties under Veridi’s name. She spent a significant amount of time fielding questions from the members of the HPD, many of which were efforts to throw doubt. Wanda maneuvered them with ease and Agatha chafed to give credence to Rio’s list of demands now panning out.

Creating a plan of action took longer than it should have and terse arguments cropped up from both sides. Currently, the new Major brought in to replace Daskalakis was pushing back against Jen’s suggestion that they place surveillance at each location.

“Risking alerting Veridi to our presence before we have legal right to infiltrate is foolish.”

Jen scoffed.

“Right, because a literal Captain of your department didn’t already sound that alarm? If we don’t get people on-site we risk far more.”

It was around this time that the Director decided to make her appearance. Agatha looked at the door before Rio walked through it, the hairs on her neck standing on end.

Rio was in a gray pantsuit and a black button-down sitting open at the collar like a taunt.

Agatha turned back toward the argument as Rio came inside and took a seat directly behind her.

Lilia had stepped in with a softer tone but her words were no less inciting of anger.

“We understand your privacy laws are strict. But there are legal methods to observe these locations without a warrant. The dock and facility are both businesses and they’re set within the eyesight of public roads. The only drawback is the house and we can comply with your laws while keeping somebody on-site.”

Agatha rolled her eyes as the Major dove into an in-depth explanation of Article 9 from their Constitution. She sat up, intent on interrupting, and felt a jolt at the back of her chair.

Agatha’s jaw snapped shut, her teeth making an audible click. It only solidified her conviction to stir the pot.

“If we needed to have a briefing on the Greek Articles, could you not have sent them in an email prior to this meeting? It’s nearly midnight.”

The Major’s eyes flickered over to her, mouth pulled in a hard line.

“It’s clear to everyone in this room that you are not equipped to be placed on such a sensitive case. There’s no need to prove the point further.”

Agatha pressed a hand to her chest, eyes taunting, voice lilting.

“You Majors are all the same. Is it a requirement of your position to be such a stuffy prick?”

The Chief of Police stepped in.

“That’s enough. Major Kostas, you are wasting time our victim does not have.” She looked to Rio, over Agatha’s shoulder. “Director, I know I don’t need to remind you about the decorum I expect from your Agents.”

Rio answered in kind.

“You do not. But I was assured, by you, that we would be able to continue this investigation in tandem with your people. It does seem that my team’s efforts are being delayed and thwarted by this new unit you’ve brought in.”

There was a moment of silence as the women stared at one another, their statuses clashing, standing firm.

The Chief of Police came to an executive conclusion.

“We will divide teams to ensure compliance with local ordinance. Major Kostas, you’ll pair with Agent Wu. Captain Ioannidis, with Agent Kale. Corporal Zervas, Senior Agent Maxifmoff and Agent Calderu. We’ll provide vehicles for the surveillance teams and Constables will be on call to provide immediate support.” Chief Koustou looked directly at Agatha. “Agent Harkness, you will remain here with your Director and me and provide tactical and operational oversight.”

Agatha could feel the challenge to the marrow of her bones. It was meant to draw out poor behavior, but she preferred to show that on her own terms. She stared back and said nothing at all despite the influx of emotions pattering drum beats on her chest. She could feel Rio’s presence at her back even as the attention in the room shifted toward logistics. She needed to expel some of this building energy before she did something drastic.

__________

They took two Embassy vehicles back to the consulate house around one-thirty in the morning and Agatha waited until Rio had climbed into the first to enter the second. She sat in silence as William and Alice spoke quietly to one another. She flexed her hands, then her arms. She rolled her shoulders and neck. She stretched out her legs.

Nothing helped the ache in her muscles.

As they walked into the consulate house, Jen commenting about needing a drink with a chorus of agreements to back her, Agatha peeled off toward her room. She closed herself inside and leaned against the door with a frustrated sigh, the pent-up irritation reaching a peak. She thought about Rio.

About the ease with which she could fix what Agatha was feeling if Agatha would only debase herself to ask.

Agatha dropped her head to her chest, stretching her neck so the healing marks made themselves known.

Feeling had always been Agatha’s flaw. She’d struggled to convert her emotions to something productive once they bypassed a certain threshold. Alder might say it was childhood trauma. Agatha would say it was an inconvenience that
Rio had always been able to work her through it.

She breathed and made the mistake of looking toward the wall where she’d fucked Rio.

“Fucking fuck fuck fuck.”

Agatha stormed toward her suitcase and kicked off her shoes. She tossed her slacks carelessly on the ground. Her sweater followed. With mindless focus, she threw on shorts and a t-shirt and stuffed her feet into her sneakers.

There was an exercise room in the house fitted with a treadmill but Agatha thought she might pass out if she didn’t leave. She couldn’t be in the same place as Rio when her body still remembered the best cure for its current state.

Agatha took the steps two at a time and almost crashed into Wanda as she reached the landing.

Wanda steadied her and frowned.

“Woah—“ she took in Agatha’s rather manic countenance and frowned. “Are you okay, Agatha?”

Agatha stepped back. Wanda’s hands felt like too much. They were too soft and too careful.

“I’m going for a run.”

Wanda didn’t lecture her on the time or the fact that leaving the consulate house alone was against protocol. She didn’t ask any questions, only offering a quiet request.

“Wait outside for me. I’ll go change.”

Agatha wanted to shake her. She wanted to remind Wanda why her kindness was being wasted.

Instead, she offered a nod.

And she waited.

She slipped past the murmur of voices in the living room and stood in the cool night air, ignoring the looks of the two security officers at the entrance. She let the light breeze touch the fire in her lungs as she stretched her legs and back.

Wanda exited the house like she expected Agatha to be gone.

Her eyes fell to Agatha and she didn’t waste time joining her in the yard. She followed suit, swinging her arms back and across her chest.

“Are we sprinting or taking a scenic jog?”

Agatha worked the muscles in her calves, her eyes fixed on the front gate.

“I need it to hurt enough that I can sleep.”

Wanda’s eyes softened but she didn’t push. They finished their warm-up in silence and Wanda followed as Agatha began to run.

Chapter End Notes

There may be some edits on this chapter once I'm able to step back from it and read it with a bit more objectivity. Hope y'all enjoyed :)

Also, a commenter called this story melanchorny and saductive and I wholeheartedly support that statement.

Chapter 11

Chapter Notes

I fixed the Spotify link in the notes of the last chapter. I’d accidentally left it on private lol.

This chapter is a little shorter but it gives a tiny break from the sad. A lot of time spent in flashbacks.

We’ll be closing up the case next chapter and heading back to DC.

Hope y’all enjoy.

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Agatha heaved in breath after breath, her muscles screaming and her lungs strung out from being overworked for the four miles she and Wanda had covered.

Agatha’s steps were jelly, her body numb and weary in a way that gave her hope. She stumbled through the gate with Wanda behind her; she was not faring much better.

Agatha let herself tumble into the grass and roll onto her back. She stared up at the stars and lifted her hands above her head as Wanda sat down next to her.

“Christ, Agatha.”

Agatha huffed out a laugh that turned into a cough, her smile lazy on her face. She could only hear her heartbeat in her ears, her mind completely empty of thoughts for the first time in months.

“You’re the one who kept speeding up.”

Wanda groaned and dropped back next to her.

“I just wanted it to be over.”

Agatha played with the spikes of grass by her head, twisting and tearing at them. She was quiet for a few beats of time, focused on the breeze drying the sweat on her skin. It had been ridiculous to do this so late and both of them would be paying for it in the morning.

Wanda hadn’t needed to join her but she had. No questions.

Agatha could give a little ground for that.

“Thanks.”

Wanda’s head rolled to the side so she could look at Agatha.

“Of course.”

Agatha didn’t look back. It was as simple as speaking a single word to bring the heaviness rushing back. She thought about what she was running from and closed her eyes to try and lose herself in her strained breathing.

Wanda spoke quietly.

“William told me that you were the one that found the discrepancy in the barn.”

Agatha sighed, lightly shaking her head.

“The kid doesn’t know how to seize an opportunity.” Agatha shrugged. “It’s his find. He saw something when the rest of us made assumptions.”

“He’ll be an incredible agent if he decides to pursue it.” Wanda’s fingers touched Agatha’s wrist once, then drew back. “You are a good mentor to him, Agatha.”

Agatha opened her eyes and slowly sat up, her knees drawing into her chest, her arms wrapping around them. It wasn’t ideal for her recovering lungs but it made her feel grounded; anchored. She groaned and pressed her forehead into her forearm.

They sat in silence for several minutes before a buzz sounded from her phone. Agatha withdrew it and laughed weakly.

“I think I’m going to lose ownership of Señor Scratchy to your son.”

Wanda sat up and leaned closer to see the image displayed on Agatha’s screen.

Vision had sent a video of Billy squealing as Señor Scratchy leapt from floor to couch and bounced around him, back legs kicking up. The bunny repeated the action several times, absolutely cruising around the living room in the guest house. Near the end, Senor Scratchy landed on the couch and simply flopped onto his side beside Billy.

Billy looked up at the screen with the widest, most innocent eyes as he reached out to run his fingers through Scratchy’s fur.

”Dad look, he likes me!

Wanda chuckled, her eyes a little faraway. She opened her mouth to say something, hesitated, then gave Agatha a wry grin.

“He’s not allowed to have a pet yet. But I do think you may have a frequent visitor when we get back. If you’re okay with it, of course.”

Agatha could see the ache in Wanda’s expression. She’d seen it many times before on longer assignments; she’d worn that expression too. Agatha felt inclined to speak to it, to let Wanda know she could talk about missing her family without Agatha crumbling.

She started to say just that, lips parting, when a pained sob threatened to spill out. Agatha sucked in a breath, dizzy with the rapid onset and angry at the weakness. She twisted at the ring finger of her left hand, pulling the skin hard enough to burn. She forced a normal tone.

“I’m sure Señor Scratchy will need more love than I can give him.”

It was all she could offer Wanda and it didn’t feel like nearly enough. Agatha pushed herself to her feet, the high from the run wearing off quickly enough that she was certain her sleep would come just as poorly as the nights before.

Wanda followed suit and they headed inside to a silent, sleeping house. They made their way to the second floor and Agatha kept walking as Wanda stopped at her door. She didn’t have any more words in her tonight. Her mouth felt like ash, like burned paper and dried flowers.

Wanda called to her as Agatha reached her own door.

“Good night, Agatha.”

Agatha pressed her key into the lock and escaped.

She lay wide awake, her eyes fixed on a black mark on the ceiling; possibly a squashed bug or a defect in the plaster. She blinked back the onset of tears several times, delirious and yet somehow restless. She thought about the hundreds of nights just like this that she had defeated with a hefty pour or several from a cheap handle or bottle of wine. It had been so much easier then, the sensations in her body dull enough to override, to distract herself from.

It was like driving back to DC had doused her in arctic water, had ripped her from a hazy dream where things were not good, but they were blunted. Agatha pulled her comforter to her chest and wished it was Nicky’s quilt. She turned to her side and the blinking no longer worked to stem the flow of tears.

”Are you still awake?”

Agatha quickly closed her eyes and said nothing.

Rio laughed tiredly and she reached out to poke at Agatha’s cheek and Agatha joined her laughter a moment later, her smile hidden in the dark as she collected Rio’s hand in hers and held it.

Rio rolled onto her side and Agatha glanced over, just able to make out the sleepy cast to her face.

Agatha squeezed her hand.

“Go back to sleep, darling.”

Rio’s fingers slipped from her own and touched gently between Agatha’s brows to ease the furrow there. She traced down Agatha’s cheek, ghosted the pads of her fingers across Agatha’s lips, and let her hand settle on Agatha’s sternum.

“Talk to me?”

Agatha’s shoulders relaxed slightly as she fixed her attention to the mild pressure, to the gentle strokes up the side of her neck. She let her hands fall to her swollen stomach and sighed.

“I don’t want to fail this child.”

Rio stilled and Agatha could feel the intensity of her gaze.

“You couldn’t possibly.”

Agatha smiled briefly, her head lolling to the side so she could meet Rio’s eyes.

“You have to say that.”

Rio didn’t match her amusement. She lifted herself so she could look down at Agatha, her expression serious.

“No, I don’t.” Rio studied her closely, her lips pulled into a thin line. “Why are you thinking like this?”

Agatha sighed.

“I don’t know what a mother is supposed to look like. My only experience– what if I’m like my–”

Rio cut her off quickly.

“You’re not.” The hand on Agatha’s chest pressed to emphasize Rio’s next words. “My love, there is not a single piece of you that could ever be like her.” Rio leaned down, pressed her lips to Agatha’s forehead. “Every single part of our lives has prepared us to give this child the things we were never afforded. All he will know is unconditional love and devotion and joy from his two really fucking kickass moms.”

Agatha laughed through fresh tears. She rolled carefully onto her side and felt a little thrill as Rio’s hand slid up, settled lightly on her throat.

“I knew you were going to look at the ultrasound you sneaky, little shit.”

Rio’s eyes widened almost comically and she leaned in to smother Agatha in kisses, her lips touching every part of her face as Agatha’s laughter increased.

Agatha put up a half-assed fight, her hands pressing at Rio’s jaw and forehead and brow as she shouted.

“You’re in so much fucking trouble, Vidal.”

Rio burrowed into Agatha’s neck and lips moving quickly, rhythmically as she spoke.

“It’s not my fault! It fell–”

“It was sealed!”

Rio groaned.

“It was an accident.”

Agatha wrapped her arms around Rio’s back, her face aching from her grin.

“You’re a liar and a scoundrel.”

Rio snickered, her teeth nipping at the sensitive skin beneath Agatha’s ear.

“You love me that way.”

Agatha playfully bemoaned that fact.

“Oh god, I do.” She slid her palm under the hem of Rio’s shirt, touching the soft panes of her back. “You cannot teach our child to be the same.”

Rio melted into Agatha’s embrace, a pleased hum in her throat.

“Cross my heart.”

Agatha huffed.

“We’ve already established that you’re a liar.”

Rio’s hand slid from the back of Agatha’s neck to her stomach, resting there for a moment before slipping to the stretchy hem of Agatha’s maternity pants.

“I can make it up to you.”

Agatha gasped as Rio’s fingers slid lower, parted her, began to tease. Agatha let out a breathy scoff.

“It doesn’t count for much when my increased estrogen levels do all the pre-work for you.”

Rio lifted her head and pressed a firm kiss to Agatha’s lips.

“I love when you talk dirty to me.”

Agatha’s laugh turned into a whine as Rio’s fingers sunk to the knuckles without resistance.

______________

Agatha woke the next morning to an alarming amount of sunlight drenching her room. She felt bad, but not nearly as awful as her barely three hours of sleep should have made her.

Agatha scrambled for her phone and her heart lurched in her chest as she saw the time. 8:05. The team was meant to be at the ROC by 7:00 to complete a short briefing and head out to their assigned locations. Agatha flung herself out of bed, wobbly legs nearly giving out as they took on her weight before they were ready. She grimaced as she pulled clean clothes onto her unshowered body. Her only clean pants were her navy slacks and she yanked them up her legs before stretching a navy sweater over her head. She shoved her feet in matching oxfords and half-donned the navy crew neck suit jacket before tumbling out of her room in full monochrome.

The house was entirely quiet and Agatha couldn’t believe they hadn’t woken her. She strode toward the door, opening her texts, when she heard movement from the kitchen.

Agatha slowed, eyes falling to the start of a text from Wanda stating that she could come in around nine due to the fact that she wasn’t going out in the field.

Agatha pocketed her phone as her panic tapered out and shoved her arm into the other sleeve of her jacket before walking in view of the kitchen.

William.

She breathed a sigh of relief and stepped into the kitchen only to find herself waylaid with the sight of Rio standing by the stove, her brows furrowed in annoyance. She looked absurd.

Black slacks, white tank top, checkered apron. The image was so confusing that it took Agatha staring for several moments before she realized that her heart was pounding in her ears.

Rio’s arms flexed as she tried to crack an egg against the edge of a bowl. The lithe form of her standing like a perfect portrait against the white walls, only marred by Rio’s clear agitation. Her hair was pulled into a loose bun and strands of it ghosted the edge of her jaw.

Nostalgia unlike anything Agatha had ever felt previously trickled down her spine and softened her, for just a moment, reverted her to a woman she had forgotten. She stared at the dark lines of tattoos peeking from Rio’s back, the way the fabric clung to her stomach, the stretch of it against her shoulder blades. Agatha’s mouth dried out.

It was a small clank from behind her that dragged her attention away. She turned sharply, nearly sending a chair across the kitchen floor, and found William staring.

Her cheeks burned and she quickly sat down, snapping at him.

“Your food is getting cold with all your gawking.”

William looked down at his bowl and frowned.

“This is cereal.”

Agatha grimaced, twisting her hand in dismissal.

William glanced over her shoulder and leaned closer.

“Director Vidal is scary.”

Agatha refused to turn and look. She noted Rio’s jacket sitting over the back of a kitchen chair, a white button-down laying over it with a fresh grease stain on the sleeve of it.

Jesus.

William met her eyes.

“She said she was making herself breakfast and asked if I wanted anything. I didn’t realize when I said yes how much she hated cooking.”

Agatha felt like a shark caught on the shore, her natural talents useless in the face of William whispering about her ex-wife while said ex-wife dropped pieces of shell into the pan with the eggs.

She pressed her hand into her forehead.

“Just eat the food when she gives it to you.”

William looked more afraid.

“What?! Will she fire me if I don’t?”

Agatha shot him an irritated roll of her eyes.

“No, Fido, it’s just not as bad as it looks.”

William seemed to be taking that in, marinating, then–

“How do you– have you tried it?”

There was a clatter from behind them and Agatha nearly leapt out of her skin, William freezing in the same way. A victorious sound came from Rio, nearly feral, and Agatha’s face pinched at the scrape of metal on metal.

”That’s Teflon dear, please don’t make me eat metal shavings for lunch.”

Agatha was in a nightmare. That was it. She just needed to wake up.

Rio appeared at her right and dropped a plate of scrambled eggs in front of William. She glanced at Agatha.

“Ran out, sorry Agent Harkness.”

William seemed to take that as his opportunity. He started to slide the plate toward Agatha.

“You can have mine.”

Rio and Agatha’s mirrored, sharp ‘no’s’ stilled his hand.

“Oh my god.” He seemed uncertain as he dragged the plate back. “Sorry, thank you Director Vidal.”

Rio smiled in a way that Agatha knew meant she was attempting to scare the kid.

Agatha’s eyes slid low, noted the stretch of fabric on Rio’s chest as she sat down with the stupid apron still on. She looked like a panther with a bow around its neck. Agatha’s next comment came out strained.

“Will you put on your clothes!”

William stared at his plate like he might be able to disappear if he thought about it hard enough.

Rio glanced down at her apron-clad torso and then back to Agatha. Her eyes sparkled smugly and Agatha cleared her throat, her chair screeching as it slid backward.

“I forgot my badge.”

Agatha nearly bolted out of the room. She was molten. It was as if she’d been dragged eleven years in the past and dropped off on the day she’d stayed at Rio’s for the first time.

Agatha blinked, stretched, groaned at the ache in her muscles and between her legs. She was cocooned in a soft, forest green duvet and her bare legs slid against the silky sheets as she shifted.

She looked around Rio’s room, blinking away sleep as she took in the dozens of dried flowers wrapped in wire and hung from the ceiling in no visible pattern. The large window in the room was currently covered by blackout curtains and the only light came from the hallway.

The walls were covered in the footprints of Rio’s life. A patch of what looked like floor tiles ranging from grand and gaudy to plain white, dirty and cracked, took up a portion of the wall by the door. Small animal skulls and skeletons littered the shelves, each wrapped and filled by dried flowers that turned something rather unsettling into something beautiful.

She had vintage prints from Rocky Horror Picture Show, Halloween, The Thing, The Shining, Scream, and several other horror films placed against the off-white walls. There were two bookshelves in the room, though most of the books seemed to be literally anywhere else, sitting open or bookmarked.

It was a strange place, but Agatha felt like she belonged in it, nestled into a pillow that smelled so much like Rio.

She sat up, the sheets falling, and moved to Rio’s set of drawers. She stole a pair of boxers and a threadbare t-shirt before giving the room another once-over.

Rio had only moved in two weeks prior, a slight upgrade from her previous studio, and Agatha wondered how she had already made the apartment feel so lived in.

Neither of them had much time, their fledgling careers as Agents keeping them up at all hours and stealing their weekends. But they’d made a concerted effort to carve out space for each other.

This thing between them was still fresh, it still buzzed in Agatha’s nerves as they danced around one another, learned and discovered parts and pieces. Their histories and hurts were still locked away, both afraid that shining a light on them would ruin what they had found together.

But Agatha could feel it; the dark parts of Rio’s soul lurking, waiting. It was in the way she sometimes looked at Agatha, the fear that sat behind her eyes like Agatha might change her mind, like she might disappear. It was in the way she dedicated herself to her work, the dogged perseverance to be perfect, to complete every single task without flaw. Agatha saw it in the way Rio had laid claim to her new space with so much intention, in the tattoos that ran up her spine, the lack of personal photographs in her apartment.

There was only one displayed, a picture that Agatha couldn’t look at for too long. It was Rio, maybe twelve, with her arm around a boy a little older. He had dark skin and a crooked smile, his hand was on her head, scrunching up her hair playfully. Rio was making a face mixed between a smile and a grimace as she looked up toward the boy. Rio’s hair was cut jagged to her shoulders, the boy’s hair was buzzed. Both had on ratty-looking clothes and small patches of blues and blacks littered their skin.

The photo itself was bent and wrinkled like it had been kept loose for years before being framed. Every time Agatha looked at it her heart broke. It felt haunted. She wasn’t sure why, nor did she have any intention to ask. Not yet.

Agatha padded out of Rio’s room toward the smells and sounds of food being made. She smiled as she came into view.

”Are you cooking me breakfast?”

Rio turned. She had on Agatha’s unbuttoned, white dress shirt with a black apron over it that hung lower than the shirt, the bottom touching Rio’s knees. There was a cartoon grim reaper on the pocket and a dirty spatula tucked inside. She stared as Agatha approached, her gaze lilting toward hunger.

“Yes. I’m an excellent cook.”

Agatha looked to the messy pan, brows raising, head nodding slowly.

“Right. Yeah.” She moved closer, tilted her head. “And you’re cooking– what is that?”

Rio looked affronted, motioning toward the pan.

“It’s breakfast.”

Agatha stepped up next to her and peered down at the concoction in the pan.

“Okay. Sure. What kind of breakfast?”

Rio crossed her arms, eyes narrowing sharply as she turned to Agatha. She took her spatula out of her pocket and, for very obvious reasons, Agatha felt like it was now being wielded as a weapon. Rio brandished it.

“What do you mean?”

Agatha shook her head, hands out as she backed away slowly, amusement dancing on her lips.

“No, you’re right. It’s breakfast. I love breakfast.”

Rio stalked toward her and pieces of yellow-white dripped off of the spatula onto the floor. Rio promptly walked through it with her socked feet. She pointed the spatula at Agatha’s chest.

“Do you have something to say, Harkness?”

Agatha reached the table’s edge, her legs bumping against it. She saw Rio’s eyes trail over her and darken.

Agatha shook her head, then reconsidered.

“Well, you have…egg?” she added a questioning inflection on the word, “on your sock.”

Rio’s threatening countenance faltered, her brow furrowing as she lifted her foot to look. A slight pout turned her expression.

Agatha adored her.

Rio took off her sock, leaving the other on. She sheathed her spatula and gave Agatha a look.

“You got lucky this time.”

She turned back to the stove.

Agatha learned four things that morning. One, Rio’s was an actual nightmare in the kitchen but the flavors were surprisingly pleasant. Two, Rio was very sensitive about her cooking abilities and would possibly cause bodily harm if questioned. Three, being fucked over a kitchen table with one of her hands half resting in leftover scrambled eggs was so much better than Agatha could have conceptualized. Four, Rio’s ability to be both alarmingly hot and so goddamned strange made Agatha nearly feral.

Agatha returned to her room and beelined for her bathroom to splash water on her heated face. She mindlessly completed the tasks she’d decided to skip upon waking up in a panic and fought to scrape at the gooey, warm feelings in her body until she was left with muscle and bone and the cavernous hole she’d made her home in.

She waited until the last possible moment to return downstairs and trail a redressed Rio and a still-confused William outside.

——

As they walked toward the ROC entrance, Rio ahead of them by several steps, William moved closer to Agatha.

“Was that weird, or…?”

Agatha shook her head.

“No, she’s normally a freak.”

William looked with concern toward Rio.

“Should you say that about the SAC?”

Agatha rolled her eyes.

“What? You plan on tattling?”

William shook his head vehemently.

“No! Just— what if she hears us?”

Agatha shrugged and glared daggers into Rio’s spine.

“I hope she does.”

They made their way to the command center to find the Chief already there, her eyes passing over dozens of screens that had been brought in and set up for easier viewing.

The Chief of Police smiled at Rio.

“Director, welcome. Nothing of interest yet. The teams are doing well; getting along.”

Agatha mentally noted that she nor the intern had been greeted. She watched Rio sit directly beside the Chief and made a choice to find a spot several chairs away.

William followed her.

She looked around the space and her original confusion from the morning returned. She frowned at William.

“Why did they move our go-time back?”

William shrugged as he started spinning slowly in his chair.

“Director Vidal and Agent Maximoff had a conversation this morning and the Director sent them off without us.”

Of course she did.

Agatha dropped her head back against the chair and looked toward the screens depicting the locations of interest. The dock and sports facility were relatively close with audio and visuals coming in. The team at Veridi’s home had a single visual from quite far away. She sighed.

“This is going to be egregiously boring, William. Buckle up.”

“They said we could help with logistics.”

Agatha let out a dry laugh.

“Logistics.” She closed her eyes. “We are the team watching the people that are watching buildings.” William made an awkward coughing noise as she continued. “It’s a fucking snooze-fest. I’d personally rather choke on rocks, but at least we have air conditioning.”

Chief Koutsou cleared her throat far closer than she’d been moments prior.

When Agatha’s eyes pried open, she peered up into her stern face and smiled her fakest smile.

“Depending on when you walked over, I was talking about joining William for his weekly improv classes.”

Koutsou huffed.

“I imagine you are very good at your job to still have one with this being your general disposition.”

Agatha ignored the prod.

“What can I do for you, Chief?”

Chief Koutsou tossed several folders on the table in front of them.

“Your Director said I could utilize you during down time to look at a few cases for the HPD.” She nodded toward William. “It’ll be good for the intern.”

Agatha feigned offense, leaning slightly back to locate Rio.

“He has a name.”

William stood and held out his hand.

“William Kaplan. I actually looked into your history, Chief. Well— what I had access to. You have had an incredible career.”

Koutsou seemed surprised, mildly pleased.

“Thank you, Mr. Kaplan.” She tapped the files. “Let me know if you have any questions.”

As she walked away, Agatha could see Rio returning with two cups of coffee in hand. She sat back down beside the Chief and slid one over.

Something dark and spiky reared its head in Agatha’s chest and she quickly yanked open the first file.

_____________

By the time three PM rolled around, Agatha had raided the break room and brought back a deck of cards, a chess set with a missing piece, and a box of donuts that had been brought in for the IT team.

She stuffed one in her mouth to drown out the grumble in her stomach as William stared at the chess board in front of him.

He pointed at the bullet she’d set on her side to replace the missing pawn.

“Shouldn’t we use something other than live ammunition?”

Agatha groaned.

“Just play. You’re lucky I’m letting you start with white.”

William pushed the Queen’s pawn.

“You had me pick a hand.”

Agatha grunted and played to d5. She smirked when he moved his Bishop out.

“The London is a solid opening.”

William looked up with his eyes narrowed in suspicion.

“It is.”

Agatha moved her Knight to f6, brow raised.

“That’s what I just said.”

He continued the main line, playing knight to f3. Agatha smiled and immediately attacked his intended structure.

____________

Forty minutes later, William was staring at the board with his head in his hands, his eyes looking forlornly at the f2 square where his single pawn was protected only by the King. Both Agatha’s dark-squared Bishop and her Queen were lined up in a battery heading for the weak pawn, and the f file was wide open for her Rook to claim. He frowned at her.

“Don’t look so smug.”

Agatha feigned offense.

“I always look like this.”

He looked toward the doors where Koutsou and Rio had disappeared two hours prior.

“Do you know where they went?”

She did not. The monster that had coiled in her chest was alive and hungry now. Her mild respect for the Chief had soured incredibly.

“No. Stop wasting time.”

William groaned and reached forward, knocking over his King.

“I’m not winning this.”

Agatha blew out a breath, her lips pulling down.

“Coward.”

He laughed, already gathering his pieces and resetting them on the board.

“You are way better than me. I just learned how to play to impress my boyfriend’s grandmother.”

Agatha reset the black pieces and slid the board away, leaving the bullet in as a pawn.

“Don’t beat yourself up, I’m better than most people.”

William grabbed the deck of cards and began to shuffle, a cocky grin appearing.

“Fine. We’ll see how you fare in a real game.”

___________

They’d only played through the first hand of something called ‘Golf’ when Rio and the Chief returned, pushing through the door with two large paper bags. Agatha didn’t look up, only continued to play through her turn of the silly game based purely on luck.

Koutsou walked over and set one of the bags on the table beside Agatha, the jolt knocking over two of the chess pieces and her bullet.

“Your diligence is astounding, Agent Harkness.”

Agatha frowned, eyes falling to the files.

“Oh? Were these meant to be completed in a timely fashion?”

Rio spoiled her fun before Koutsou could rebuke her.

“Don’t waste your breath. She’s completed them already.”

Koutsou frowned and sifted through the cases, brows pinched. She picked up one and glanced at Agatha.

“All of them?”

Agatha shrugged, already reaching for the paper bag that smelled like french fries and grease-covered meat.

“I get that you couldn’t give us any sensitive cases due to your clamorous mistrust, but gas station robbery? Hit and run? Shoplifting? Vandalism?” Agatha smiled. “If you wanted to waste our time, leaving us to monitor the teams on surveillance was enough.”

Koutsou picked up the multiple folders and sifted through them. She turned the last over.

“The homicide?”

Agatha had already found the fries and set them in front of herself.

“I mean, I can’t make arrests from here, nor do I have any kind of access to the witnesses or suspects, but I’d bet these fries it was the man on camera shooting the gun.” Agatha stuffed her mouth, a bitter glee flooding her as she saw the agitation roll over the Chief’s face. She’d been a hard nut to crack but Agatha was persistent. “Did you not look at the files before handing them over?”

The Chief’s jaw tensed for a moment before releasing.

“I did not.” Her next words seemed to come out with more reluctance. “Thank you.”

Agatha withdrew several cardboard containers and set them down in front of herself and William. She lifted a group of fries up in salute and then stuffed them in her mouth.

“And thank you!”

When the Chief moved back, Agatha let the heady pride of victory rear its head. For the next few minutes, she could let her shredded emotions sink below the surface.

For the next few minutes, she could breathe.

Chapter End Notes

This was written on my phone at work the past two days and it isn’t edited lol.

Chapter 12

Chapter Notes

Sorry for the long wait. I'd half-convinced myself that this story was ass and that I was a gremlin who didn't know how to write. My gf was not happy and said that, while I WAS a gremlin, it was not because I was a bad writer. Got a little writer's block for a moment but struck back with this hefty chapter. (Edit: I don’t plan to stop writing this fic! I just had a little slump)

ALSO, I got a bit wind back in my sails today when I saw my story linked on a Twitter thread; thanks to whomever did that.

See the end of the chapter for more notes

The ease of pressure, of tension, lasted until Chief Koutsou excused herself to handle an emergency in another department. She’d said that her interim would arrive around seven to relieve them and had clearly only been speaking to Rio.

Agatha felt a mix of relief and irritation at her departure, but she let herself veer hard into the latter. She had another forty-seven minutes of sitting in this room, staring at screens, and avoiding Rio’s general location, before she could bury herself beneath her pillow for a solid four to six hours of sleep.

Even optimistic William was struggling to maintain his energy, his body slumped in his chair. He glanced at Agatha, his voice weary.

“I can’t believe there’s nothing else we could be doing.”

Agatha shot him a look of warning but it was too late. Rio turned to look from her position right in front of the multiple screens. She looked far too pleased.

“There’s mountains of paperwork if you’re feeling bored.”

William looked to Agatha for help but she held out her hands.

“One must learn by digging their own graves, kid.”

William grimaced and stood, looking around the space for said paperwork.

Rio tilted her head to the hall.

“My office. It’s stacked on the left corner of the desk. You can bring them back here.”

William resigned himself and Agatha’s eyes trailed after him as he left the room.

The hairs on the back of her neck stood on end the moment he was out of sight. She stared at the game of solitaire in front of her and ignored the sound of Rio rising from her chair.

Agatha didn’t look up even as Rio flipped a free chair and sat directly across from her, their knees bumping under the table. Agatha’s fingers tightened on the cards in her hands and she placed one down stiffly.

Rio’s elbows settled on the table, her chin dropping onto her hands.

“You’ve been quieter today.”

Agatha was under no illusion that Rio’s curious tone would lead to anything beyond a ploy to tip the scales in her favor. She placed another card on the table and refreshed her hand.

“I hadn’t noticed.”

There was a finite amount of time before William returned and Agatha was determined not to give an inch.

Rio clearly had other plans. She slid her knee between Agatha’s and parted them, a low hum in her throat as they went easily.

“Still so responsive.”

Agatha froze. She knew her breath would come out shaky so she held it as Rio let her knee rest on the inside of her own. Her body was tense, every part of her awareness suddenly laser-focused on the woman in front of her. She saw the arrogant curve to Rio’s brow, the expectation there, the intensity of her gaze.

“You’re playing a very reckless game, Director Vidal.”

Agatha could hear the hazy edge in her own voice and she watched Rio’s eyes flicker to her lips.

Rio’s gaze didn’t waver as she spoke.

“Have you thought about it, Agatha?”

Her voice curled around the syllables of her name like she was tasting the shape of it.

Agatha ground her teeth shut and blindly discarded the trio in her hand before moving to pick up more.

“Not once.”

Rio chuckled, the sound of it tapping into Agatha’s veins.

Agatha wasn’t sure what drove the next words but she tried to claw them back as they escaped her lips.

“Why don’t you take the Chief for a spin? I bet she’d let you choke her.”

Rio’s eyes widened in surprise, her smile growing. William entered the room as Rio stood, voice low in her response.

“She wouldn’t like it nearly as much as you.”

Rio returned to her chair and William dropped next to Agatha. He looked like a kicked puppy, a stark splash of water to Agatha’s current psyche. She frowned deeply and continued to play her game.

Rio glanced back at William.

“Expense Reports, Preliminary Summaries, Public Records. The rest are above your clearance.” Rio motioned toward Agatha. “She can help you if you have any questions.”

Agatha grimaced, shooting a deadly glare toward William.

He looked at his files with wide eyes and slowly separated the ones he could work on. He opened the first and stared at it blankly for almost two minutes.

Agatha groaned loudly and yanked the first stack on top of her card game. She was going to lose anyway. With a very complex combination of feelings churning in her gut, she set to work filling out the documents as poorly as possible. Just enough that Rio would have to waste a decent amount of time making corrections.

________________

 

At the end of day three of their surveillance, Agatha was prepared to get arrested if it meant the case would stop dragging on. Things at the ROC were tenuous at best, both Agatha and Rio having fallen into a brittle stalemate.

They’d gotten a few false alarms. One at the sport’s facility with a group of kids breaking in to vandalize and drink themselves into a stupor. Alice and Ioannidis had sat back to watch, their next several hours filled with the drunk commentary of fifteen year old kids.

The second was at the docks. A member of Veridi’s extended family had taken a joy-ride on the small, dingy fishing vessel that had been sitting at the dock. Kale and Zervas had also refrained from intervening.

Agatha was sitting in her same chair, William beside her as she stared at the grainy image of Veridi’s home.

William had completed the paperwork under Agatha’s sharp corrections and had definitely learned his lesson on keeping his mouth shut. Boredom was to be complained about when no consequences could follow.

Now they would wait for the catalyst; either Veridi would make a mistake or Koutsou would hurry the fuck up on getting their warrants.

Agatha’s eyes flicked to the multiple angles of the small dock. She narrowed her eyes as a car drove by on the long, two-lane road that ran past the dock. Agatha stood and walked toward the screens. She took the remote from where it lay in front of Koutsou and ignored the questions it prompted.

She began to rewind, searching…. There. She paused on the same car that had passed by minutes before.

“We might have action at the docks.”

Before Rio or the Chief could respond, Jennifer called in.

”There’s a gray Volkswagen Polo that has made a second pass at our location. License FFT 6794.”

Agatha rolled her eyes.

“You don’t say. Do you have eyes on them?”

”Agatha, how’s timeout? I was radioing in to speak to an adult.”

Agatha pressed two of the comm links together to create ear-piercing feedback through the connection.

Several shouts sounded from the three teams and Rio reached forward to yank the comm out of Agatha’s hand. She shot Agatha a tired look before speaking to Kale.

“This is Vidal. Do you have eyes on the vehicle?”

The Chief was already searching for the license, her fingers flying across her keyboard.

There was a sound of a door opening and then Kale came through.

”I’m moving to a closer vantage point, The Captain is staying put. It looks like it turned toward that neighboring house.”

The Chief frowned.

“They do not have a Volkswagen registered to their names.” She tapped her fingers impatiently as a file loaded. “Got it. This license plate was reported stolen four hours ago. It belonged to a Hyundai i10 registered to a family in Athens.” She stood and immediately radioed her next orders. “Support Team, be prepared to close in on the docks.”

Agatha felt the first dredges of adrenaline churn in her chest and she began to follow.

The Chief turned, eyes sharp, and paused. She looked Agatha over and drew in a breath.

“If you make me regret taking you along, I’ll find a way to make your life hell.”

Agatha gave her a bright smile.

“You’re going to have to do better than that, Chief. I’ve been in hell for a long time.”

______________

 

The ride to the docks took almost thirty-five minutes and Agatha’s skin was itching. She was trapped in a car alone with Rio and Koutsou, her only moments of respite coming from conversation amongst the surveillance teams.

She had purposefully sat behind Rio to avoid any unwanted eye contact; the additional perk came from her ability to press her foot into the back of the seat to cause her mild discomfort and annoyance.

Jen called in.

”No movement at the docks.

Jen had been told to hold off on approaching the vacation home until a larger team could get into position.

Agatha shifted, feeling the reassuring weight of the P99 sitting against her hip. She frowned as Alice spoke over the comms.

”We have movement here. South entrance of the facility.”

Wanda’s voice followed after.

”Possible activity on Veridi’s property.”

Agatha’s mind began to parse through the information they’d gathered on Veridi and his overplanning.

Koutsou ordered the Constables on route to split toward the other two locations.

Agatha leaned forward to look at the Chief.

“It’s the docks.”

To her credit, there was only mild skepticism in Koutsou’s tone as she responded.

“Why do you say that?”

Rio answered for her.

“Veridi’s web of bribes was overkill. He paid more money more frequently than he needed to. Sure, it kept him clean if nobody was looking, but that map is easy to follow once you have the scent.” Rio shrugged. “Agent Harkness is making the assumption that he’s overdoing it again.”

Agatha pressed her foot harder into Rio’s seat.

“I’m right. People with that kind of need for absolute control can’t just change their approach. Veridi is splitting our attention but the dock is his only avenue of escape that isn’t heavily regulated.”

The Chief held her radio to her mouth, debating the merit, before radioing the change in command.

“Support Team, stay in-route to the docks. Split pairs out to locations two and three.”

Agatha didn’t bother to hide her smug expression as she settled into her seat.

The Chief rolled their vehicle to a stop half a mile from where Jen and Captain Ioannidis were bunkered down. Two vehicles of Constables had already arrived and they had unloaded, strapped on vests, and armed themselves with MP5s. They all turned to their Chief as she stepped out of the vehicle.

Within three minutes, Koutsou had split the constables into two teams. She took half toward the vacation home and sent Agatha and Rio toward the docks with sharp commands and a word of warning.

“Director Vidal, I expect there will be no surprises. The Captain will converge with you.”

She looked to Agatha.

Rio intervened.

“Agent Harkness knows how to follow orders, Chief. Let’s move.”

The words splashed acidic inside Agatha’s chest and she turned toward the Constables at her back. They looked severe, agitated, and many of them had their eyes on her like she might be the criminal. That didn’t bode well.

A hand gripped her arm and she instinctively pulled to no avail.

Rio– no– Director Vidal was looking at her. No games, no power plays. She held Agatha’s gaze without waver and her voice was quiet, demanding. It was so similar to the one that picked Agatha apart but the traces of affection had vanished.

“Behave like you want to keep your job, Agatha.” Agatha rolled her eyes, stomach clenching. Rio’s grip tightened, her eyes narrowed. She looked every inch of the leader she had become, the lines of her face razor-sharp. “No. Don’t fuck around. Don’t listen to your pride, listen to me. You do what I say. If I’m not there, you do what the Captain says. Do you understand me?”

Agatha’s blood, already pumping from adrenaline, seared through her. Rio like this was…. She couldn’t find words fast enough.

Rio’s hand became a vice on her arm, the pressure turning to pain as she stepped closer.

“Agent Harkness. Do. You. Understand. Yes or no?”

Agatha’s lips parted, her heartbeat out of control. She couldn’t look away.

“Yes.”

It came out much smoother than Agatha expected, only a trace amount of something unprofessional curling through the breath she took after.

Rio let her go and turned, waiting for the Chief’s word to move in.

Agatha stood beside her, her arm throbbing in time with her chest. She blinked, cleared her throat, and settled in place at Rio’s back.

__________

The order was given ten minutes later and Rio led the team toward the docks, their steps hugging closely to the tree line separating them from the water.

Agatha was already sweating, her hairline damp in the mild humidity. The eight constables at her back were surprisingly quiet with their steps as they trailed her.

Rio slowed them as they came in sight of the docks, the three prongs of it shooting out into the water. The trees came to an abrupt stop and left a gap of about forty feet with little to no cover. At the other end of the gap was the fence that surrounded the property; it was filled with storage containers, pieces of old, rusted boats, fuel tanks, and various scrap materials.

Rio called in.

“Kale, what’s your position?”

”We’re at a gap in the fence north of the enclosed dock. No movement sighted.”

Rio motioned.

“Alright, we’re moving. Run low and stay quiet.”

She took off with Agatha at her heels, the Constables close behind. They moved into the unprotected space on high alert, eyes searching the gaps and slits in the fence for any threat. They made it about halfway before Agatha felt the hairs on her neck stand on end. She looked toward the road, toward the dockyard, then her gaze veered sharply toward the water just in time to notice movement and a fresh ripple spreading across the surface.

She matched pace with Rio.

“The water. Somebody’s in the water.”

Rio didn’t ask a single confirming question before calling it in.

“Alert. Movement in water. Could be more trouble than expected ahead. Captain, Kale, be careful.”

The Chief’s voice rang in, her tone elevated.

”Vacation house is clear, but there was recent activity. Multiple persons were living here. Ammunition and SCUBA gear have been left behind. We’re heading toward you. Watch your sixes.”

Rio slowed them at the fence, crouching low, listening.

The sound of water lapping against the shore, birds, heavy breaths, boats nudging against bumpers… the scrape of boots in the dirt just beyond the fence.

“Get down!”

The ten of them dropped in unison as gunfire erupted from inside, pelting into the fence, the dirt, ripping through reeds of grass.

Two constables tossed flashbangs over the fence, the concussive blasts silencing the spray of bullets as twin groans sounded from inside.

As a Constable began to climb, Agatha yanked him back down.

“You think they’re the only ones with guns?”

He looked at her like he hadn’t even considered it and Agatha saw how fresh he was, the face of a rookie who was certain the rules of life and death were different for people trying to protect and serve.

Rio motioned to a partial break in the fence and hissed a command.

“Provide cover fire, cut this open.”

Agatha aimed her gun inside with six other constables but didn’t shoot alongside their sprays. She had very limited bullets and she planned to make them count.

Two constables went to work on the fence, clipping rapidly until the hole was large enough to move through.

Rio patted her shoulder.

“Five in, five cover.”

Agatha moved in second-to-last under the protection of bullets slamming into the massive container fifteen feet away. A yelp caught her attention and she turned to find the rookie caught up in the fence.

“Oh for fucks—“

She cut herself off as she shoved her arm around him and yanked him to the ground just as enemy fire screamed around them. Agatha felt a dull burn in her arm as she dragged at the constable. He scampered toward cover with the other three tucked against a rust-red boat hull.

A constable tossed another flashbang as two opened fire. The earthshaking bang and echo was louder this time, jarring, and Agatha saw the rookie press in a panic against the metal hull, his eyes bugged wide.

She looked to make sure Rio and the others were moving in safely before gripping him by the collar and slamming him rather handily into the hull. He looked like a wild animal.

She got close to his face, breathing hard, ears ringing.

“You trained for this. You are better than this. Toughen the fuck up or stay put. You’ll feel so much worse if you get somebody killed.”

He blinked hard several times as the others fell in. Agatha didn’t let go. She didn’t break eye contact. She stared him down until his panic began to shift and turn toward embarrassment.

She slapped him.

“Don’t find another crisis. You’re already in one.”

He nodded sharply as Kale called in.

”We’re pinned in the warehouse. At least seven armed. They’re loading up a high-speed vessel. I think I see Veridi.”

Rio grimaced, eyes searching the yard around them for the clearest path.

“Don’t do anything stupid, Kale. Wait for us.”

The response was strained but huffy, littered with gunfire.

”Please. I’m not Harkness.”

Agatha nearly laughed as she released the rookie and patted his red cheek.

“Buck up, rook. You know what to do.”

A hand gripped her other wrist and lifted. Rio’s face was covered in a film of dirt, her expression severe.

“You’re bleeding.”

Agatha glanced down at the line of a rather irritating cut along her forearm. She rolled her neck.

“Fence. It’s fine.”

Rio nodded and turned toward the shipping container as bullets sprayed their cover.

“Wait until they reload. Four cover, five on me.”

The ten-second wait felt like it took hours. Agatha’s entire body was tensed for movement. At the first beat of silence, four Constables leaned out and offered cover as Rio led the charge forward.

Agatha locked in, her mind elevating, her instincts sharp. The pair of them moved together like they were in a predestined dance, Rio swinging around, firing twice, Agatha covering her back, taking out a black-suited individual as he appeared further into the yard.

It was the muscle-memory, the knowing, and Agatha’s body was more alive than it had been in years.

They crouched into cover again and Agatha saw several figures ahead, adjusting to cut them off from the enclosed dock. She grit her teeth. It would take ages moving like this.

Jen’s voice came through again, this time sharp and raised.

”Officer down! The Captain has a gunshot wound to the leg. They’re moving in on our location.”

The Chief called through.

”Thirty seconds out of the North gate!”

Jen spoke tersely through the line.

”They closed in behind us. You’ll have resistance. I moved him as far as I can but we’re sitting ducks in here.”

Agatha looked around them, sound muffling as orders were called and gunfire echoed and ricocheted in her ears. She saw a ladder leading up the back of the closest shipping container and peered around the corner. There was an entire row of them that led almost directly up to the old, greenish window of the enclosed dock.

Agatha took a step and stilled. She growled out in irritation and turned to Rio, tilting her head toward the ladder.

“I’m going up.”

Rio put the pieces together quickly.

“No.”

Agatha nearly snarled at her, her fingers curling into Rio’s vest.

“Kale is pinned and Veridi is escaping. Keep their attention on the ground and I can do something about it. I’ll stay low, lay some cover.”

Rio’s jaw snapped shut, her eyes searching Agatha’s. She took a breath, nodded.

“Go.”

Agatha did. She passed the rookie and motioned toward his belt.

“Mind if I borrow those?”

He passed over a pair of flashbangs without question and Agatha sprinted for the ladder. She climbed up toward the top and slowed, eyes looking for Rio, waiting for her command.

Rio glanced up at her and her face transformed for a moment, a pulse of fear in her eyes before she seemed to tamper it. She spoke quickly to the gathered Constables. They moved quickly. Two fired out, four ran across to take up cover on the other side, and Rio’s eyes fell back to Agatha.

She motioned the go-ahead and Agatha flung herself up, rolling into a crouch on the container. She didn’t stop to reconsider or question herself as she leapt to the next, ran, jumped again. Her feet hit metal, the echo of it enough to draw attention by the time she’d made it halfway down the line.

Agatha picked up her pace as bullets chased her steps, one splintering on metal and sending shrapnel into her calf. She groaned and kept running.

As she neared the last container, she realized the distance to the window was further than expected, likely about twelve feet across. She could hardly see inside, the panes crusted with salt and dirt, but she thought she could make out the shape of a railing.

Agatha’s gaze flicked down at the masked figures as she passed them, and noted a group of three blocking the entrance, their eyes already turned up toward her.

She steeled herself. Rio was going to be so fucking mad.

Agatha kept her pace, her arms pumping, her legs working overtime as she reached the edge of the shipping container and launched herself toward the window.

Shouts sounded from all around her as her arms crossed in front of her face, her eyes closing tightly shut. The panes shattered inward, their edges cutting into Agatha’s bared skin as she flew through them.

Dread flooded her body as she became weightless, began to fall, fall— she slammed ribs first into a metal railing.

Every bit of air compressed from her lungs as the metal shrieked from her momentum. She opened her eyes through the sting of sweat and blood in time to see multiple masked figures recovering from the explosion of glass.

She was on a catwalk that surrounded the small warehouse and just twenty feet away, she could see the boat Jen had mentioned and the man standing at the wheel that was undoubtedly Veridi. It was already moving forward toward the open gate, four figures in the back.

Agatha ripped the pins from both flashbangs as her vision blurred from lack of oxygen.

She grinned manically and tossed them both, a perfect arcing line, right into the boat.

The suited individuals and Veridi all dove away just as the concussive blast ripped through the warehouse.

Agatha’s smile fell as the metal railing gave way, her body lurching over and falling toward the cement below.

It wasn’t a far fall, the impact relatively mild to what it could have been, but Agatha still hadn’t caught her breath and her back landed on something ridged and sharp. She lost consciousness for a dizzying moment, her skin tingling, everything else numb as she blinked.

She heard so much noise, none of it making sense as she coughed and gasped desperately for air. She rolled over onto her elbow and looked toward the boat.

She could vaguely make out the blaze of flames and the bodies scrambling around, eyes watering, hands to their ears. Two fell in the water from the boat, three had jumped onto the dock. One stumbled back and fell, hitting his head sharply on the boat’s hull as it floated unmanned toward the exit.

Agatha looked around for her gun and saw it several feet away buried under debris. She pulled in lungfuls of stale, fishy air and began to drag herself toward it. Her earpiece was still alive with a cacophony of voices but she couldn’t make sense of the words. Her hand wrapped around the grip of her weapon and she used every bit of her strength to force herself to her feet. She stumbled and leaned heavily on the closest wall as the capable enemies regained their bearings.

Agatha fired twice, her ears still ringing, and drew back as they returned fire. Everything throbbed with a dull sort of pain that kept her alert and standing as she tried to sift through the ringing to make sense the chatter.

”—on’t have eyes on Harkness but they’re pursuing something across the warehouse. Veridi is down. I’m counting five hostiles still on the move, two in pursuit.”

The Chief called in.

”We’ve cleared the path. On our way to you, Agent Kale.”

Rio’s voice followed.

”The last three are retreating into the warehouse. I want eyes on Harkness, now!”

Agatha glanced toward the double doors beneath a still-hanging section of the catwalk. It swayed precariously as the doors flew open and Agatha refocused her weapon on the remaining joint keeping the catwalk afloat.

She emptied her magazine even after the bullets hit their mark and forced a structural collapse. Her finger squeezed repeatedly on empty as the three targets were knocked to the ground. Rio stepped back a proper distance, her dark brown eyes nearly black with fury and something obsidian, something molten.

Agatha sat fully patched up on the edge of a hospital bed. She had bandages on her arms and was told in no uncertain terms that she was incredibly lucky that her injuries weren’t worse. She’d gotten stitches in her back and the area was still numb even though she’d been waiting here for nearly two hours.

Her clothes were horribly uncomfortable as she sat in her dried sweat and blood but she’d refused to put on a gown. Doctors had offered her painkillers and she’d accepted happily.

She was nearly to the point of calling a taxi when Jen, of all people, stepped into the room.

“Harkness.”

Agatha looked past her and offered a bemused frown.

“Kale. You draw the short straw?”

Jen rolled her eyes as she ushered Agatha from the room.

“You should be grateful, the others wanted you to stay for observation. Consider it my thanks for buying me some time to not get shot in the face.”

Agatha grumbled after her.

“If I’d known I was saving your life I wouldn’t have bothered.”

Jen led them to the elevator and pressed the button impatiently, not deigning Agatha with a response. The ride down and the walk to the exit were silent. Agatha found it irritating.

She’d had far too much time to think already. Once the nurses had left her she had let herself live through her actions again. The screech of adrenaline in her veins, the sound of the glass shattering around her, the impact of the metal bar through the thick Kevlar. The sensations were fresh, the taste of the air in the warehouse easy to recall. Her inability to breathe, Rio looking for her. Rio’s relief. Her hands. The harsh touches. Her anger.

Agatha bit the inside of her cheek to stop the path her mind veered down. She focused on the stinging hurt in her back and arms as they walked out of the building.

She rounded the vehicle, let herself inside, and shot Jen a look.

“Bitter gratitude is a good look for you, Kale.”

Jen mimicked her tone.

“And suffocation fits you well.”

“I’m surprised you could see my heroic effort from where you were cowered with the Captain.”

“Oh, it was more than seen. There were cameras all over that building. Not to mention the body cam footage.” Jen smirked. “You should see your face when you hit that railing; you looked like a pug.”

“That was my first time working with Vidal. She’s intense about her people.” Jen shrugged. “I guess that’s what you want from your boss though.”

“How do you mean?”

“She was about to smash heads together. You weren’t responding, classic attention-seeker that you are, and she got real snappy.”

“Yeah, sounds about right.”

They remained quiet for the remainder of the ride and Agatha opened her door before the vehicle rolled to a stop at the ROC.

_______

As soon as Agatha stepped into the command center, two dozen eyes fell to her. The gathered Constables and the small team they’d been working with directly, her own team at the back. Everyone was covered in a thin film of dirt. Some sported bruises and cuts, others looked relatively unharmed.

The Chief was front and center, clearly finishing her debrief.

“Agent Harkness. Woman of the hour. I have a mountain of paperwork for the stun grenades you borrowed from my Constable.”

Agatha winced, holding her hand out limply.

“I’m sorry, Chief, I think my hand was broken in the fall.”

A round of chuckles sounded from the room and Agatha tried not to stand taller. This was a far cry from the general attitude toward her just hours before.

The Chief nodded toward the back where her team was gathered.

“Dictation is an option. Please have a seat. We’ll finish here soon.”

Agatha walked toward her team, all of them watching her approach with varying expressions. Lilia’s was curious, Alice’s was impressed, Wanda’s was concerned. Agatha focused on William, ignoring Rio beside him.

She sat on his other side.

He immediately leaned over, whispering emphatically.

“That was totally nuts.”

Agatha looked toward the computer in front of him.

“You have the footage?”

William nodded, turning it toward her to reveal multiple angles of her suicidal jump through single pane glass. It played out far quicker than it had felt in the moment, her body hitting the metal, her wide, pained expression, her hand unclipping the flashbangs from her belt and flinging them across the open space.

The camera warbled and gray dots covered the screens as the expulsion knocked into them. Only two of five remained in position after the video returned, the other three aiming directly at the floor. The only camera that remained on her slumped form was darkened, the picture corrupted.

It continued to play as William leaned toward her.

“Are you okay?”

She waved him off, the cuts on her arms tugging painfully.

“Peachy.”

The briefing continued. Agatha learned that the other teams had moved in on the sport’s facility and Veridi’s private home. Georgina had been found locked away in the subfloor of the barn. She was hospitalized but word had already come through that she would be completely okay; at least in the physical sense. It seemed that Veridi’s people had discovered who she was a few days after the abduction. She’d been brought and kept at his private home in hopes that the search would dissipate and a ransom could be requested.

She was malnourished and sleep deprived but otherwise unharmed. Agatha breathed a sigh of relief and looked toward William.

The videos on the screen were still running, the busy dock packed with activity, but his eyes were narrowed in on the darkened edge of a particular one. Agatha’s heart lurched in her throat as she saw how closely Rio was standing to her, the intimacy of the position made worse by the fact that it was not obvious that she was being checked for injuries.

William leaned in closer, head tilted, brows drawn, when Rio’s hand reached over and closed the computer screen with a snap.

William’s cheeks reddened a dark shade, his eyes very carefully locked onto the surface of desk in front of him. Agatha didn’t look at Rio, Rio didn’t look at Agatha, and William barely moved for the remainder of the post-op brief.

__________

The team arrived back at the consulate house two hours later. The long days leading up to such an explosive conclusion had drained them. As they walked in, Lilia pointed to the kitchen, looking specifically at Agatha.

“Wine.”

Agatha thought of her empty room waiting for her, about the unsettled energy still coursing under her skin, and easily followed into the kitchen.

In the flurry of opening cabinets for glasses and wine, Wanda pulled Agatha aside with a soft touch at her wrist.

“Are you alright, Agatha?”

Agatha was fine. Truly. It had been the most excitement she’d experienced in ages. A few bumps and bruises were part of the job. But her mind… it replayed the damaged footage over and over in her head. It drew to the forefront the weight of Rio’s hands on her, the look in her eyes as her stony facade began to crumble from her fury, the threat that sat behind it. She accepted a glass from Lilia as it was pressed into her hand, raising her brows at Wanda and offering a thumbs up.

Wanda frowned, searching her expression until she was gifted her own glass. Even William had a glass shoved into his grasp and Lilia held up a hand before Wanda could speak.

“It’s Europe, Maximoff. Let the kid live a little.”

Agatha bit back her amusement as William took the glass easily, like he’d held one every weekend for years. Bookclub, probably. Or puzzle nights with his boyfriend.

Lilia held up her glass toward Agatha.

“To this bat-shit crazy bitch. And to finally going home.”

The team pressed their glasses together and drank.

Alice tapped her fingers against her glass.

“On the scale of things I’ve seen in this job, jumping at full speed through a window is up there with some of the most reckless.”

Agatha feigned a haughty bow, warmth spreading in her chest at the good-humored cheers.

“At your service.”

She looked up just in time to see Rio leave the room.

Jen glanced behind, brows raised, before she took Rio’s untouched glass from the counter and finished it herself.

“Don’t mind if I do.”

The others moved on quickly, only Wanda looking after Rio’s departure.

And William. He stared with a ponderous frown at the empty archway, then his eyes fell back to Agatha. To the arch. To Agatha. They widened.

Agatha reached over and lifted the bottom of his glass, nearly splashing his wine into his face.

“Drink up, intern. Once we’re in international airspace, Maximoff’s rules reapply.”

Her feet were kicked up and crossed on the coffee table, the black soles of her shoes aimed toward Agatha. She’d cleaned her face, a butterfly bandage placed on her temple where an angry bruise sat.

Another beer sat untouched on a coaster in front of the couch, droplets slipping down, pooling on the ceramic.

Rio’s hand on her mouth stayed in place and she pressed close as the footsteps made their way back toward the stairs.

Agatha trembled despite her attempts to regain her composure. She squeezed her legs together, the disappointment like a weight in her chest.

The footsteps echoed up the steps and as soon as they heard the thunk of a door closing, Rio stepped back. The hand on Agatha’s mouth slid up, pushed her damp bangs from her face.

Rio’s eyes burned with irritation and desire and a well-stroked ego.

“You just couldn’t be patient and take what I gave you.”

Agatha closed her eyes, fought the urge to lean into the palm on her cheek. She was utterly ruined, wrecked. She wanted to cry at the pit in her stomach, the broken-off release.

“Rio.”

Rio’s hand on her cheek slid down to grasp Agatha’s jaw. She pressed her lips against Agatha’s throat and hummed her response.

Agatha swallowed a whine.

“Rio. Please.”

Rio smiled into her throat, caught her ear with her teeth, then stepped away.

“Goodnight, Agatha.”

Chapter End Notes

Ooope.

Chapter 13

Chapter Notes

I am so grateful to you all for your beautiful comments. They were so uplifting and encouraging and I read every single one like four times. It really got me motivated and refocused (clearly as I've gotten this update out). I do plan to respond to comments tonight at some point while my GF catches up on Arcane S2.

**TW: Childhood Illness**

This chapter gets really sad at some points. My GF said I was her enemy and if I made her feel any more sadness she would break up with me. So I guess don't expect me to mention her anymore lol

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Agatha was the last from her room– team breakfast avoided, and the last to stuff her suitcase into one of two waiting SUVs outside. She had her sunglasses shoved over her eyes as she walked into the post-dawn light and headed toward their waiting jet. The team was still half-asleep, quiet, but Lilia motioned toward her and laughed.

“Another party before a flight?”

It was an innocent callback to a conversation from nearly a month prior, but memories from the previous night drummed through Agatha’s skull. Rio was boarding with them, walking beside Wanda just two steps back.

“I didn’t sleep well. Scratchy sheets.”

The statement was clipped, an unspoken request for the topic to be dropped.

William pitched in and Agatha was on the verge of relegating him back to intern status permanently.

“Really? I looked up the brand and ordered them the first night we stayed here.”

Agatha’s voice rose mockingly.

“Oh, did you?”

William looked like he was going to respond and Agatha increased her pace, reaching the stairs. She climbed inside before she was forced to converse about thread count while the sensations of Rio inside her after five years was playing on repeat in her body.
