She cleared her throat and pushed the shirt from her right arm instead of waiting for Rio to do so. Her skin prickled and she watched Rio step close, her fingers settling on Agatha’s shoulder. She gently ran her finger along Agatha’s collarbone to see if it remained intact.

Agatha hissed as Rio pressed against the start of a large bruise.

Rio smirked lightly.

“It’s not broken. Doesn’t rule out a fracture but you may just have a bone contusion.”

Agatha rolled her eyes, shifting herself away from Rio’s touch.

“Is that your professional opinion, doctor?”

Rio chuckled and reached for her again. She drew Agatha back, her arms wrapping around her waist, their cold skin pressing together.

“Yeah, do you want your prescription?”

Agatha closed her eyes, glad Rio couldn’t see her face.

“Sure.”

Rio hummed.

“I think a long, hot shower would really aid in your recovery.”

Agatha’s chest rumbled with her laugh, her head fully leaning against Rio’s shoulder.

“You think? Where’s your prognostic confidence?”

Rio sighed forlornly.

“With the eight to fifteen years of medical school, residency, and fellowship I have yet to complete.”

Agatha laughed even though it jostled her stiffening, aching shoulder. She stepped away from Rio’s warmth to get her towel and she tossed a second to Rio.

“I think we can trust your instincts on this one.”
_________

Agatha reached the top of the sledding hill and both Billy and Tommy turned to her, holding out their sleds.

Agatha jumped in before they could begin arguing over who would pair up with who.

“Why don’t you both ride together and I’ll race you?”

Billy shoved his sled in her hands and grabbed at Tommy’s. They got themselves settled and stared in excitement at Agatha.

Agatha looked at the hill, far less steep than the one that had decimated her cohort. She looked where Wanda and Vision were waiting and narrowed her eyes. She placed the sled and sat inside, her hands latching around the handles.

Tommy was sitting in front, his head turned. Both boys looked ready to scoot and Agatha chuckled.

“Alright. On your marks… get set….” She grinned. “Go!”

Agatha let them go first. She had a different mission.

The boys began screaming within seconds, Tommy’s hands flying up as Billy clung to the handles. Agatha pushed off and aimed herself toward Wanda.

It happened in seconds, Wanda yelping, trying to dive away, Agatha reaching out as she passed and clotheslining her legs from under her. The impact hurt like a bitch but she watched as Wanda ate absolute shit in the piles of snow.

Agatha skidded out, fell off of her sled, and tumbled in the snow several feet away.

She heard Vision’s laughter, then Wanda’s, and she realized her body was shaking with it as she rolled onto her knees to get up. Billy and Tommy missed the entire debacle but had no issue joining in with the adults as Wanda pushed herself to her feet.

“You were twenty-six when you went down that hill! I’m pushing forty!”

Agatha’s face ached from the cold and her mouth was dry from her laughter. She stood slowly and shook out her hand as she continued to chuckle.

“Your ankles are made of iron.”

Tommy dragged his sled over.

“Ankles are bones!”

Agatha heaved in a breath and nodded.

“You are so right.”

He smiled at her, his normal reservation and distinct lack of interest nowhere to be found.

A cold, packed wad of snow slammed into the back of her head as a smaller, far less impactful one hit her shoulder.

“You want to be on the winning team?”

Tommy giggled and immediately dropped and began scooping snow toward himself.

_________

Agatha regretted the need to wake up so early the next morning. She was sore from doing absurdities like sledding and having a snowball fight with small children who never grew tired. She rolled out of bed, let her muscles settle, and pulled on a dark sage turtleneck and her off-white slacks and blazer. She skipped breakfast. By the time she’d made her way downstairs, her stomach was a hornet’s nest. The anxiety had spread from her chest to her lungs to the bottoms of her feet and she was trying to swallow back the nausea that seeped up her throat.

She climbed into her car and pointedly avoided looking at her passenger seat.

She sent a quick text to Wanda that she was leaving early and pulled out of the driveway. Her initial plan had included a return trip to the home she hadn’t seen since she ran. It had seemed like a fine idea when she had written the letter, stuck in the pain of it, but now she was certain she couldn’t do so.

She drove to the post office, arriving too early to be able to go inside, and sat in her car with her hand tightly wrapped around the wheel.

It took her ten minutes to look at the letter, five more to pick it up and scrawl her old address on the face of it. Her hand shook as she wrote the familiar numbers and the street she’d expected to grow old in.

She sat for another ten minutes before she was able to step out of the car and walk to the deposit slot. She shoved it inside before she could lose her nerve.

A deep, terrified regret shattered her thin facade of calm and she drew in a breath. She knew that the alternative to this was facing her past, but now that she would be forced to wait, to consider the what ifs, she wasn’t sure which was worse.

Agatha’s knee bounced violently as she drove into work and she cranked the dial, Ray and Dave Davies belting into her car. By the time she arrived she felt like she’d been holding onto an electric fence with both hands.

Agatha quickly made her way inside and beelined for her office. She tossed her shit on the desk and froze. She remembered the clack of her chair against the wall as she’d stood abruptly. It had been returned to its position neatly and the chair Rio had replaced the seat she’d dragged behind the desk in its proper place. Written on four sticky notes set beneath her keyboard were dozens of words in Rio’s distinct writing.

She couldn’t stop her feet from moving, couldn’t avert her eyes, and she sat down to find Rio’s notes on their last discovery along with a few helpful distinctions between the civilizations they’d pinpointed.

Agatha ran her fingers over the notes, her heart in her throat.

Agatha had spent the next several days trying to fall back in rhythm. She woke up early, ran with Vidal, participated and excelled in classes, trained to close out most of her days. Their dynamic had shifted, the curiosity and burgeoning excitement shifting to galvanizing tension. Rio’s eyes lingered, searching, studying, exposing. Agatha could feel her attention at her back on their runs, on the side of her face during their classes, on her body when they trained.

Agatha’s lingering was far more physical in nature. She had never been particularly touchy with anyone in her past. Yet, somehow, she felt as if her hands were constantly finding reasons to touch. A press to Vidal’s back to move her out of her way, the brush of shoulders when they walked side by side, the lag that had developed when Agatha pulled Vidal to her feet or vice versa. Every time they were paired in combat, Agatha had to force her mind to focus and her body to activate her muscle memory.

Their training at night was near torture. Agatha had begun to believe she might be losing her mind every time Vidal caught her, submitted her, and she felt feral at the power rather than frustrated about the loss.

Nothing had occurred since Vidal had brought her lunch and Agatha had kissed her as a dismissal. There were moments where Agatha felt like a drawn bow, so ready to release or snap that she could hardly breathe.

But they always parted before their doors now. Rio on that first night. Agatha on the next two. It was becoming an uncomfortable strain to Agatha’s days. The anticipation was nearly debilitating and she found herself aggravated that Vidal seemed so fucking calm despite the heated gaze she never withdrew.

Several members of her cohort were going out but she’d turned down their invites. She tossed on jeans and a weathered band tee with ‘The Strokes’ written in large letters across the chest. She’d planned to drop by Vidal’s to let her know she wasn’t in for training; that she wanted the night to herself. She needed relief and Vidal was clearly not intending to be the one to provide that. There were dozens of women within walking distance that would.

Vidal lowered her hand slowly, her eyes running up and down Agatha’s appearance. She tilted her head.

“Change of plans?”

Agatha stared at her thighs under her shorts, the muscles visible even when she was relaxed. She swallowed at the thin strip of skin under Vidal’s cropped shirt. Vidal’s arms were bare to the shoulder, the sleeves cut off. Agatha’s voice was a little breathless in her response.

“Yeah. Get dressed.”

Agatha wanted to drive her head into the doorframe repeatedly.

Vidal’s brow rose, a smirk lifting and settling to a grin.

“Yes, ma’am.”

As she turned away, Agatha held her hands out, mouthing vitriol herself as she turned back around. She was an idiot. She was weak. She wouldn’t be able to focus on anything else if Vidal was within a ten-foot radius. This was becoming absurd.
_________

“Oh, she’s getting serious.”

“I prefer you when you’re losing, Vidal.” Agatha leaned down, aligning her shot. “At least when we played pool you made a show of it.”

It turned predatory, heated, and Agatha could feel the way her breathing hitched and grew heavy. Her chest rose and fell as she clenched her hand around the plastic pusher.

“Loser buys shots.”

Agatha shrugged.

They’d drawn the attention of several of the closest tables and only the blasting music kept the sound of the game from being irritating.

She patted Agatha’s side and stepped around her.

“She’s paying.”

Agatha passed over her card, the motion bringing her chest against Vidal’s back. She didn’t retreat, her hand settling on the bar beside Vidal’s.

“Agatha.”

Her fucking voice. It was a warning and a promise in one and Agatha was obsessed with the way her name sounded on her lips.

“Hm?”

Vidal leaned back against her, her head resting under Agatha’s chin. Her chest rose and fell harshly as her hand slid over Agatha’s.

“I think we should leave after these shots.”

The burn of tequila on her throat was enough to distract Agatha for just a moment before she stepped back and headed for the door.
________

The return trip was agonizing and they were almost intercepted by a lategoing group of their cohort after they’d entered the base. Rio had snatched Agatha’s arm and pulled her toward the other dorm entrance.

They arrived at Rio’s door first and Agatha kept her hands to herself as Rio let them in.

Rio’s bed was made and her desk was stacked ridiculously high with books. Sticky notes were plastered across every inch of wood and Agatha couldn’t make out what they were from there.

“Agatha! How was your Christmas?”

Agatha blinked away the clinical focus she had sunken into and frowned.

“Fantastic.”

William didn’t seem to believe her, his lips turning down as he presented her coffee. She noted his eyes tracking across her desk and did not tell him his gift was stuffed in a drawer because the thought of seeing Rio look at her like that made her dizzy.

“Oh, yeah, it was great!” He moved to sit down. “Teddy and my dad had the games on in the background and it became a competition for mom and I to see who could turn the volume down the most without getting caught.”

“I’m thriving. Excelling. Just dandy.” She walked out the door. “I’m going to get another coffee.”
________

By nine, everyone was preparing the war room for the arrival of the visiting agents. Wanda had prepared copies of their updated case files to share and she stacked them near the front of the room. The remaining tables were lined in two rows of four facing the front screen.

The first arrivals were the agents from Birmingham, their team of five led by a man in his early forties. He shook Wanda’s hand, introduced the four other members curtly. He seemed severe, his graying, brown mustache covering the most prominent lines of expression on his face. He had accepted his balding and shaved his entire head. His team sat down, three men and a woman, and Wanda read the situation quickly. She passed them the files so they could immediately dive into the new updates from the team.

Agatha refrained from entering their operations room until it was packed with a dozen agents, all eyes on the work Agatha and Rio had pieced together over their four hours tucked away from the world.

There was chatter and quiet conversations as they picked apart the new evidence and marked it against their own research.

The Cincinnati team had arrived soon after and Agatha ignored the jolt of anxiety when Bohner filed into the room with his team. She wasn’t sure she’d be able to handle seeing him in a senior role, but her rising fears were settled quite quickly as he sat with his team on the opposite side of Birmingham’s while a tall woman with dark skin approached Wanda.

William stood from his desk, his curiosity finally drawn from Agatha to the room.

“Do you think this will go well?”

Agatha shrugged and looked at Rio’s notes that she’d transcribed onto her actual notepad.

“It’s about fifty-fifty. Sometimes everyone is happy to collaborate. Other times, its three separate entities jockeying for the attention and benefits that come from solving a high-profile case.”

William leaned against the edge of her desk.

“Do you think they’ll be mad that you found what they couldn’t? Cinci had the case for three weeks. Birmingham for almost two months.”

Agatha raised her brows.

“Most definitely.”

William laughed at the questioning look she sent him.

“I may have read through your additional notes yesterday. How did you find all of that?”

Agatha glanced over to find Wanda motioning for them. She stood.

“You have to know how to research.” She started to walk away and stopped, letting out a sigh. “It wasn’t just me. Director Vidal’s–” She cleared her throat. “insight… was beneficial.”

“Director Vidal? Does she often engage with–”

Agatha walked out of the room before he could finish the question. She took a seat near the back, William hustling to sit beside her, and watched as the three Senior Agents converged at the front.

Lilia and Jen sat on either side of them and Alice pulled up a chair.

Jen frowned.

“I don’t like all of these people in our business.”

Agatha rolled her eyes.

“Ironic.”

Jen leaned around William but her rebuttal was cut off by the start of the briefing.

The Birmingham Agent, Rodriguez, started them off with a full breakdown of the details everyone was already privy to. It was a drag, a solid hour of regurgitated data and evidence that had Agatha wishing she could slip back into her office to continue her research. She’d just finished sliding back her chair to escape when the door to the war room opened again.

Agatha’s heart dropped, her skin icing over as Rio stepped inside. She stopped breathing and the monotonous droning of Agent Rodriguez became an indiscernible mumble.

Rio wore her navy suit, the tailored pants and blazer sitting perfectly over her white shirt, the collar starched around her neck, top two buttons undone. Her hair was loose but pushed behind her ears and she looked– Agatha drew in a ragged breath.

Rio, as she always presented herself, was like stone. The weight of her presence filled the room, turned the heads of the teams, interrupted the flow of the Senior Agent Rodriguez currently covering the locations of each victim’s body.

But it was like a veil had been lifted from Agatha’s eyes, like she had been living the past several months with an imperfect gaze.

Because, while Rio was stone, she was chipped, imperfect. Cracks, so thin they were almost impossible to see, made themselves apparent to Agatha like streaks of lead on white paper. Rio’s perfect mask was not so perfect.

A part of her had hoped her sudden ability to see was a fluke. That Rio had been the one to change, Rio was the one to reveal herself when she’d sat in Agatha’s office and looked up with such agonizing hope. When she’d gripped the wheel of the car and tried to force all of her emotions back into their proper places. When she’d broken down on the beach.

But this was Director Vidal, the easy control, the straightened spine, and Agatha could still see her. Rio looked tired. She looked more than tired. She looked like she emptied herself out and left the best parts somewhere where they wouldn’t cause her pain.

Agatha glanced around the room and she knew with a certainty that she was the only one seeing it. A sense of odd wonder flooded her and she let her eyes fall to Rio again. Every line of her was so familiar.

When had she forgotten? How had she forgotten?

The guilt came sharply. Who had she been seeing if it wasn’t the woman who had become her entire world? How could she have written off, written out, the person she’d chosen to create a home with? A family?

It was as if she’d constructed a puppet and replaced Rio with something soulless. Something easy to distance herself from, to maintain control over.

Agatha felt the creeping, deadly reach of panic flare in her chest as Rio took a seat near the back of the room on the opposite side of Agatha. Rio hadn’t looked at her, hadn’t given her attention to anyone until she was situated in her chair. Only then did she give a nod for Rodriguez to continue.

He nodded and eased back into connections between the specific spacing of the bodies within clearings and the types of trees found nearby.

Agatha zoned out as Senior Agent LeBlanc took over and shared the specific developments from their killer’s movements in Ohio.

She clenched her hands into fists and kept her eyes locked onto the woodgrain of the table below her to keep from seeking out Rio across the room.

William leaned in her direction and she held a hand out to stop whatever asinine question he thought was appropriate to pose while their entire team and two others were gathered. Instead of a whirl of continuous thoughts about Rio, her mind was like a dead radio station with bits and pieces of traffic picking up and dropping out.

She lost track of time, of her surroundings, and the buzzing only cut out when Wanda spoke her name.

“Agent Harkness.”

Agatha blinked and flushed, hoping this was the first time her name had been said. Wanda didn’t look worried and Agatha violently stuffed her anxiety down as she stood and moved toward the front of the room.

All attention moved to her, Bohner’s eyes locking onto her with his stupid smile spread wide. He was dumb enough to wave and Agatha ignored him entirely.

“Director Vidal and the team were able to isolate a repeating pattern in the carvings on the victims’ bodies.”

She ignored the strange looks she received from her team as she expounded upon their discovery. She successfully dissociated, her emotions dampened to numbness, and her eyes landing anywhere but Rio as she delved into possible theories and the added insight Rio had provided through her sticky notes.

She’d nearly reached the end, finish line in sight, when the war room door opened again. Agatha didn’t stop– assuming whomever it was could ease in quietly– until the newcomer cleared their throat.

“My apologies for interrupting. The instructions left by A. Harkness said that this was to be delivered upon arrival and–” He glanced at the note. “that the contents of the package were not a threat and did not need to be vetted and searched.” He looked up. “Unfortunately, all packages need to be vetted and searched. It’s the cause for the delay.”

When he remained standing, Agatha felt her emotions like an undercurrent, an anger that was greatly misplaced. She held out her hands.

“Do you have a poem to read with your delivery or can you set it to the side and get the hell out?”

The man paled and quickly found the large box amongst the packages and sorted mail. He lifted it, looked around in distress, and then looked to Agatha again.

She fought to stay beneath the waves. The roiling in her body and the skittering of too many feelings were distinctly similar to what she’d experienced on Christmas day.

“Put the box on the ground.”

Her voice snapped, whiplike, and the man quickly set the box down by the door and grabbed his cart. He hesitated, picked up a thick clipboard, and looked at her.

“Um, we actually need A. Harkness to–”

“Leave.”

He dropped the clipboard onto his cart and nodded too many times as he dragged it outside. The wheels screeched against the linoleum in his hurry and Agatha felt the sound echo inside her brain.

She needed a moment or twenty to gather herself before she ripped somebody's head off. She looked back to the room and saw multiple pairs of eyes watching her in the awkward vacuum left behind by the delivery man’s dismissal.

She glanced at Wanda and, to her utter relief, Wanda understood.

Wanda’s voice carried over the room.

“Let’s take a brief intermission before we continue. There’s coffee in the kitchen and the pantry has an assortment of rather dull granola bars for you to choose from.”

The tension in the room eased as conversation broke out and chairs skidded and scratched backward. Everyone’s eyes left her and she pulled in a heavy breath.

She just needed to make it to her office. She needed to sit down, strongarm her brain into submission, and make it through the rest of the day without cracking apart. She’d just reached the table where her team still sat when Bohner’s voice called out behind her.

“Harkness!”

She tensed. Alarms blared in her skull as she turned around.

“Bohner.”

He grimaced at that, his scraggly brown beard and mustache just as unkempt as he’d always kept it. He forced a smile.

“I always regret not taking Greta’s last name.” His face took on a constipated look and Agatha felt a chill cut through her. “I– well– I never got to say I’m sorry for what– I mean.” He let out a pitched chuckle and Agatha couldn’t fucking breathe. “You are so strong. “Agent Bohner.”

She heard Rio’s voice like it was spoken into a tunnel.

Agatha was staring through his skull. She had dropped wholly and jarringly back into her body sometime during his speech and she was completely lost.

Bohner turned to Agatha’s left and smiled.

“Vidal!”

Agatha felt a hand on her arm and stepped with it as it pulled.

Wanda ushered her toward the exit of the operations room and Agatha followed like a ghost.

She wasn’t wholly present for the journey as they took the elevators and walked through a familiar corridor. She didn’t recognize where she was until Wanda was guiding her into Rio’s chair.

Agatha blinked, breathing erratic, and tried to focus enough that the swelling fear in her skull wouldn’t split her in two.

Wanda knelt down in front of her and gripped her hands.

“Agatha, you’re okay.” Wanda’s hands squeezed hers lightly. “Breathe. Breathe. That’s good.”

Wanda freed a hand and pushed Agatha’s hair over her shoulders. The lack of weight against her cheeks and jaw and temple was freeing.

Wanda squeezed her hands again.

“How can I help?”

The words rang in Agatha’s ears, repeating themselves from a long-forgotten memory. The iron grip around her heart eased as she thought of Rio.

Chapter End Notes

There are moments of this chapter I wasn't sure about because I was writing for so long that it all just looked like a jumbled mess. I know when I step away and come back I will feel a bit better. I may return to make some edits.

Chapter 20

Chapter Notes

We got a rather large chapter here. Just under 10k.

TW for religious trauma and incredibly hateful speech. If you are not able to read that at the moment, don't go past "go gloat, kid" and check the ending notes for a synopsis.

Got some shit-ass news today about a job I used two days of PTO to interview for, had three interviews, and then received a basic ass email telling me they weren't moving forward. Writing this chapter took my mind off of it so hopefully I continue to have a spiteful drive to write.

I’ve had a hard time getting a moment to respond to the comments. Just know that I’ve read every single one and I adore them and I will do my best to reply.

See the end of the chapter for more notes

”Harkness.”

Agatha glanced up from her mostly packed bag to see a staff member standing in her open door. She glanced to Rio where she was lounging on Agatha’s bed and found her similarly bemused expression.

The man nodded.

“I know.” She squeezed. “I’m proud of you for pushing through it.”

There were two photographs that hadn’t been there, at least not visible, on Agatha’s last visit. One was Nicky. His pretty blue eyes and forest of brown curls were stark against his pale cheeks. He was wearing a bucket hat that was too big for his head, the brim of it hanging over his eyebrows and the back of it resting against his neck. He had on a full khaki outfit and was holding his stuffed rabbit in his hands. Agatha’s fingers reached out to brush against the glass, her heart stuttering. Her eyes turned to a second one and her breath caught.

It was a photo she didn’t recognize.

It was of all three of them. Rio and Agatha were looking down, Nicky between them as they walked through the park. They’d let him walk whenever he asked, even if it meant they showed up late to everything for the few weeks it took for the novelty to wear off.

“I found it on my phone a few years ago. I don’t even remember the specifics of the day. Where we were headed or if Vis was even with us.”

Agatha swallowed and looked away.

“Could you send me this photo?”
__________

To her endless relief, her return to their operations room was not met with any strange looks. Bohner and Rio were no longer present, the visiting teams were gathered and pouring over the evidence, and her own team had taken up space in the kitchen.

She knew they’d likely seen or heard something, that they undoubtedly had assumptions and questions, but when William caught her eye, he just smiled. He waved her toward them and Agatha made a pitstop on the way to stoop down and pick up the large box sitting by the door.

She ignored their looks as she carried the hefty box to the counter and set it on the side. She unplugged the coffee maker, dislodged the fresh pot to set to the side, and swept the machine into the trash to the outcries of her team behind her.

She didn’t look back as she ripped into the box.

“William. Bring your tools.”

He appeared at her side moments later.

“What tools? I don’t have any tools.”

Agatha paused in removing the styrofoam to frown at him.

“What do you constantly have on your desk when you're fiddling with your little statue?”

William’s cheeks reddened slightly.

“Oh, those aren’t– well, they are, but not the kind of tools you…” He tilted his head, eyes falling to the box. “probably need.”

Agatha set the styrofoam aside and tried to dissect whatever the fuck that meant.

“What kind of tools are they?”

William reached for the styrofoam and picked at it.

“For building a Metal Earth model. Specifically, the Tardis.”

Agatha’s bones grinded at the sound of the styrofoam and she smacked his hand away as she began to unpack the box.

“I don’t know what any of that means.” He looked like he was going to explain further and Agatha raised her brow. “Don’t be tricked into believing I want to hear more.”

She lifted the hefty, black machine out and onto the counter and William crowded her space to get a look.

“Holy shit!” He frowned. “What do you need tools for? I think you just plug it in.”

Agatha shouldered him to the side and peered into the box. She pulled out two protective bags and huffed.

“Find me a screwdriver.”

She opened the instructions and added a “please” just as William spoke an easy “you got it.”

He left and Wanda took his place, amusement in her voice.

“This is a way to avoid buying gifts.”

Agatha flipped through the instructions.

“Of course it is. I don’t have time to think about what kind of poison to slip into a fifty-dollar shampoo for Jen.”

William returned like he’d been running and held out a flathead.

She stared at it for several moments and then looked to Wanda.

Wanda took the flathead from William’s hand and laughed.

“I’ll find a Phillips. Thank you, William.”

By the time Agatha had assembled the final pieces and secured the portafilter holders, she felt as close to okay as she was going to get for the day. Any anxiety remaining had slipped away when minute after minute passed without a comment or question from her team.

She grabbed a sticky note, scribbled ‘Happy Fucking Holidays’ on it, and slapped it on the machine before walking out of the kitchen without a word.
_________

The next several days were a balancing act of brimming regret for the letter that was sure to arrive at Rio’s soon, genuine explorative work and collaboration with the two visiting teams, and a tenuous sense of self as she fluctuated between stable and bitchy depending on who was in her sphere.

She spent most of her time huddled away in her office and only engaged when she had to. Jen had commandeered control of the samples and body found in Virginia. She spent a significant portion of her time researching the type of blade used to carve into the skin.

Lilia was working to craft a stronger profile using Agatha’s updated information; she was completely in her element and despite their late coming to the case, was given deferment by the other teams.

Alice was working through the victims’ heritage to find any connection between them and the languages and symbols carved into the victims.

The Cincinnati team had brought in a language expert who’d been able to identify Ancient Korean writing along the right shoulder. It had been improperly transcribed, the shapes incorrect, and once studied, the world revealed was ‘death.’

The discovery only left a single word on the left shoulder undiscovered. It was assumed to be ‘sacrifice,’ but so far they’d had no luck in finding the origin.

She hadn’t seen Rio since the briefing, and Bohner had given Agatha a wide berth since.

Now, Friday, Agatha was sitting with William beside her as she looked over the shallow pool of documents from The Moche civilization. They were clearing rapidly through the rather staggering list of civilizations that practiced any form of human sacrifice and Agatha knew they had to be missing something. She’d looked into the Moche previously and had ruled them out due to a lack of a written language.

William had a notepad, but he seemed to be taking notes on Agatha’s process rather than the information itself.

“Why are you considering this one if it doesn’t have a language?”

Agatha chewed on her lower lip as she picked through her current document. She’d gotten the idea to go back through from Rio’s notes that were still tucked under her keyboard.

Don’t rule out the languages that have no orthography. Phonetics can be utilized to map sounds to symbols. Due to the killer’s general lack of expertise and willingness to make logical leaps, it’s possible they tried their hand at crafting their own wording.

“Because there’s still phonetics. Sounds and their supposed meanings.” She pointed to the particularly gruesome image on the page. “The Moche sacrificed for fertility, their harvests, weather, and various other reasons. In all likelihood, we have more access to documents regarding the civilizations this killer is adopting into his ritual.” She scrolled lower and tried to contain the thrill that shot through her. “Take a look at this. What do you see?”

William leaned in and Agatha slid back to give him an easier view. He set his notebook on her desk and scribbled a few symbols.

“The ‘S’ looking symbol. It matches the first unidentified letter pretty closely.”

Agatha stared at the carved image and looked back at the screen.

“And?”

William wrote a few more scratches into his page.

“The ‘U’. Su?”

Agatha nodded toward the operations room.

“I think we may have found our final word. Grab our linguistic friend. She can confirm.”

William grinned excitedly and hustled from the room as Agatha wrote ‘su= to give or to offer. She looked but could not find any more matching phonetics.

William returned with the young woman, her face round with thin, wire glasses sitting on the bridge of her nose. She had deep, brown skin and her braids ended at the collar of her sweater vest. She seemed excited as she trailed after William.

“You’re Agent Harkness?”

Agatha stood and offered her seat.

“Yes. We might have something but I don’t have the expertise to be able to take it further.”

The woman sat and turned to give Agatha a brilliant smile.

“I’m Dr. Thomas. You can just call me Imara. From what I’ve heard, you’re the reason we’ve almost completed identifying the historical context of these mutilations.”

Agatha shook her head.

“Director Vidal was imperative in that search.”

Agatha ignored William as his eyes shifted to study her. He’d been doing that a lot more; the only sign that he’d heard anything of her and Bohner’s conversation.

Imara nodded.

“Of course, I’ve worked with her before. She’s rather interested in history if I remember correctly.”

Agatha didn’t want to confirm, didn’t want to insist it was far more than interest. She shrugged noncommittally and waited to see whether she’d hit another dead end.

Imara hummed, the pitch excited.

“Oh.” She looked down at William’s notes and began to add to them, her eyes flying across the page, her voice reciting like a memorized textbook. “The indigenous languages of the Andes. Quechuan and Aymaran languages were the most prevalent. It is entirely possible the killer borrowed from one of them to develop the rest of his word.”

She typed rapidly, pulling up several other pages. Agatha stood and watched as Imara scrolled. She finally stopped and she smiled brightly back at Agatha.

“Bingo. Holy shit– I mean, sorry for my language but holy shit.” She raised her brows. “How did you even get to this without context?”

Agatha grit her teeth and tried to find a way to merit it to Rio without receiving another odd look from William. She cleared her throat.

“Director Vidal suggested that the language might not need an orthography.”

Imara chuckled.

“I told her she was in the wrong field.”

Agatha disliked the familiarity and the way it twisted her chest. She looked at the words Imara had written out.

ʃu– to give or to offer.
ŋka– a formalized act or event.
Hypothetical word: ʃuːŋka– Shunka

It matched the word carved into the victims near-perfectly and Agatha thought about Rio’s reaction to the killer inventing their own word in a dead language. Where Imara seemed intrigued, she knew Rio would have a scathing review.

She forced the thought from her mind as it brought with it a nearly crippling anxiousness.

Imara stood.

“Come on. You’ll need to present this to the teams. This will aid in our exploration of the sites, the victims, and the timeline.”

Agatha did. She kept it short and sweet, her ego fed through every awed look and constipated stare from the Agents she’d beaten to the punch.

For the remainder of the day, she shifted her attention to the locations each victim was found and continued, as best she could, not to think of the letter that might be sitting in Rio’s mailbox or shoved into her trash can.
________

In Agatha’s moments alone, the ones where her sense of self seemed to fracture into distinct identities– one that wanted to run, one that wanted to heal, one, so new and unbidden, that craved something she had forgotten– she would write.

Rio,

Dr. Imara Thomas has been working with us on the joint case. She mentioned you, said you’d worked together before, that you would have excelled as a subject expert. I remember when you would study into the late hours of the night before Nicky was born and how excited the material made you. When Nicky came along, you weren’t even mad that he’d wake up at all hours of the night; you’d take him into your arms with your flashcards and a book light and you’d rock him to sleep whispering about urban planning in major cities in America or Iceland’s longest lasting Parliament. I remember being so relieved that somebody else had to hear your notes repeated for hours, that I didn’t have to drag myself out of bed.

I’d give anything in the world to have either back.

When Nicky got his diagnosis, you dropped everything; your classes, your hobbies. You spent hours every single night researching and connecting with doctors and other families that had gone through similar things. You spent so much time understanding the effects of food on our bodies that you could probably pursue a career as a nutritionist if you wanted to. You took everything as it came, fought with your soul to keep our son alive. Believed the stark, horrific truth of things when the doctor gave her final prognosis.

I’m so sorry it took me until recently to understand you in those last months of his life. I was lost in my destructive hope, in my denial, and I let it drown me.

I see you now.

Yours,

Agatha

In between work and letters, Agatha spent time with Billy, and to her surprise, now Tommy. They would come by with armfuls of toys and toss them on Agatha’s floor to play. They built tunnels and huts for Scratchy and squealed when he destroyed them instead of running through them.

Sometimes she would find herself in the living room of the main house with Wanda watching old sitcoms or in the study with Vision getting her ass handed to her in chess.

She met with Alder and endured her first full conversation about Nicky. That had been a terrible day. One that had her curled in the fetal position on his quilt, sobs wracking her chest as she clung to the fabric.

Every day that passed drew her closer to the 29th, to the day that she hadn’t made it through sober in five years.

Friday after work, Agatha mailed her second letter. The petrifying fear had lessened to a pained acceptance. She was determined that, at this one thing, she wouldn’t fail, she wouldn’t cower away.

She still hadn’t seen Rio, didn’t know how her letter had been received, but she pressed on because, for once, it felt like she might be getting somewhere.
_______

Saturday night, while Agatha was lounging on one side of the Maximoff's incredibly comfortable sofa and Wanda and Vision were cuddled into the other, their phones rang.

Wanda had said a quick goodbye to Vision and Agatha had run to the guesthouse to throw on slacks and a sweater. They’d climbed into Wanda’s car and driven forty minutes to a half-built structure on the edge of Maryland.

Snow blanketed the ground and reflected the bright reds and blues of the police vehicles cordoning off the area. Personnel and police tape was posted along the perimeter and Wanda and Agatha flashed their badges as they slipped under.

As they met with the police Lieutenant, getting a quick synopsis of what they’d found inside, Jen and Alice arrived, and Lilia followed only a short two minutes behind.

Jen was impatient, eyes on the partially constructed building. She was the first to enter the scene when they were given the green light.

The team stepped carefully around the evidence markers on the ground; numbers denoting large footprints, splatters of blood, and the sickening trail of hair and a chunk of skin leading up to the open construction site.

It was small, the building the first of many that were supposed to be erected within the next several months. An eventual summer camp for middle schoolers preparing to start high school.

Agatha carefully stepped onto the cement base, her eyes flickering over the familiar scene. The icy air masked the smell of blood and death only slightly and she felt the pungent scent of it burn through her nose.

In the same pose as before, with the same carvings, was a body. Only this time, the head had been removed entirely and taken.

Agatha tugged her gloves onto her hands as Jen squatted close to the body. She was speaking quietly with the analysts on scene, directing them to take specific photos.

Agatha, no matter how many bodies she’d come across, always felt the uncomfortable churning in her gut when she was forced into close proximity.

“It’s an alarming change to the killer’s signature.”

Alice nodded, her eyes passing over the space.

“This is the second body in a row found in a building under construction.” She tapped her fingers against her thigh and Agatha could tell she was piecing something together. “The linguist uncovered Ancient Korean as the right shoulder carving, right?”

Wanda nodded.

“Right. Why?”

Alice pursed her lips.

“It could be a loose representation of sacrificing to secure the foundation of a building. That was the believed reason for their sacrifices; to ensure the sturdiness of the foundation for important structures.”

Lilia huffed softly.

“I can’t believe this building holds any importance to our killer.” She turned, looked around. “I think he is fully crafting his delusion; creating a dogma or personal ritual.”

Agatha frowned.

“He?”

Lilia nodded.

“All evidence points to a male killer. And the prints outside were quite large. This is not often how the female mind, even the psychopaths, operate.”

Wanda twisted a finger in the air.

“Jen, stay here until all samples have been collected. The other field office agents are arriving soon and I want boots on the ground looking for that head.”
__________

By the time they arrived at the WFO, there were seventeen miserable, wet, and freezing agents that poured into their operations center. Jen was the only one that hadn’t touched the snow and Agatha had considered pushing her into a drift on the walk back to their cars.

She ran her hands together and made a beeline for the espresso machine with her team hot on her heels.

William popped out of their office and met them in the kitchen, sliding through irritated bodies.

“The images from the scene came through an hour ago.” He glanced around at the unhappy faces and lowered his voice. “I’m assuming you didn’t find the head.”

Agatha stared at the steaming machine and debated putting her hands near it like a fire.

“You assume correctly.”

Lilia was grumpier than Agatha had ever seen her and she scoffed.

“We searched a ten mile perimeter and found jack-all. I think we could have left that to loca–” She cut herself off and nearly bodied Agatha out of the way as she retrieved her mug. “Move it, Harkness.”

Agatha nearly spilled the burning hot shot of espresso on her hands, a sharp noise of surprise leaving her mouth.

“Lilia!”

Lilia was already manhandling the machine for the next pour and she simply grunted.

William’s eyes widened at Alice and Alice shook her head.

Jen didn’t have the sense to keep her mouth shut.

“You won’t get your coffee any faster by breaking the machine.”

The team went silent.

Agatha smiled, holding in her laugh with her back to the team as she foamed milk.

Lilia’s voice rivaled Agatha’s in her most acerbic moments.

“What was that, Kale? Miss ‘I take two hours to collect samples so I don’t have to put my dainty fucking feet in the snow? Do you have anything else to share?”

Agatha poured the milk into her cup and hid her amusement behind the rim of the mug on her lips.

Alice and William had taken a step back and Jen was leaning slightly away from the sinister expression on Lilia’s face.

Jen held out her hands.

“Damn, Lilia, okay. Point taken.”

Lilia stared her down until her espresso had finished pouring. She pointed at Alice.

“You’re next.” She glowered at Jen. “You’re last. I will set your desk on fire.”

Jen’s eyes widened as Lilia stalked out of the kitchen and Agatha let out a cackle as soon as she was certain Lilia was out of earshot. Alice’s lips curled into a smile as she took her place in front of the machine.

William glanced at Agatha.

“That was almost scarier than you.” Agatha’s face soured immediately and he shook his head. “Nevermind.”
______

They spent the rest of Saturday huddled over their computers, everyone seeking threads to point them in the direction of the next possible victim. Alice fleshed out her theory, attempting to connect the scenes of the murders to the civilizations they had identified.

Jen had returned to the body for the autopsy and sent pages of notes with two sentences underlined. The head was removed after death. I won’t be able to tell until the lab results come back, but I’m wondering if the concoction that has killed the last several victims is the same or if this change in signature goes deeper.

Agatha worked with Will and Lilia, the three of them pouring through the history of the named civilizations to see if there was anything regarding beheading. Despite their efforts, there was no connection directly related.

They’d commandeered a table in the corner and the room was filled with murmurs of quiet conversation as the dozen guest agents worked around them.

Will frowned.

“What if it’s a ‘new’ civ?”

He put air quotes around the word ‘new.’

Agatha leaned back in her chair, head tilting.

“What are you thinking?”

William drummed his fingers on the table.

“What if he’s adding civilizations as he kills?”

Lilia shook her head.

“That wouldn’t align with the pattern. He’s put the same carvings on every victim. This new one had the same carvings; just without the head.”

Agatha hummed.

“How often do serial killers adjust their signatures?”

Lilia tilted her head back and forth.

“Almost never. Their MOs have a tendency to change. Usually a way to avoid detection if they’re not the attention-seeking type. Sometimes it's as simple as a learning curve or a change to environment or psychological state. But the signature is often a compulsion. It’s often deeply rooted to the killer’s psyche and motivations.”

Agatha stared at her screen for several moments, her mind thumbing through the possibilities. She looked to Will.

“Still pursue it. See if anything matches so closely that it can’t be ignored.” She turned her attention to Lilia. “It’s rare but it has happened, right? A signature change?”

Lilia nodded.

“In a few cases. Fantasies evolve, boredom can set in, they can adopt new symbols. It’s not impossible, especially with the killer’s flexibility in combining the sacrificial elements of half-a-dozen civilizations. The only connection is in the sacrifice itself. Not the reason or the culture or the time period.” She nodded. “It’s definitely worth considering.”
__________

Near the end of the day, the Cincinnati team had been able to identify correlation between the victims and their connection to the ancient civilizations. They requested samples to be taken, for the DNA of each victim to be checked for specific genetic markers.

Alice had joined them to show her slowly-stabilizing theory regarding the locations of the deaths and they’d closed out with a significant amount of new data to explore the next day.

As they were packing up, bone-tired and grumpy, William piped up.

“There’s a Trivia night. At a bar nearby.” He looked nervous. “I’m meeting Eddy there now if anyone wants to join?”

Agatha’s first instinct was to say no, to go home and bury herself in her bed until she had to wake up and likely return to the office first thing in the morning. Instead, she let his nervousness sway her.

“I could do with a drink.”

Alice shrugged.

“Sure. Why not.”

Lilia nodded, lips pursed.

“I would like to forget this day. I still feel the cold in my bones.”

Jen, who’d rejoined them after a day staring at the cadaver and their many samples, hesitantly agreed.

“I’ll come too as long as Lilia doesn’t throw me from the bar when I’m trying to get a drink.”

Lilia rolled her eyes, her prior agitation having seeped away. She patted Jen’s arm.

“Why don’t we just let that go? Hmm?”

Jen scoffed, a smile pulling at her lips as she went to her office to return her laptop.

Agatha shot Wanda a text and did the same.
__________

Forty minutes later, they were all gathered tightly together in a booth with William and his boyfriend.

Agatha liked him. He seemed doting, easygoing. He looked at Will like he was a king and it made her chest ache.

They idly played trivia, the questions so asinine that the breadth of intelligence at the table far overshot the minutia being asked. William and Eddy were by far their strongest players, their apparently rampant use of social media keeping them in the game.

They placed a strong sixth and Wanda joined them soon after the ending of the game.

Agatha was gently buzzed and squished against Will and Alice. She laughed and it didn’t hurt. She smiled and she meant it.

It was strange, unfamiliar, but she let herself settle into the warmth of it.

Alice nudged her.

“I’m going to smoke a dart.”

Agatha followed easily to the back patio and they took up beside one of the outdoor heaters that barely worked.

She took the cigarette offered to her and palmed the lighter. The first drag of smoke into her lungs felt like heaven.

Alice was quiet next to her for several moments but it wasn’t necessarily uncomfortable. They’d half-finished their cigarettes before Alice spoke. Her voice was quiet, unthreatening.

“You are an incredible agent, Agatha.”

Agatha blinked, frowned. She felt a flush of embarrassment and didn’t know what to do with the compliment.

“You too?”

Alice chuckled and sat on the edge of the closest table.

“I’m not fishing for compliments. I’m telling you a truth. You are fucking good at this job.” Alice ashed her cigarette. “Every person on our team knows it. Every agent visiting from Cincinnati and Birmingham too.” She nodded. “I am never going to pry and I do not expect to talk about your history. But I wanted you to know that it doesn’t change, won’t change, how the team sees you. How Will looks up to you.” She put her cigarette out before it was finished, like she was going to give Agatha a few moments to herself. “If you ever do want to talk, nobody, not even Jen, would turn you away.”

Agatha didn’t respond as Alice walked back inside. She stared at the frozen ground and let her cigarette burn down until it was searing her skin. She cleared her throat and dropped the butt into the ashtray.

To her surprise, Alice bumping into her walls, peering over them, didn’t terrify her nearly as much as Bohner’s ill-timed, ill-worded attempt at sympathy. She didn’t feel pitied, didn’t feel weak. Alice hadn’t stayed to see if Agatha would break down or spill her guts; she’d just given her a lifeline, told her to tug if she needed saving.

She returned to the table and Alice acted like nothing had changed. She slid out, allowed Agatha to squish in next to Will, and continued her conversation with Wanda across the table.

Will feigned a gag as she reached for her drink.

“I don’t know how you do that. Cigarettes smell.”

Agatha chuckled and dulled the taste of it with her beer.

“I hope they ban flavored vapes.”

William and Eddy gasped, a twin press of hands against their chests. William seemed to remember himself then.

“Wait…” he frowned. “That in no way affects me actually. I didn’t even know vapes were flavored. How terrible and bad for our youth.”

Agatha rolled her eyes at his horrific attempt at covering up his blunder.

“Okay. How quickly did you burn through the pink one you just bought?”

William’s eyes shot wide as Eddy snickered beside him.

“How!”

Lilia turned her attention to him from across the table.

“You work with seasoned FBI agents, William.”

The table’s attention turned to the conversation, each one naming the moment they saw Will sneak out of the office or step away to vape. Agatha laughed as she told him that she’d seen it fall out of his bag when he’d come to work at the safehouse.

By the time she and Wanda made it home, it was late, nearing midnight. They’d both been up for nearly twenty-four hours and they were expected for a late-start in the office by noon the next day.

Still, as Agatha reached her room, she sat down to write.

Rio,

I understand what you meant when you said you had so many things that you wanted to tell me. Now, without the option to seek you out, I find myself wishing I could share even the most mundane of experiences. I won’t. I don’t want to waste any time when you might ask me to stop writing to you at any moment, when you might stop reading these.

Instead, I want to tell you that I’m sorry. I know there are thousands of things I could apologize to you for, things that I did so wrong. But I want to focus on the present for just a moment, on the choices I’ve made since returning that grate at my conscience, the ones that sits like tar in my lungs.

You were doing your best to save me, to keep me from ruining my career, and I threw that back in your face in Greece. I never should have touched you with hands meant to harm, meant to cause pain. I know how cruel it was of me to toss aside your clearly set boundaries, to disregard your plea.

I should have seen how much pain you were in, Rio. I should have looked for it. I know exactly where you try to hide it, what it looks like printed on your skin. I’m sorry I didn’t try to understand.

You should know that I did mean it. Even though I didn’t want to, even when it made me mad with rage, I meant it.

I’m sorry I ever let you believe that I didn’t.

Yours,

Agatha


_________

The next week was grueling. The news had finally picked up on the story and they were making a mess of things. Names were tossed around, incorrect evidence, and a whole lot of fear was incited by the false suggestion that the killer was hunting at random, that there were no leads despite the months law enforcement had been in pursuit.

Reporters and news vans sat outside the WFO in hopes of catching anyone to speak on the matter.

On top of the news-drop, they’d also begun receiving dozens of calls, empty leads that drew resources and police to dead ends.

The team managed it with as much grace as possible, though tempers were short and the pressure was high. They’d snap and snipe at each other for eight to ten hours of the day, but, as soon as they stepped out of the building, they would reset, recuperate, and try again the next day.

A tradition had been born with that first Trivia night. On Monday, the team had found themselves at another bar, no trivia this time, and they’d spent the night throwing darts and bemoaning their eighth long day in a row with no end in sight. Wanda had told Will he would have to take Wednesday and Thursday off due to his non-salaried position and he had asked her six times if she’d keep him updated on any new findings.
___

Thursday, tensions in the operations room boiled over. The three teams had gathered for a briefing, Wanda, LeBlanc, and Rodriguez spearheaded the breakdown, detailing every solid piece of evidence and allowing for the team to toss out their theories.

Jen stepped forward with results from the lab regarding their newest victim’s bloodwork.

“Our victim, identified as Rumi Condori, had the similar concoction of embalming substances as the others, but there were trace amounts of MDMA in his system. It is unclear if this was ingested by Condori before or after his capture several days ago.

She flipped through to further results.

“So far, the theory that the victims may be chosen due to their heritage is incredibly plausible. Analysis of mitochondrial DNA from our first victim revealed that the individual belongs to haplogroup L, a lineage predominantly associated with Sub-Saharan African ancestry. Our second victim belongs to Y-DNA haplogroup E1b1b, a lineage predominantly associated with North and Northeast Africa. It can also be traced to parts of Europe. This would align with the Ancient Egyptian connection. I believe the results we are still waiting on will replicate this result in some way.”

Alice spoke up from where she sat beside Agatha.

“That means our killer has access to genetic testing. Correctly picking these victims by their appearances would have been impossible.”

One of Cincinnati's team members spoke up.

“That should narrow our search significantly, shouldn’t it?”

Alice scoffed, earning Agatha’s appreciation and a warning look from Wanda.

“Do you know how many people have access to genetic testing in the United States? Anyone can access the testing agencies. Even if we narrow our search to those able to administer and read the tests you’re looking at ten thousand. That doesn’t include the hundreds of thousands of lab technicians that might have learned to interpret the tests.”

Wanda stepped in before anyone could snap back.

“It does give us another avenue to pursue.” She looked to LeBlanc. “Do you and your team want to spearhead that search?”

The Senior Agent nodded, her jaw tight, and Agatha buried her smirk. She spoke up over the din of conversation.

“William is not here but he proposed a theory I believe considers merit. Especially after the lab results.” She felt the attention of everyone in the room turn to her. “As we’re assuming, there is a pattern of two victims per civilization. That means that our most recent victim is, in fact, outside of our current identified civilizations. I would like to take time to explore this change in signature and believe William might be correct in proposing that a civilization has been added to the mix.”

There was a period of quiet, then a quiet voice murmured.

“Great, let’s let the intern make suggestions when we run out of ideas. Fucking Christ.”

Agatha’s lips curled into a sharp smile as she found the man on Birmingham’s team leaning into one of his companions. He noticed her gaze and sat up straighter.

Agatha raised her brow.

“Oh no, by all means. Let’s hear from the team that has provided nothing but warm bodies to this investigation. If you’d like to go home, the void you leave behind will not be noticed. I’m sure we could make better use of table space.”

The man who’d made the comment stood, the others following, only to be confronted by Agent Rodriguez.

Wanda moved to Agatha and gave her a frustrated head shake as she sent them back to their offices.
______

 

Rio,

I have taken time removed from the first reading of your letters. I have read them again. And again. I will not linger on the loss of what might have been if I had been stronger; it will do very little to lessen the weight, but I will do my best to explain.

You should know that I never moved on from you, from our son. In the five years I was away, I lived a halflife. I know you know this, I know it’s why you brought me back here. You were right to do so.

It was an enduring emptiness that on its best days felt like a relief, and on its worst, a tourniquet suffocating the flow of blood to my heart.

Sometimes I would sleep on the couch because I couldn’t look at Nicky's quilt.

It was the only thing I’d been able to take when I left and even then, it spent months tucked into the recesses of a chest in my room. I was so certain that the moment I faced him, what was left of him, I would shatter and never recover. I was so afraid that the pain of it would render me a husk, a being of skin and blood and nothing else. I know now that I became that anyway. In my avoidance.

In the earliest memories of my departure, I know I lost days, even weeks, to the mindlessness that had overtaken me. Even when I worked with the police, I had simply found a way to package my apathy in a bitter but efficient box so as to be minutely digestible for those around me.

But, in all of it, in every empty moment, every meaningless victory, you were always there.

Yours,

Agatha.

______

Friday, Agatha had decided to work from her office. She was becoming far too irritable and Wanda had requested she avoid starting fights with the other agents.

Will blasted into their office with the energy of somebody that had not taken a break, but instead spent the entire two days off obsessing over the case.

He smiled at her.

“Alice said you put forward my theory. Can we pursue it or was it sidelined?”

Agatha motioned toward his desk.

“Pursue away. I can help you once I’m finished reading through our next-of-kin statements.”

William had set to work with a laser focus, his eyes constantly roving through whatever pages of text he’d been looking for.

It had taken almost four hours of continuous research before William let out a strangled sound, his eyes blowing wide as he looked at his computer.

“Agatha!” He waved at her wildly. “Agatha, I found it.”

She stood to walk to his desk even as he continued flailing.

“Agatha!”

“Breathe before you pass out William.”

She circled his desk and looked down as he began to read the words aloud, entirely defeating the purpose of her moving at all. She rolled her eyes.

“The Nazca site led to the unearthing of twenty-two human remains that inhabited southern Peru from 100 B.C. to 800 A.D. Four of these human remains were trophy heads; one child and three adults. In an analysis of the hair taken from the child, it was discovered that the victim had ingested a natural psychedelic, mescaline.”

Agatha whistled, a glimmer of pride sitting in her chest as she took in William’s excited expression. She tilted her head toward the door.

“Go gloat, kid.”
________

As the day neared its end, a bright spot of hope bringing up their moods, their team headed down the elevators with intentions to grab a drink at the nearby bar before going home. Wanda walked with them despite declining the invitation to join.

Agatha felt good. There was a hollowness, an ache in her that never really seemed to fade, but there was also hope. A glimmer of belief that she might be able to live the rest of her life and feel even small shreds of joy and happiness.

She was walking beside William as they exited into the brisk evening, Jen and Lilia ahead, Alice and Wanda behind. The bar was close enough to walk and they slowed outside to say their goodbyes.

Wanda had just reached out to squeeze Agatha’s arm when Agatha’s eyes passed over William’s shoulder.

Her lungs seized violently as she took in long, gray hair, a weathered face, and the cold hazel eyes of a woman she hadn’t seen or spoken to in nearly ten years. She heard Wanda say something but she suddenly felt like the terrified little girl that used to find the darkest corners of her home to avoid being seen.

A hand touched her shoulder and Agatha drew in a shaky breath as Evanora Harkness stood from a bench twenty feet away and began a dreadmarch toward her.

She wasn’t sure what the others were doing, what they were seeing. She felt as if she’d been glued, rooted deeply to the cement. Her hands were numb and her eyes stung from a low, simmering desolation.

Evanora came to a stop several feet away, her eyes leaving Agatha to look behind her for several moments.

“When I heard that you had returned to DC, I didn’t believe it.” She looked just as calculated and bitter as she always had. “I would have expected you to come to terms with your decisions. To come home and repent.” Evanora shook her head. “What greater, damning sign can God give than the death of one’s child?” She sighed. “Yet here you stand, returned to your vile job.” She glanced toward the sound of a door slamming open and her face hardened. “To your wife. If God had wanted you to have a wife, he would have made you a man, Agatha.”

Agatha’s arms hung loose at her sides, the barrage of her mother’s warped beliefs bludgeoning at the very fragile scab holding her together. Agatha couldn’t see through the tears she had no ability to control, couldn’t think past the hate, the disgust, the harsh, ugly words.

Evanora put on the face of a disappointed mother, the face of hatred that had been Agatha’s norm for so long.

“God, in all his mercy, delivered that boy from evil. He is lucky he died before he came to recognize that he’d been born into the claws of a sexual deviant, a devil.” Spit flew from her mouth, her eyes black with hate. “He was an abomination.”

Agatha flinched back and she felt the surge of bodies as multiple members of her team stepped around her. She saw a dark figure nearly collide with her mother, heard the echo of a smack, and Evanora’s form stumbled. Wanda, Alice, and William had halted their momentum and Agatha blinked her tears from her eyes.

Holding up the surprisingly quiet, wobbly form of Agatha’s mother with a fist in her collar, was Rio.

Agatha stared, her heart thundering in her chest as Rio’s rigid form stood before Evanora and spoke so quietly that she couldn’t make out the words.

Evanora’s face, a vibrant, splotchy red on her right side, darkened, then blanched, her eyes widening in fear. She didn’t struggle against Rio’s hand curled into the collar of her shirt and her eyes fell from Agatha sharply, aimed toward the ground.

Rio spoke for some time, never releasing her grip, and Agatha could do nothing but stare as her mother’s expression folded in on itself. She didn’t look at Agatha again; not even as Rio released her.

Evanora turned sharply and stormed away without another word.

Rio watched, her shoulders tight, until Evanora was entirely out of sight.

The collective tension in the group did not lessen as Agatha tried to search for the many bandages Alder had provided her with to patch up her wounds when they were torn open. But there was too much blood, too much pain, and she lowered her gaze to the ground with a defeated gasp.

She could feel the hesitance, the shock from her companions. She wondered if her mother’s words had rang true for any of them. If they saw her as evil, as villainous.

Sleek, leather shoes appeared in her vision and soft fingers gripped her chin, lifted her face.

Rio had tears in her eyes as she looked at Agatha with such fierce determination that Agatha’s world simply stopped.

“You are good, Agatha.” She swallowed, her voice hoarse. “And, however short our time with him, our son was a gift.”

Rio let her go and turned as Wanda gently gripped her arm.

“We should get ahead of this.”

Rio drew in a slow breath. She kept her eyes forward.

“She won’t press charges. And she won’t be returning.”

She walked away without looking back.

Chapter End Notes

If last scene was skipped:

The team leaves to go get drinks and Evanora Harkness is waiting outside to confront Agatha. She says terrible shit to Agatha and Rio comes out and slaps her. Rio clearly says more to Evanora, who leaves, then Rio tells Agatha that she is good, and walks off.

Anyway, hope y'all enjoyed. I'm really, really excited to write the next chapter. Come chat with me on twitter @Adimnoss

Chapter 21

Chapter Notes

OKAY LISTEN UP. THIS CHAPTER GOT TO SIXTEEN THOUSAND WORDS AND THAT WAS TOO MUCH. I HAD TO CUT IT IN HALF AGAIN AND RIO IS ONCE MORE NOT SUPER PRESENT IN THIS CHAPTER.

BUT BUT BUT, SHE WILL BE IN LITERALLY EVERY SCENE OF NEXT CHAPTER.

Also, that chapter will be out pretty soon since I already wrote a lot of it.

See the end of the chapter for more notes

In the aftermath of a terrible thing, a dreaded possibility, a worst case scenario, Agatha found herself suffocated in the kind of love she hadn’t allowed herself to feel for nearly six years.

”You are good, Agatha."

Rio’s words shredded through the vitriol of her mother’s with so much ease that she was reminded, once again, how deeply, how intimately, Rio knew her.

She stared after her, watched Rio’s rigid form stride toward the parking garage with her hands curled into fists. She wanted nothing more than to chase after her. She wanted to cling to the briefest taste of comfort and forget that her mother existed, forget that Rio’s touch was only ever fleeting because of what they had become.

She looked after her until Wanda stepped into her view, until her arms were wrapping so tightly around Agatha’s shoulders that she could hardly breathe.

The reality of what her entire team had witnessed, the awareness of being known, nearly brought her into a debilitating panic.

Jen’s voice rang out over their painful quiet of the team.

“Fuck, Agatha, your mother is a cunt.”

It was like a torrential wave crashing over a forest fire. It didn’t put it out, but it lessened the strength of it, the heat. Agatha let out a surprised laugh, an almost manic sound that rumbled through her chest even as she continued to cry.

Agatha wasn’t certain if there was a term for the raging complexities, the overload of emotions crashing through her, but she was certain she didn’t want it to occur in public.

Wanda seemed to be on the same wavelength. She eased back enough to wrap her arm around Agatha’s back before speaking to the team.

“Enjoy your night. We’ll see you tomorrow.”

She felt a hand touch hers, something hard being pressed into it as she was led away. She reached Wanda’s car, an unspoken decision to leave her own, and lifted it to reveal William’s bright pink vape.

A laugh left her again and she dragged herself into the car and closed the door.
_________

William stared at the beer in his hands. It had been placed there by Alice without a word, and none of the others had made any comment about his age or the legality of it. He’d been nursing it in case the action wasn’t repeated. Eddy was at home, ready with boxed wine and a new vape, because William had texted a quick, holy shit bad night talk later wine nic pls

William’s chest hadn’t stopped burning from the moment he’d seen that old, raggedy crone walking toward Agatha. He’d nearly committed a crime, Alice’s hand on his arm the only thing that kept him from clubbing the woman over the head with his backpack.

He was almost happy he couldn’t fully see Agatha’s face as her mother spewed some of the most bigoted, old-world garbage like it was truth and law and ‘shouldn’t Agatha just be so fucking ashamed.’

William had heard of his fair share of hatred, of phobia; Eddy had experienced it growing up, but he’d been lucky. His parents were supportive, almost annoyingly so, and he’d had the self-love and confidence to surround himself with like-minded individuals who loved him for his joy and kindness and weirdly specific interests.

It had given him a bit of a naivety that hadn’t been shrugged off until he’d heard Eddy’s stories. His dismissive approach to ‘if they don’t accept you, leave them’ had nearly been the end of their relationship and likely the biggest fight they’d had. Because how fortunate did one have to be to acquire such a mindset?

Now, seeing firsthand the hatred that Agatha had faced from her own mother, he felt the stirring of that guilt, the anger that the world wasn’t even close to the place he’d thought it was for his formative years.

“Will?”

William glanced up to find three of the women he’d found himself bewitched by now watching him in worry.

William blinked and leaned back.

“Sorry. I–” He shook his head. “Did I miss something?”

Alice smiled softly and tilted her head toward his beer.

“No, but you’ve decimated the paper around the bottle into scraps and you haven’t spoken in five whole minutes.”

William frowned.

The four of them had been nearly silent on the walk there.

Alice had been the first to head off after Agatha’s departure with Wanda and she’d pulled him along gently. Jen and Lilia had followed.

They ordered drinks, sat down, and the conversation had been stilted and strange and circular. Lilia had mentioned the stickiness of the scuffed, wooden bar and Jen had said they should have remodeled instead of purchasing one of those fancy pay-from-your-phone jukeboxes.

Alice had mentioned a few of the bars she would suggest for their next outing and William had left the conversing as he spiraled through wanting to text Agatha and trying not to be sad.

He dropped his chin into his hand and pushed around the pieces of thin paper he’d shredded off his beer.

“I feel bad we’ve been trying to figure out Agatha’s whole thing.”

Any lightness at the table sobered, sombered.

Alice put her arm around his shoulders.

“There was no malice there, kid.”

William shrugged.

“She was so private. We should have respected that.”

Lilia finished her drink, something dark with ice that slushed against the glass.

“This isn’t a good use of your empathy, William. Don’t beat yourself up, don’t get lost in coulda, shoulda, woulda.” She slammed her glass down. “Lets talk about unethical but legal ways to ruin that fucking bitch of a mother’s life.”

Jen lifted her wine.

“Here, here.”

William’s lips twitched into a smile as he took another sip of his beer.

“What would that even look like?”

Alice shrugged.

“Mildly unethical: interfering with employment, casual public disruptions, disruptive mail delivery, informal character assassination.” She raised her brow suggestively. “If we want to go to prison: fabricating evidence, entrapment, threats.”

Lilia chuckled.

“I don’t think we need to worry about it. It looked and sounded like the Director has something up her sleeve.”

William leaned in.

“You think? What if she just threatened her?”

Lilia shook her head.

“That’s not what that looked like to me. The bitch had committed to disrupting Agatha as much as possible. That was planned, likely a repeated action. Show up unannounced, deride, humiliate, put pressure on the wounds she likely created in Agatha herself. She’s done that before– I don’t want to think of how many times– and whatever the Director said to her was enough to break that momentum. If it had been as simple as a threat, I can’t imagine her mother would be affected. That would be ammunition in her pocket.” Lilia looked impressed. “She has something on her. Something good.”

William spun the bottom of his beer against the wooden table.

“It sucks to be helpless. I wish I had said something too. It’s not my place but I wish I had.”

Lilia smiled at him.

“You’ve done so much for Agatha, young man. Don’t for a second think that Wanda’s original placement of you in her office was not fully intentional. You were the only person Harkness could tolerate for the first several weeks.”

William’s brow furrowed.

“She didn’t even use my name until we were in Athens.”

Alice chuckled.

“Agatha is one of the smartest people in any room. You think she didn’t know who she could disrespect and to what level? She might not have said your name but she let you create a veritable forest on her side of the office. She let you sit in her safehouse and work with her. You think if Jen had shown up at her door she wouldn’t have lit her on fire?”

Jen’s mouth dropped open.

“Okay, rude.”

Lilia raised her brow.

“You would have deserved it. Nobody else sniped at her like you did.”

Jen’s face fell slightly.

“Yeah.” She shook her head, grimaced. “No, yeah, you’re right. Jesus, I really fucking put my foot in my mouth.”

Alice interrupted, arm slightly out to stem the conversation.

“Listen, my point is, Agatha liked you. She listened to you. The rest of us, no offense, had proved ourselves, our skills. Sure, Jen and her loathed one another, but Jen is the best at what she does. The same with the rest of us. Our competence earned us a general level of respect that included the use of our actual names and a willingness to accept our insight.” Alice gripped William’s shoulder. “You’re kind of hard to dislike, Will. Even for somebody who, apparently having every right to, did not like a lot of people.”

William blew out a breath.

“What are we supposed to do now? I just– she lost her son? How do you recover from that? And her wife? Who is now her boss? Every way I can think of to help her, I know she’ll hate.”

Alice gave a half-smile.

“You’ve done an excellent job meeting Agatha where she’s at. You had more patience than god in those early days.” She took a long drag of her beer. “You keep doing it. We all show her that nothing has changed. You continue to pester and annoy her.” She talked over his rebuttal. “Jen continues to be an asshole, just maybe without the digs into her past.” Alice shrugged. “This doesn’t change her status on our team or her place in our lives. We have to show her that.”

Lilia nodded and pointed at Alice.

“Exactly. If we try to pursue this or ask too many questions, she’s going to handle that very, very poorly.”

William chuckled slightly.

“Okay, yeah, an Agatha crashout seems like a catastrophic level of danger.” He finished his beer. “I guess this ends our background investigation.”

Jen looked around as Lilia and Alice nodded. She looked affronted.

“Background investigation? You mean all of you have been looking into this and I wasn’t privy!?”

Lilia patted her arm patronizingly.

“There, there, Kale. It wasn’t you, it was the fact that you would use it against Agatha the moment you knew something was going on.”

Jen’s eyes widened.

“That’s quite literally ‘me’.”

Alice nodded.

“Yeah but we can add you to the group chat now. Since it’s over. If that would make you feel better.”

Jen gripped the table.

“There was a group chat?!” She pointed at Lilia. “She was in a group chat!? She sent me a picture of her ankles because she was texting me while in the bathroom. She doesn’t know how to use her phone.”

Lilia looked mock outraged.

“Excuse you! Will has been helping me.” Her face shifted into a rather coy look. “Besides, we may not need to close down operations just yet. Just shift our focus.”

Alice frowned.

“Meaning?”

Lilia held out a hand.

“You’re telling me you didn’t see it?” She paused for emphasis and nobody said anything. She groaned. “Jesus. Let me spell it out, delicately due to the circumstances. Our Director and Agatha were literally married. I don’t think they ever stopped loving each other.”

William’s eyes widened comically as he stared at Lilia.

“I thought we had to treat her normally! You want to Parent Trap them?!”

Lilia waved him off.

“Don’t be stupid, Will. I think we bide our time, give this a chance to settle. Show support because Agatha deserves to have that. I love that woman even if being close to her is like touching barbed wire. Then we pick our moments.” She narrowed her eyes, hands pressing into the table. “Information access requests? The information we have access to is a bureaucratic nightmare and the Director is the one to give it. Maybe we request a threat assessment if we have a viable reason to search for a mole in the facility. We can offer our team up to give those trainings they’re always asking seasoned agents to give.”

Jen groaned.

“I hate those trainings.”

Lilia waved her off.

“Everyone does, Jen. Consider it payment for suggesting Agatha’s sabbatical was because she killed somebody.”

Jen leaned back, hands out.

“Okay, I’m feeling less included and more attacked.”

William felt his smile curl up his lips as the three women around him bickered. He knew even the fact that this conversation was happening would enrage Agatha, but the idea of doing something even if it was small and ultimately led to nothing, made him feel a little less helpless.
___________

Agatha stared at her hands as they drove. She could see them shaking despite the blasting heat from Wanda’s vehicle. The influx of emotions had reached a peak, had threatened tear through her, and now they had just… vanished.

She was frighteningly numb. It was different than the apathy from her years away. It was all pressure. Akin getting a cavity filled at the dentist. Unpleasant, like you thought at any moment the drill might hit too deeply.

The emotions weren’t truly gone. Instead it was wolves waiting behind a closed door, so patient, so knowing. And eventually, soon, she’d have to reopen that door.

Agatha’s eyes hurt but they were dry, and she finally looked up when the vehicle slowed to a stop.

She saw they were in the near-empty parking lot of a gym. It was almost entirely dark besides a single light deep inside, the sign showing closed, but Wanda got out of the car confidently.
