I also want access to your employee files to see if there are any strange connections or patterns.”

Patrick dropped back in his chair, and Agatha wanted to laugh at the fact that Rio had made him change levels three separate times since entering the room.

He shook his head.

“This is ridiculous. You need a warrant for all of this!”

Rio nodded.

“That’s fine. We can sit here and wait until we get that squared away. This is a case of high-priority. I’m sure it’ll come through within a few hours.”

Patrick’s hand shook as he reached for his phone.

“My assistant can take you to the Disposal Officer on shift. I’ll put together the documents you requested.”

Rio smiled.

“I’ll wait right here with you.” She glanced at Agatha, eyes sparkling. “You good with the Disposal Officer?”

Agatha nodded and tried not to linger on the confidence– bordering on cockiness– in Rio’s eyes.

She stepped from the room and followed the assistant as he guided her into the elevator.
_____

Agatha took a slow breath as they exited the facility together. They’d applied the necessary pressure, most of that pressure coming from Rio, and were currently walking to her car with two boxes filled with employee files and a flash drive.

“I think William would have learned a lot more coming here to experience you dismantling Mr. Graves.”

Rio popped the trunk and they slid the items inside. She lifted a brow.

“You’re saying you didn’t learn anything?”

Agatha scoffed, her stomach buzzing again. It felt like they were in a strange limbo; they could engage more than before, talk to one another without it leading to bloodshed, but there was still this lingering chasm of unspoken words sitting between them.

She climbed into the passenger seat, veering away from Rio’s question.

“The Disposal Officer was defensive but I don’t think she was hiding anything. There were no last-minute changes to the route and no unauthorized logins to the shipment database. She may have motive if we find out she’s in any kind of financial trouble, but I think we turn our attention elsewhere.”

Rio nodded, backing out of the parking spot.

“I spoke with the head of security after I got what I needed from Graves. Gillian Rourke. She gave me the list of employees that would have had access to the shipment database and the pre-planned route. Nobody accessed the disposal records outside of normal hours and there were no glaring security breaches leading up to this attack.” Rio frowned. “There has to be something in here. There’s no way this was pulled off without somebody in that building lending a helping hand.”

Agatha was inclined to agree.

“Any chance it could have been Graves?”

Rio shook her head.

“No, Graves is a snake but he has no venom.”

“What happened last time that he didn’t want you to bring up?”

Rio chuckled, her lips curling like the memory was easy to recall.

“He was trying to protect his boss at the time, I think. He said something along the lines of–” Rio’s voice deepened, taking on a shockingly accurate cadence. “‘If one cannot take risks, one cannot make breakthroughs. Society has chosen to demonize progress.’ I’ll never forget his face when we showed up at his home with a warrant and a tactical team. We searched and found nothing incriminating, but he had a pretty interesting set-up at his bedside.

“I was the first in the room and he must have been in the middle of using it because it had…” Rio winced. “fluids. But it was one of those sex machines? He kept calling it his ‘thruster’ like he might desensitize it for the eight people forced to lay eyes on it.”

Agatha snorted.

“Oh my god. I wish you had mentioned it in his office. I have so many questions.”

Rio grinned.

“You would have made him cry. He would have refused to help us.”

Agatha waved her hand dismissively.

“Some things are more important than locating stolen radioactive material that could level DC.”

“I’ll have Wanda make a note of that in your employee file.” Rio’s smile steadied, her mind returning to the case as she exited the highway. “When I pushed Graves for their lack of a thorough check on their anonymous donor, he said that the facility was in bad shape and they were considering closing the doors. He accepted the money because they needed it and didn’t ask questions because he had no other option.”

Agatha scoffed.

“Sounds like they should have just taken the loss. This is going to get out. Any remaining trust and funding will get pulled when the public discovers that the institute's negligence put their lives at risk.”

Rio nodded.

“I’m hoping we close this out before the public gets word.”
_____

Agatha stared at the screens currently playing four separate news channels as they returned to the room. Will and Wanda were the only ones back.

Headlines like, Truck Carrying Cesium-137 Hijacked; One Driver Dead, One Missing, Hazardous Materials Shipment Hijacked: Authorities Seek Missing Driver, Authorities Searching for Stolen Radioactive Material After Highway Attack.

None of it was great, all of it would spark panic.

But the worst was on the fourth screen.

Experts Weigh In: How Dangerous Is the Stolen Cesium-137?

“We turn now to Dr. Halperin, a nuclear security analyst, for insight.”

“‘Cesium-137 is an incredibly dangerous isotope. In the wrong hands, just a few grams could be used to contaminate an entire city block or even disrupt critical infrastructure. If dispersed into the water supply, it could cause long-term radiation poisoning with effects lasting for generations."

Rio’s expression shuttered, her eyes narrowing. She looked at Wanda.

“Get me our press liaisons. I want a team working on getting this misinformation corrected as soon as possible.”

She stepped away and put her phone to her ear as Wanda did the same.

Agatha walked to Will. He looked scared, his eyes staring at the screen as the so-called-expert prattled on, and Agatha stepped forward and muted it.

“What’s being reported isn’t accurate. It’s an attention-grab at best, fear-mongering at worst. It’ll get straightened out.”

Will nodded, his hands fiddling with the edge of the table.

“I know. But my parents called and they’re scared. Wanda said I couldn’t tell them anything.”

Agatha nodded.

“The risk posed by you giving your family information they aren’t privy to can cause panic. It could compromise the case or be an abuse of power. Not to mention that your career would be over before it began.” Agatha sat beside him. “This is one of the ethical challenges that comes from our job. But, I can tell you this: out of one every hundred cases like this, ninety-five are solved without issue. This is why we try to keep it out of the public eye.”

William settled in his seat, his face taking on a serious lilt as he refocused.

“Did you guys find anything at the institute?”

Agatha shook her head.

“Nothing substantial. Not yet. But we have a lot to get through. What about the crime scene?”

Will turned his computer toward her.

“It was a professional hit. Well-planned. The attack happened on a remote stretch of the route, a single-lane road cutting through several farms. There were spike strips thrown across right before the truck passed. It looks like five to six individuals moved in from the fields on either side. No cameras, no eye-witnesses. The casings at the scene were from a nine millimeter and a .38 special. Wanda thinks that the attackers never intended to fire. That the driver shot first and they ended up killing him. They moved quickly and their getaway vehicle was equipped to handle such sensitive materials.”

Agatha tapped her fingers, eyes on the bloodstained pavement on William’s screen.

“If they weren’t going to kill anyone, they may have been trying to keep this low profile.”

“Why?”

Agatha shrugged.

“Many possibilities. Could’ve been that they weren’t aware how much cesium was in the truck. Or they did and they still thought it wouldn’t bring attention immediately.” Agatha puckered her lips. “It’s also possible that whomever is pulling these strings is an extremist. They might have a specific target and they protect life in certain contexts when they aren’t a part of the greater picture.”

William’s cheeks puffed out.

“This job is insane.”

Agatha clapped his shoulder.

“Can’t argue there.” She stood, nodding toward the boxes they’d brought back from the institute. “Come on. We might as well be useful until we get our next marching orders.”
____

A man sat primly in front of the seal, his face trustworthy and open, his voice smooth and admonishing.

“It was in poor taste for Dr. Halperin to share sensationalized misinformation with a clear expertise. Many of his claims were exaggerated, misleading, or speculative. Some were simply untrue. Cesium-137 is dangerous in large quantities but the amount acquired is not capable of leveling a city. It will not pollute the water supply nor cause lasting effects for generations. Cesium-137 is water soluble and would dilute rapidly before it became highly dangerous. As for the high demand on the black market–”

Agatha watched the liaison as activity swarmed around where she and William sat looking through the employee files.

Rio was speaking closely with a very familiar blonde and Agatha felt a flash of embarrassment slip through her as she remembered the rather dramatic encounter on the trail. She kept her head down in an effort to stay out of sight.

William set another file aside.

“Why is this information not digital?”

Agatha opened a new employee file.

“It is. But some of these are from older employees who left before the files left paper. They weren’t entered into the system. We asked for everything in case a previous employee sticks out.”

Jennifer and Alice moved through the crowded operations room and settled across from them.

Jennifer grimaced.

“I prefer when our space is our space. Why can’t they film the rebuttals in the media room?”

Agatha smirked.

“They heard about your pathological need for attention and wanted to oblige you. I think they’re waiting for you on camera two.”

Kale rolled her eyes.

Alice diverted the conversation.

“Anyway. Kerem was pretty resistant to conversation. But it didn’t seem to stem from guilt. We were able to get him to answer our questions after talking in circles for thirty minutes.” She pulled a baggie from her coat and set it on the table. A phone sat inside. “I’m taking it to tech, but Kerem says that he received a voicemail from Melik two days before the transport. Melik said he felt uneasy; that somebody had reached out to him about the shipment. We’re tracking the number now but I imagine it’ll come from a burner.” She sat down. “Anyone get anything useful?”

A series of head shakes followed and Agatha frowned.

“Anyone heard from Calderu?”

William nodded.

“She spoke with Wanda about an hour ago. She said she thinks there’s something there. The wife is nervous. She got spooked when one of her kids said something about ‘daddy talking to work friends a lot.’”

Agatha picked up half of their stack and set it in front of Jennifer and Alice.

“Might as well–”

Wanda’s phone rang and she answered.

“Calderu.” She put the phone on the table. “You’re on speaker.”

”I do love an audience.” The sounds of traffic could be heard in the background. “The mother finally broke. She said that Lenny had gotten pretty stressed about work. He’d gotten cagey about his calls. She said she’d noticed he had a secondary phone he kept in his car. She’d thought he was cheating and confronted him. He told her that he couldn’t tell her what was going on to keep her safe. That he loved her and the kids. That he’d tell her once everything was over.”

Wanda frowned.

“So we’re looking at coercion.”

Alice tilted her head.

“Or he’s on the take.”

”I don’t think he’s doing it because he wants to. Just a gut feeling, but that’s a pretty well-adjusted family. It’s obviously possible, but I’d be surprised.”

Wanda nodded.

“I’m inclined to agree. This is a waiting game. We need phone records and any possible hits on the tire prints left on the scene. Lilia, come back to the office. We’ll work the leads we can until something breaks.”
____

Alice sat up straighter in her seat, lifting the file from her table.

“Did the institute director mention anything about a Dr. Russell Adkins?”

Agatha shook her head.

“Rio didn’t mention him.”

She ignored the looks at the use of Rio’s first name, saved her internal chastisement for later.

Alice turned the folder.

“Six years ago. Russell Adkins was a prominent member of the RRIM. He was an up-and-coming oncologist at a private hospital in Manchester, England. He accepted a position and moved within a month. It looks like his career was short-lived. But he made quite a stir while he was there. There are dozens of claims he made about the unethical manner with which their medical trials were conducted. He apparently got rather fanatical and sabotaged one of the trials.”

Agatha pulled the file toward herself.

“Dr. Russell Adkins contaminated the blood samples with dangerous amounts of Cesium-137, putting the entire laboratory in grave danger. The other doctor spearheading the trial was Patrick Graves.” She flipped the page and let out a whistle. “Adkins claimed he was in a sexual relationship with Graves and was insistent that Graves agreed with the ‘statement’ he was making.”

Agatha sat back, eyes immediately searching for Rio. She’d been in and out of the room for the past three hours, most of it spent on the phone or directing the media team. She looked back down at the file.

“If this is some kind of revenge, if Adkins is involved, he could be targeting Graves specifically if he feels betrayed.”

William made a startled sound, his eyes glued to his computer.

“Dr. Patrick Graves, Director of the RRIM, is speaking at a conference tomorrow in Virginia.” He read from the screen. “Restoring Trust: Ethical Trials and the Rebirth of Medical Integrity.”

The shift at the table was severe. Lilia leaned in.

“How large is this conference?”

William searched, his face blanching.

“It’s a national conference. There’s an expected attendance of twelve-thousand doctors from around the US. Some are traveling from overseas to attend.”

Wanda stood.

“I’ll update Director Vidal. We’ll pass this off to the overnight team. Go home, get some rest. Hopefully we can shut down this conference or at least delay it.”
_____

Agatha couldn’t sleep. The moment she’d left the WFO she felt herself split, part of her mind still stuck on the case, the other veering sharply to Rio; to their conversation, to the way it had felt to hold her again. She knew she shouldn’t reach out. The space was likely good: they needed to stay focused. They both needed rest. They both needed time to think and process their sudden reconnection.

It didn’t mean that laying in the bedroom of the guesthouse, alone, felt anything but terrible. The sheets were cold, the bed somehow felt less comfortable than Rio’s couch, and she was sinking into a strange, potent discontent that she hadn’t felt in years. Her grief had been so loud that it had drowned out the quieter emotions like loneliness and hope.

Agatha groaned and turned, twisting the sheets between her legs. She gave up after two hours of attempts and walked back down to the living room. She let Señor Scratchy from his cage and sat on the ground as he darted around her for the next several minutes. He’d just settled, his soft, furry head nudging into her hand, when there was a knock on the door.

Agatha glanced at the clock. 1:34 AM. It might be Wanda. She could likely see the lights of the guesthouse from her bedroom.

Agatha picked up Scratchy and pulled her silk robe tighter as she walked to the door. She tugged it open and stilled.

Rio was still in her suit but she looked exhausted. Her hair was loose, brushing her jaw and shoulders as she rocked. She looked uncertain but determined.

“I know I shouldn’t be here but I wanted to answer your question. From earlier.”

Agatha’s heart rate spiked, her lungs tightening in her chest.

Rio forged on.

“You asked me if–” Her eyes fell to the rabbit in Agatha’s hands and she gaped. “What– you have a rabbit?”

Agatha felt like pulling out her hair. She stepped aside and motioned Rio in.

“Can we just focus on one thing at a time? You had something to say?”

Rio stepped inside, eyes still on Señor Scratchy as he began wriggling in Agatha’s arm. She looked overwhelmed, her chest rising sharply.

“It looks just like him.”

Agatha forcibly set her desperation to hear Rio’s answer aside. She leaned down and let Scratchy onto the floor. He darted toward the kitchen, a flash of fur, and Agatha turned to Rio.

Rio looked stricken and Agatha stepped closer, her hand linking with Rio’s.

“If we sit down, he’ll come back. He’s a menace but he’s a lover too. Billy trained him to cuddle.”

Rio followed Agatha to the floor, both of them crossing their legs and staring toward the kitchen.

“Trained?”

Agatha chuckled.

“Vision told me that while I was in Greece, anytime Scratchy sat with him for more than two seconds he was awarded a treat.” She rolled her eyes. “I had to put him on a diet when I got back.”

Agatha watched as Señor Scratchy blitzed back into the room, his hind legs kicking up behind him. As soon as he saw them on the floor, he slowed.

Rio’s voice was strained when she spoke beside her.

“Agatha.”

Agatha looked over, saw tears in Rio’s eyes, and squeezed Rio’s hand tightly.

“I know. I saw him in those first few weeks I was here. I got him on a whim and I genuinely thought I might be crazy the next day when he got lost in the safe house.” Scratchy nudged at her hand and she scratched softly behind his ears. “I’m glad I got him though. Sometimes it felt like he was all I had.”

Scratchy’s nose twitched as he neared Rio, his ears shifting, and then he hopped into her lap.

Rio’s free hand shook slightly as she ran her fingers down the fur on his back. She took a deep breath.

“He’s really soft.”

Agatha released Rio’s hand so she could hold him properly.

“I know. Don’t you just feel terrible for suggesting you could ever curb stomp a bunny?”

Rio’s watery laugh burst out, startling Scratchy into another bout of zoomies that sent him careening around the couch. She laughed harder, and Agatha joined her.

Rio wiped at her eyes and sniffed.

“That was so mean. I was saying the bunny would be a terrible sidekick.”

Agatha leaned against the back of the couch, her body suddenly tired.

“Why did you really come here, Rio?”

It was said softly, hopefully, and Agatha couldn’t find it in herself to be chagrined.

Rio’s hands folded in her lap, her shoulders drooping slightly.

“I thought about going home. I should have. I know we have to be intentional here. But I couldn’t.”

Agatha drew in a breath, her eyes tracking the flex of Rio’s forearms as she clenched her hands.

“Why?”

Rio met her gaze, her lips pulling up in a sad smile.

“I’ve had to sleep alone for five years. Why would I do that again if there was a chance–” She hesitated. “If there was a chance I didn’t have to.”

Agatha pushed herself to her feet, her body flooded with feeling, her throat tight. Rio looked up, surprised, and Agatha held out her hand.

“Come on. It’s past two in the morning and we have to be at work in five hours.” She pulled Rio to her feet. “I don’t know if there’s extra toothbrushes here, but I have mouthwash.”

She started walking toward the stairs, Rio in tow, and felt a slight resistance. Looking back, she saw Rio’s eyes already on the stairs, her need heavy in her eyes.

Rio searched her expression.

“Are you sure? I don’t want to take away your space, Agatha. I know this wasn’t… the most orthodox move on my part.”

Agatha chuckled and tugged again.

“When have we ever, in our lives, gone about things the most orthodox way?”

Rio’s cheeks reddened and Agatha adored her.

“Okay.”

Agatha pulled her to the stairs and stopped.

“I have to put Scratchy away or he’ll eat the furniture. You can take anything you need from the closet.”
___

By the time Agatha reached her room, Rio was sitting on the edge of the bed in borrowed shorts and socks. She’d taken one of Agatha’s long-sleeved shirts and it sat loose on her frame.

The sight of her, waiting for Agatha, dressed in sleep clothes and near exhaustion, brought back an aching nostalgia. They’d done this a thousand times.

Agatha brushed her teeth, set her robe on its hook, and pulled the covers down.

“Let’s not overthink it now, okay?”

Rio nodded and folded into the bed as Agatha did the same.

Agatha reached over and flicked off the lamp as Rio’s hands reached for her. She curled into Rio’s chest and pressed her face against Rio’s throat with a sigh.

She was on the verge of sleep, her mind fading in and out, when Rio whispered next to her.

“Agatha?”

“Hmm?”

Rio’s arms tightened.

“You asked if there was a path forward. For us.”

Agatha nodded and Rio continued.

“That’s the only path I see.”

Chapter End Notes

With how long this case took, we might extend to 30 chapters. I don't know why I ever give myself a structure to follow because I immediately break it.

Chapter 26

Chapter Notes

*broadcast voice** We'll be back to the regularly scheduled reconnection + filthy smut after these necessary plot points.

I have also posted chapter 2 of my new story if you would like to get a dose of flirting and a much less traumatized version of agathario.

Twitter & Bluesky: @Adimnoss

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Agatha woke to the blaring of two alarms, a groan leaving her as she shifted. Soft hair, softer than hers, slid against her cheek and she blinked into the dim light of predawn.

Rio’s lips twisted in a grimace when the alarm didn’t immediately stop and she turned further into Agatha, her hand sliding around her back, her fingers pressing against Agatha’s skin where her shirt had risen up.

Her forehead pressed into Agatha’s shoulder as she pulled herself closer.

Agatha’s whole body buzzed, her heartbeat stuttering at the slide of warmth on her spine and Rio’s breath hot against her shirt.

She took note of her own limbs, finding one of her arms under Rio’s neck and one of her legs tangled up with Rio’s.

She felt the draw of sleep, the pull to find both of their phones and throw them toward the stairs in hopes they both fell far enough to go unheard.

Rio sighed and Agatha knew that wasn’t going to be an option.

Both of them twisted apart to silence their phones, their bodies sliding from one another, and Agatha turned off her alarm. They had twenty minutes before it was imperative that they start moving.

Rio settled back against the pillow, her eyes on the exposed ceiling, the stained beams, and the fan.

Her face was puffy, her eyes squinted from lack of sleep. Agatha was certain she’d never seen someone more beautiful.

Her breath felt constrained as she reached over, her fingers sliding through the hair that was pressed to Rio’s forehead.

Rio’s eyes closed, her mouth parting slightly as she let out an unsteady breath.

Neither said anything at the touch but Rio didn’t stop her.

Agatha ran her thumb over Rio’s brow and Rio’s eyes opened again.

She didn’t look over.

“I remember staring at this ceiling for hours when I stayed here. It had been over a year since you’d left and I just–” She frowned. “I was so sure that the hurt of everything would fade over time. I thought I’d be able to handle the memories if they weren’t so fucking painful. I wasn’t doing well and Wanda asked me to move in so that I could help with the boys.” She chuckled. “She didn’t need my help. But she knew how to twist my arm.”

Agatha let her hand fall to Rio’s chest and rest there.

“Wanda is very persuasive. I’m pretty sure she lied to me when I had to move out of the safehouse to get me to come here.”

Rio’s lips curled up in amusement.

“Oh, she did. I’d already placed that visiting team in a much closer safehouse.”

Agatha rolled her eyes.

“Bitch.”

Rio grinned further, her eyes finally falling from the ceiling to meet Agatha’s.

“She hadn’t been allowed to look out for you for so long. I think she was willing to kidnap you here if you didn’t come willingly.”

Agatha let herself hold Rio’s eyes, let herself get lost in the rich brown.

“I don’t think that would have gone very well for her.”

Rio shrugged.

“She’s pretty good at getting what she wants.” She motioned lazily toward the room. “It seems like it was probably the right call.”

Agatha sighed.

“It definitely stripped away some of my stress; allowed me to focus on other things.” She looked away. “I’m sorry for taking this away from you; Wanda, Vision, the boys. I didn’t know–”

Rio frowned.

“You needed them, Agatha.”

“So did you.”

Rio blew out a breath.

“I’ve had them. I wouldn’t say I was ever… happy, but I got myself to a place of general content over the past few years. Taking a step back so that you could receive the support you kept refusing was not the sacrifice you seem to think it was. I was happy to do it. I was hopeful.”

Agatha swallowed the sudden tightness in her throat.

“I didn’t make it easy for anyone.”

Rio scoffed, but it held nothing but gentle amusement and mild exasperation.

“Agatha, you’ve never made anything easy. It’s part of your charm.”

Agatha huffed, prepared to disparage herself, and frowned when she heard the door open below.

Wanda’s voice rang out up the stairs.

“I don’t need answers, I just need to make sure you both make it to work on time.”

Rio pressed her hands over her face and let out a groan.

“I’m her boss, I can’t believe she’s making sure I get to work.”

Agatha felt the flutter of nerves, the disappointment that she’d have to leave this space and return to a world that had very little care for whether she and Rio figured this out. She drew her hand from Rio’s chest and forced herself out of bed, her heart aching as she moved away. She swallowed and began the transition from woman to agent. It was harder this time and she stepped into her closet in an effort to take some space from Rio’s perceiving eyes.

She pulled on dark gray slacks and a tan turtleneck with black paneling, her movements purposefully slow to give herself more time. She partially hoped that Rio would have already headed down to Wanda when she turned toward the door.

Rio was standing there, her go-bag standard suit already donned, and her arms crossed over her chest. She was looking at Agatha like she knew, and Agatha felt tears press against her eyes.

Agatha let out a tired breath.

“Do you remember what you used to say? Anytime we had to wake up at an ungodly hour or had to pay double for a midnight babysitter?”

Rio’s posture was soft as she smiled.

“If I was in charge I’d banish early and late call-ins because they were heinous and unforgivable.” She tilted her head back and forth. “I’ve been corrupted by fidelity.”

Agatha chuckled.

“I knew you’d turn traitor. Power always went to your head.”

Rio’s eyes narrowed, her arms falling to her side as the conversation turned clearly away from work.

“It was never the power.”

Agatha barely heard her. She stared at the top buttons of Rio’s shirt and felt her stomach flip, her fingers curling into her palms as she stared. Her voice wavered.

“No?” She fought the urge to step closer. “What was it?”

It was absurd that the temperature in the room had sparked from just a few volleyed comments.

Rio’s chest rose and fell sharply.

“It was your response.” She looked on the edge of reaching out, her eyes dark. “You’ve always had an interesting relationship with power.”

Agatha felt herself move closer, her bare feet against the cool floor. She felt as if she were in a trance, her eyes locked on Rio’s collar. She drew to a stop a few inches away.

“I’m not sure I know what you mean.”

Rio’s fingers reached out and curled into the waistband of Agatha’s slacks. Her expression hardened, a taste of confidence appearing, and Agatha’s stomach swooped. She felt her cheeks warm.

Rio lifted a brow.

“Oh?”

Agatha’s eyes slid from Rio’s collar to throat, to the muscle in her jaw, to her eyes, then back to the collar. She finally let herself reach. Her fingers caught the top button and she released it. Then the second. As she moved to the third, Rio’s fingers circled her wrist and it was so reminiscent of a better time that Agatha couldn’t breathe.

She wasn’t upset when Wanda’s interruption followed.

“There’s coffee!”

Rio’s expression released as she stepped back.

“I think we’re in trouble.”

Agatha stared after Rio as she retreated toward the steps, her shirt remaining unbuttoned, her dress shoes scooped from the floor to be carried down.

Agatha pressed both of her palms over her face and took deep breaths until she could pull herself together.

She put on her socks and shoes and followed the sounds of quiet conversation to the kitchen.

Wanda was in a navy suit and a white button-up. She had a coffee to her lips and her eyes danced as Agatha stepped into the room.

Rio was half-inside the freezer with a scowl on her face.

“What have you been eating?”

Agatha’s hackles raised slightly. She felt vulnerable with both Wanda and Rio in her space; the two people could read her, who saw through her. She felt unstable and she had to bite back her first response.

“Sawdust. Dried leaves. Leftover frosting from the twins’ last birthday.”

Rio snorted and closed the freezer, her questions ceasing like she remembered Agatha’s tells, like she still knew when to back off of a topic.

Wanda reached back and held out a coffee toward Agatha. She seemed inclined to stir the pot, her eyes filled with delight.

“Sorry to interrupt the morning meeting. Did the team miss the memo?”

Agatha let the coffee warm her hands.

“I think we could definitely set up shop in your guest house. You might need to boost your WiFi but there’s enough room for the team if Jen agrees to work in the cellar.”

Wanda grinned from where she leaned on the counter. She let her eyes flick between them.

“Both Billy and Tommy saw Auntie Rio’s car and had an unlimited amount of questions. From whether the guest house had two bedrooms all the way to begging to come visit you this morning instead of going to preschool.”

Rio took it in stride, as if this didn’t feel like an alternative reality, as if this wasn’t throwing her through loops and spirals and leaving her reeling.

“I can come say hi if they haven’t left yet.”

Wanda huffed.

“I sent them off with Vis to get breakfast beforehand. I wasn’t sure what I was walking into.”

Agatha cleared her throat.

“Any updates from the overnight team?”

Wanda raised a brow but allowed the subject change.

“The event is privately funded which has made their efforts rather fruitless. Bridgepoint Advanced Research and Zenith Foundation representatives resisted the need for a delay or cancellation of the event.”

Rio found a yogurt stuffed in the back of the fridge and grimaced as she looked at the expiration date. She tossed it in the trash and looked toward Wanda.

“How are their reputations? Any red flags?”

Wanda shook her head.

“It seems like a plethora of the usual reasons: investor and donor safety, fear of political fallout, state-backed pressure, international legal barriers. They’re Switzerland and Singapore based companies and the amount of roadblocks in place will push this situation to the wire if we can’t at least get boots on-site.”

Rio’s demeanor shifted, her brow furrowing as she pulled out her phone.

“Get me their representatives. I’ll make the call.”

Wanda nodded.

Agatha felt the reprieve of the switch into work-mode and she pulled open a cabinet to retrieve a bright blue box. She took the last crinkling, silver package and held it toward Rio.

Rio’s eyes widened, an innocent excitement flashing through her that crushed Agatha’s lungs. She took the pop tart from Agatha’s fingers.

“Oh my god I haven’t had one of these in years.” She stripped the thin package open. “Holy shit.”

Agatha stared at Rio, and she wanted nothing more in this moment than to be just a normal person; to have a nine-to-five that she was allowed to play hooky. All so that she could spend more time with this ridiculous woman who managed a position of serious power but still got excited by the sight of a processed rectangle of sugar.

For years, having any kind of honest conversation with herself or anyone else had been her greatest terror. Now that she’d taken that first step, now that she could taste a future that didn’t hurt quite so terribly, she wanted to be consumed by it.

Wanda walked toward the door, her hand squeezing Agatha’s shoulder.

“I’ll see you both at the office.”

Rio mumbled a goodbye, her mouth stuffed with chocolate pop tart, and Agatha stared at her and cried.

Rio’s eyes shot wide, two steps taking her within range of Agatha. She looked ridiculous as she tried to swallow the dry pastry with a deeply concerned look on her face.

Agatha shook her head, wiping and laughing tiredly.

“I’m fine, I promise.” She laughed again and sniffed. “Jesus Christ. You look stupid eating that.”

Rio coughed, her face grimacing in discomfort, before she was able to clear her throat.

“I forgot how much they stick to your mouth.”

Agatha rolled her eyes.

“I’m sure it won’t stop you from eating it.”

Rio feigned offense.

“Of course not. Am I supposed to starve? What are you eating?” She reached for the uneaten half. “Here.”

Agatha shook her head, lips twisted.

“I’d actually rather eat the sawdust.” She finished her coffee and set the mug in the sink. “We should go.”

Rio touched her side, her fingers splaying on Agatha’s ribcage.

“Agatha.” She waited until Agatha looked. “I know how you’re feeling right now. Once this case has been handled, we’ll be able to have a semblance of a life and you and I will talk without interruption.”

Agatha leaned into the warmth of Rio’s hand, her chest rising and falling in a sharp sigh. The distinct one-eighty, the sudden urge to let all of her thoughts, scrambled and unintelligible, spill from her mouth, had Agatha on edge. She swallowed her heart and nodded.

“I know we will.”

A pressing, chafing thought; the fear that Rio would change her mind or remember how fucking hard Agatha had made her life, had poisoned Agatha’s mind.

But, they had a job to do. Agatha let her fear settle deep into the recesses of her mind as she turned to the door.
______

Agatha tried not to stare as Rio paced the operations room like she was the harbinger of a coming storm.

Will was on her left, Alice was on her right, and Jen and Lilia were unashamedly turned around in their seats to watch the absolute dressing down Rio was giving to some representative from Zenith.

Rio’s jaw stood out prominently as she listened to the other end. Her voice was smooth iron and her words licked across Agatha’s skin.

“The danger posed to everyone attending this conference and the surrounding public should be your first priority. If I am forced to relay, once more, why I need my agents on-site and looped in with your private security, you will have the IRS, the Treasury Department, and the FTC, barking at your heels for what remains of your organization’s lifespan.”

There was a pause as Rio listened to the response. Her answer was just as icy as before but her posture settled slightly.

“Thank you for your time, Lucien. We’ll have a team on the ground in thirty minutes. I expect that your private security will defer to my agents.”

She hung up before a response could come through and Jen whistled.

“Wow, that’s terrifying. And kind of ho—.”

Lilia slapped Jen’s shoulder.

“Have an ounce of decorum.”

Jen shrugged, her attention returning to the files.

“They couldn’t get ahold of Graves?”

William shook his head.

“He’s turned off his phone. We found it at his house. His financial records show he’s at the hotel where the conference is being held but we’re still waiting on the warrant to access his room number.”

Rio walked toward them with Wanda on her heels.

“We have the green light to flood agents into the hotel and conference center. It’s likely Adkins and whomever is working for him has set up somewhere in the hotel. I want your team on it. I’ll be coordinating from site and working on access.”

Alice nodded.

“They won’t cancel?”

Rio shook her head.

“They don’t believe the threat is credible and we don’t have anything substantial beyond a very probable theory. Adkins is still in Maryland and he’s been a vocal member of a number of radical environmental groups. He’s spoken against the RRIM multiple times and has likely been a huge thorn in their side. We don’t know why it’s escalated to this level, but when all signs point north…”

Wanda finished.

“You go north.” She nodded to the team. “Gear up. I want full tactical gear and full face respirators.”

Agatha frowned.

“No PPE?”

Wanda’s jaw clenched.

“No. They’re worried it’ll cause a panic if we show up in radiation suits.” William looked truly terrified as Wanda continued. “We’ll be wearing lead-lined vests and gloves. We’ll have suits and a decontamination zone on site. The moment we get the go-ahead, we’ll evacuate the site. Until then, stay cautious and don’t do anything stupid. If you get eyes on Adkins or the missing cesium, do not engage until I give the go-ahead.”

The team nodded as they stood, William following suit, and Agatha raised a brow.

“You are off-site for this one, Will.”

William looked conflicted, his fear as present as his determination.

“I can help.”

Agatha nodded. It wasn’t her place to make the call but she was making it.

“I know. From here. Dig further into Adkins. See if you can find any record of connection with Director Graves in the past year.”

William glanced toward Wanda and only nodded when the directions weren’t countered. He turned to their shared office and Agatha followed.

She closed the door as the rest of the team geared up.

“You will be helpful here.”

He sat at his desk and chewed his lip, his brow furrowed, his eyes distant.

“I know, I just— I know you want me here because you think I’ll freeze or fuck up.”

Agatha nodded. There was no sugar coating this part of the job. He’d have to adapt or find a new career.

“This is new to you. You have not been trained for the pressure and the fear that comes with a situation that puts your life on the line. Your team comes first. Always. If you are a threat to that team, you swallow your pride and do what you can.” She heard the irony and attempted to lighten the mood. “Or you throw your boss into a door.” She aimed her thumb toward the operations room. “Want me to send in Agent Maximoff?”

William rolled his eyes, his lips turning up.

“I’ll dive into Adkins and relay what I find.”
_______

Agatha was sweating. The heavy weight of the vest on her shoulders and the suffocating gloves on her hands had her pulling at her collar for some air.

The team seemed to be fairing similarly; beads of sweat sat on their temples and their cheeks were all flushed.

They’d set up in a conference room on the first floor of the hotel, the entire hallway blocked off by “reserved” signs.

Wanda had a blueprint of the hotel on the widescreen at the head of the room.

“We are running through the floors from penthouse to basement with Geiger counters until we have warrants for a more thorough search. We believe they’ll be situated in a room instead of an employee space or storage area.”

Alice pointed toward the bottom corner of the map.

“The lower levels would have less foot traffic and it looks like they travel through to the conference center.”

Wanda nodded.

“They may use the lower levels as a route, but they aren’t temperature controlled. Cesium 137 needs to be at room temperature to remain chemically stable.”

Agatha stared at the twenty floors they’d be attempting to clear in the next two hours. The conference would begin at ten and guests would begin to pour in en masse in about thirty minutes.

“They won’t want to be in the same room as the material. It’s likely we’re looking at a string of rooms that have their do not disturb signs up.”

Wanda confirmed.

“If you encounter anything suspicious or your detectors alert, fall back and wait for orders. Kale, Harkness, I want you starting at the penthouse level. Calderu, Gulliver, you’re on ten coming down. I’ll be relaying all information to and from Director Vidal and our other agents on-site.”

Agatha huffed.

“I thought my only concern would be radiation exposure. Not Kale’s sights on my neck.”

Jennifer scoffed.

“Please, if anyone would take a pot shot, it would be you.”

Agatha grinned sharply and stood.

“You’re right. You take lead. I’ll watch your back.”

Jennifer rolled her eyes as the team moved out.
———

Moving through the halls was a slow process, the lack of credible intel meaning that every room could be a plausible threat. Kale had the Geiger counter on her hip, her jacket covering the bulk of the vest and the harness where her issued piece sat.

They’d cleared three floors without any radiation alert and Agatha felt the impending catastrophe they were attempting to curtail heavy on her spine.

She made a vaguely robotic beeping sound and saw Kale freeze in front of her and quickly relax.

“God dammit, Harkness.”

Agatha grinned.

“Just keeping you on your toes, Kale.”

Jennifer slowed and fell into step with Agatha.

“It feels like we’re wasting time.”

On that, Agatha could agree.

“You could start screaming on every floor. See if it draws anyone out.”

“Right, let’s announce ourselves to make easier targets.”

Agatha lifted a shoulder.

“Oh I’d be tucked away somewhere. Only you would be a target.”

“I miss when you were hospitalized in Greece.”

Agatha chuckled.

“I bet. It must suck riding my coattails all the time.”

Wanda’s voice came over the comms.

”Let’s aim for professional, agents.”

On cue, both spoke the same line.

“She started it.”

“She started it.”

Agatha’s smile matched Kale’s as they took the stairs to the eighteenth floor.

They’d just pushed through into the hallway when the Geiger counter spiked, the sound sending ice through Agatha’s spine.

She stilled, Kale matching her, and spoke quietly.

“Floor Eighteen. We have activity.”

Wanda’s voice cut through.

”Levels?”

Jen looked at the device.

“Nearly zero. It’s either far away or contained properly.”

Agatha stepped into the hall despite Kale’s warning look, her eyes and ears on her surroundings.

Wanda spoke again.

”Press forward. If it spikes, retreat.”

A violent retching sound came from a few doors ahead and Agatha unclipped her holster.

“What are the effects of gamma radiation exposure?”

Kale took up a position a step and a half back.

“Depends on exposure. Fatigue and headaches at low exposure. Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea at higher levels. If there’s contact to the ski—“

Agatha waved her silent as the retching occurred again, closer and clearly behind the door ahead.

She reached the door and listened, her eyes falling back to see if the Geiger counter reading had increased.

Kale shook her head.

There was no ‘do not disturb’ placard on the door and Agatha reached up and knocked.

“Housekeeping.”

There was a muffled moan and a hoarse ‘I’m good’ through the door.

Agatha knocked again and then pressed her fingers against the handle to simulate the sound.

There was a louder groan and the door jerked open.

It was a man in his late thirties, his head almost entirely bald and his clothes rumpled and stained. The room reeked of alcohol and vomit and she could see the stamp from a club on the back of his hand.

He groaned.

“I said I’m good!” He doubled over, his sweaty face pressing into the door. “If you feel like bringing me water though—“

Agatha pulled the door closed.

“False alarm. He’s just hungover.”

Rio’s voice came through the comms.

“We’re continuing to receive pushback on the evacuation. This is a conference filled with oncologists and there is a non-zero chance of certain medical equipment reading on the Geiger. I am speaking with the front desk to see if I can get Graves on the phone.

Agatha wanted to pull out her hair.

She turned to Kale just as a door at the end of the hallway jerked open.

The Geiger counter screeched to life as a man stumbled out, his face red and slick with sweat. He dropped to a knee and then pushed himself up as he coughed.

“Help— help me— please.”

He stumbled again, dry heaving, and Agatha’s stomach dropped at the blossoming burns on the skin around his nose, mouth, and cheeks.

Agatha pushed Kale backward.

“Kale, mask up.”

Both drew their respirators from beneath their jackets and pressed them over their faces.

The man stumbled forward again, his eyes blood-red and blinking painfully.

“Please!!”

Agatha maintained a level voice as she spoke to the team.

“Evacuate the building.”

From behind the choking man, Agatha watched as an individual in full radiation gear stepped from the room. He had a backpack on that looked too heavy, the straps pressing down into the suit as his head turned toward them. She could barely make out the face of Adkins behind the shield. He turned the opposite direction and ran toward the steps.

Agatha swore.

“Adkins is on floor eighteen! He’s not hitting the conference. He’s targeting individuals.”

Calderu’s voice sounded, the tone terse and warped by her own respirator.

”He has a partner on floor seven. We have two victims in need of urgent medical care for suspected radiation exposure.”

Rio’s voice cut through, commanding.

”I want full radiation suits donned by all on-site agents! Drisk, Patel, get PPEs to our agents on floors seven and eighteen. Calderu, Gulliver, Kale, Harkness, do not engage! Draw back.”

Agatha and Jen continued to back away as the exposed man struggled toward them.

Kale shook her head.

“If we evacuate this building, everyone on this floor that steps out is going to come in contact.”

Agatha drew in a slow breath.

“If we don’t evacuate, we risk Adkins finding a way to infect everyone here.”

Kale swore and spoke quickly over the comms.

“Where are the HVAC units for this hotel?”

There was a pause, then Wanda answered.

”Roof.””

Kale shook her head, her eyes locked onto Agatha.

“We don’t have time to wait for suits. If he gets to the roof he can blast whatever he has through the HVAC system. That would irradiate the entire building and the immediate area.”

Agatha grit her teeth as they turned to the stairs.

Rio’s voice snapped through the comms and it sounded like she was running.

“I want power cut to the entire building. Kale, Harkness, do not move from your position. Do you copy?”

Kale lifted a brow at Agatha and Agatha, for once, felt bad for her blatant disobedience. She nodded and both of them stepped into the stairwell.

Agatha tried to soften the blow.

“We copy. We won’t engage unless absolutely necessary.”

She could imagine Rio’s face and she clenched her teeth to stem the guilt.

Rio cut through again.

”Hold at the access hatch. Do not engage Adkins without protection. That is an order.”

Agatha’s heart was pounding violently and her body was covered in a cold sweat as they took the stairs carefully toward the top floor. She would listen if she could. If it was possible to wait and still stop Adkins, she would listen.

“Understood.”

They moved through the next two flights with focus and precision. As they reached the penthouse, they found the end of the stairwell.

Agatha pushed into the hall.

“Other stairwell.”

They’d just started down the hallway when the elevator doors dinged. Both raised their weapons and lowered them quickly as two agents stepped into the hall in standard-issued radiation suits.

Agatha was almost relieved she was going to be able to listen to Rio.

“Kale and Harkness standing down until we get our PPE.”

The two agents moved from the elevator and toward the opposite stairwell.

Agatha’s eyes narrowed at the familiar gaits of the agents in front of her and took a step. Something sick and cold curled around her spine.

“Rio!”

The forms didn’t slow, but Rio’s voice came through the comms and echoed in the hall.

“Stand down, Agent Harkness.”

Agatha’s throat nearly closed. She was stopped from pursuing by a hand on her arm.

Agatha forced her lungs to work as Rio and Wanda disappeared into the stairwell.

The wait was excruciating. The next minute passed as if every second was twenty, and Agatha felt the tension in every fiber of her body. Rio and Wanda called in their breach just as two figures sprinted from the opposing stairwell with full suits.

The next series of calls from the comms came in rapid succession.

Lilia marked the apprehension and containment of the partner and the location of Graves.

Alice announced that power would be shut off in two minutes.

As Agatha was shoving her body into the radiation suit— the agents behind them zipping both her and Kale in— gunfire sounded from the rooftop.

Rio shouted, her words strained.

”We’re taking fire! Adkins has accessed the HVAC system and he has two gunmen on his position”

Agatha and Jennifer bolted toward the stairwell with the other agents sticking close.

Their feet pounded on the cement steps as they approached the exterior door.

Wind whistled loudly through the thin reliefs creating a harrowing sound on top of the bursts of gunfire.

Agatha unholstered her firearm and braced against the door.

“Ready to breach. Give the signal!”

The bursts of sound suddenly doubled as Rio and Wanda provided cover-fire.

Wanda called through.

”Cover immediately to your left. Move now!”

Agatha’s shoulder slammed into the compression bar and she sprinted outside, eyes clocking large machines and structures to press herself behind.

She heard Kale at her back, the two other agents taking up positions several feet away.

Exhaust from the air conditioners spilled up toward the sky and the machinery hummed, droning under the sound of feet scraping cement and the firefight.

She couldn’t see Rio and Wanda, but with a quick look around her cover, she saw the edge of a bright yellow radiation suit belonging to one of the gunmen on the far side of the rooftop. She signaled to Kale.

Kale put a hand on her shoulder and spoke quietly.

“We’re at your nine. One gunman spotted but behind cover.”

Wanda responded.

”Vidal is attempting to get a visual on Adkins. I’ll provide cover-fire. Get closer if you can.”

Agatha glanced at the two other agents, motioning them right. They acknowledged and hunkered low.

She waited for Kale’s okay, for Wanda’s suppressive fire, and swerved into the wide alley of boxy structures on the roof. She hit a dead sprint, eyes on the yellow of the target, and made it to the halfway point before the yellow suit shifted and the black of a barrel came into view.

“Cover!”

She dove into cover, her elbow striking the cement hard as she slid. She grimaced as she looked toward Kale on the other side of the alley.

“We’re within thirty feet.”

Rio’s voice came through quietly.

”Make some noise on my signal. I’m ten feet out from Adkins and he’s unloading half a dozen shielded containers.”

Agatha pushed herself into position as bullets spiked into metal and kicked up cement beside her. Kale followed suit opposite her.

Agatha’s hairs stood on end as Rio’s “now” whispered through the line.

In time, as five agents laid down cover, the hum of machines ceased entirely, the power shutting off.

Agatha saw a spray of red on yellow as one of Kale’s shots hit home against the target and she pressed forward, moving up ten feet as the gunman retreated behind cover. She could just make out Adkins kneeling beside the open face of an HVAC unit, his backpack sitting beside him on the ground. He was fully focused as he sat silver, cylindrical containers beside himself on the ground.

Rio came into view behind the HVAC unit, her body pressed tightly to the metal.

A strained, agitated voice sounded.

“If you’d just let me complete my work, I wouldn’t be resorting to this! Only a few needed to suffer for the sins of many.”

Adkins didn’t seem to mind that he didn’t receive an answer.

Agatha watched him lift one of the leaden containers and rest it on the edge of the HVAC unit. Rio was inching closer.

Adkins continued.

“It doesn’t matter if you kill me, it doesn’t matter if you bury my name and my mission in redacted paperwork and metal cabinets.” His movements were precise as he fiddled with the case. The seal released. “I will have succeeded.”

Agatha tried to suss out Rio’s best path to success. There was an injured gunman currently kneeling out of sight behind cover and another somewhere Agatha had yet to lay eyes on. She didn’t have a clear shot at Adkins due to the bunching of pipes curling at his back, but she could draw his attention. She raised her voice.

“Most of our documentation is online, actually.”

Adkins stilled his movements, his head turning slightly as he looked toward Agatha’s voice. It was an announcement of her position, a dangerous way to draw attention, but the injured gunman leaned around the corner and raised his weapon in Agatha’s direction.

Adkins called back, his voice trembling with rage.

“You fail to see the bigger picture! You work for the hive, your mind is not your own.” He seemed to calm himself and carefully picked up the next lead case. “It’s not your fault. To split from the path is to choose a painful awareness. There is a striking acceptance of complacency in our world and to see it is to despair.”

He set the newly opened containment cylinder down carefully and selected the next.

Agatha spoke quietly to her team.

“Does anyone have eyes on the second gunman?”

Wanda cut through.

”Confirmed. He’s flanking Adkins. I could draw him out but not without risk.”

Agatha’s gloved hands tightened around her weapon as she calculated.

“He’s got three of those transport cylinders open and doesn’t look to be stopping.”

Kale met Agatha’s eyes across the gap.

”The gamma radiation coming from those open containers is already highly dangerous. If the powder is open and dispersed, even without flooding the HVAC, we have a serious problem.”

Agatha grunted her affirmation as Adkins spoke again.

He had four open containment cylinders beside him and was working on a fifth.

“The building is equipped with backup generators that should kick in at any moment.” He reached for the final cylinder. “And if your team has managed to cut off the back-up,” He set the final open cylinder on the ground. “Well, I’m certain my message will reach those immediate area.” He sighed. “It’s a shame, truly. Radiation sickness is a terrible thing to endure.”

Agatha’s stomach dropped as he lifted two of the containers and stood.

“He’s going to release them.” Her adrenaline severed her connection to her fear, her breathing leveled out as she tensed. “I’m pressing now. Provide cover.”

Rio’s voice was barely a whisper, her proximity to Akins keeping her quiet.

”Flood them.”

Kale was the first to fire, her bullets kicking into the metal frame with loud pings and screeches. Agatha flung herself from her position, her own weapon firing twice as she sprinted toward the massive HVAC unit.

Rio moved in unison, rounding the corner of the HVAC unit and– Agatha nearly screamed. Rio had no weapon out. She collided with Adkins and stabilized the jarred containers, her hands closing around his on the handles as he struggled.

It left her entirely unprotected, her hands occupied as Adkins yanked and kicked and lunged toward her.

Rio held her ground, using her weight to drag Adkins to the ground and minimize the dispersion risk. Agatha got a bead and fired twice at the injured gunman, his weapon clattering to the ground as his head fell back.

She’d just rounded the corner when an impact hit Rio’s body and forced her backward with a shocking jolt.

Agatha whirled just as Wanda appeared and dropped the shooter. She couldn’t breathe. She had to clamber over the dozens of metal tubes to get to Rio and Adkins was already pulling himself to his feet, one hand reaching for one of the cylinders while the other brandished a short blade.

He ran toward Rio as she struggled to stand, slicing at her, and she parried the attack enough that miss her throat and cut into the suit at her shoulder.

Agatha felt nothing as she bludgeoned her limbs on metal to reach the other side. Her body was in a near-free fall of panic as Rio stepped back from the next swing.

Agatha wanted to launch Adkins from the 20th story. She wanted to shred his suit and watch his body slowly give way to the effects of radiation. Instead, she drove her boot into the back of his knee. As he collapsed, she caught his arm and dislodged the canister.

Rio weakly kicked out and knocked the blade from his hand before collapsing back to the ground.

Wanda and Jen closed in, the other agents following suit. Agatha let go of Adkins, used all of her will to gently set the canister aside, and scrambled toward where Rio was pushing herself up. Rio’s suit had been punctured in the chest, the bullet caught in the vest. No blood seeped from the hole and Agatha felt the faintest twinge of relief.

Rio lifted her arm and Agatha saw the gash from the blade, blood slicking the radiation suit and dripping down the sleeve.

Agatha helped Rio stand with her uninjured arm as Jen shouted behind them.

“Get her out of here, now!”

Agatha dragged Rio toward the stairwell with fluctuating terror and Rio used her free hand to block the hole in the suit of her chest. Agatha flung the door open and pushed them into the stairwell as she called for help.

“Radiation suit failure, definite exposure.”

Fully outfitted agents hurried past them from the hallway to aid in Adkins’ arrest and Agatha listened over the pounding feet as directions were delivered calmly from the teams below.

She and Rio started down the arduous, twenty-story descent toward the decontamination zone. She could hardly breathe, hardly speak, and while Rio was carrying her own weight, she was slowed by cracked ribs and blood loss.

A team of medics met them at the fourteenth floor with a stair chair. They strapped Rio in and moved off with urgency, leaving Agatha to follow behind with her heart in her throat and her lungs seizing with every breath.
______

By the time Agatha was allowed to see Rio again, she’d nearly bitten the head off of every specialist that had come within a two-foot radius.

All exposed agents, including the medical staff that had carried Rio down the stairs, were placed into decontamination procedures. Agatha’s suit was vacuumed and a damp wipe was used to remove any loose powder from the fabric. The process was explained in depth but Agatha caught every fourth word.

She was then misted down and the suit was very, very carefully unzipped and peeled inside out and away from her body. The specialist in the room placed the suit in a radioactive waste bag before returning to Agatha with a geiger counter for a thorough search.

She was moved and left with an FBI sweatsuit with orders to shower with soap and water.

When she reemerged, Jen, Alice, Lilia, and Wanda were already gathered outside the decontamination zone.

Wanda looked at her approach with concern.

“You okay? Word on Rio?”

Agatha’s teeth ground together.

“I’m fine. I haven’t heard anything on Rio.”

Wanda nodded.

“I’ll get one.” She looked exhausted, her hair frizzy and pressed against her skull. “The rest of you can head back to the WFO. There’s going to be an ungodly amount of paperwork to complete after this shitshow.”

Lilia looked relieved, her shoulders slumping slightly as she complied. She touched Agatha’s shoulder and moved past, a complaint leaving her lips.

“I think exposure to radioactive material should give us a ‘go home early from work’ pass.”

There were mumbled agreements from Jen and Alice as they trailed after Lilia, both following suit and pressing a hand to Agtha’s shoulder.

Wanda focused her attention on Agatha.

“She’s going to be fine.”

Agatha glanced back toward the decontamination zone with her heart in her throat.

“She fucking better be.”
______

Rio was released when it was nearly dark outside. The sun was low in the sky and Agatha was nearly starving and even closer to rabid. Clean-up crews had been on-site from moments after arrest until now and they had yet to descend.

Agatha’s agitation seeped away as Rio, donning the same sweatsuit, stepped into her view.

She looked weary and pale, her gait slow as she walked toward Agatha with the mantle of her position worn on her face. She didn’t stop to talk, walking past Agatha with a slight tilt of her head.

Agatha followed after her, then passed her, to open the passenger side door of Rio’s SUV and help her inside.

Rio’s jaw locked as she hoisted herself up, her face twisting in pain as she settled into the leather.

Agatha climbed into the driver’s seat and started the engine.

They didn’t idle and chat. In fact, neither spoke until they’d lost sight of the hotel and pulled onto the highway.

Rio’s rigid posture and blank expression faltered, a small gasp leaving her mouth as she shed her stoicism.

Agatha’s chest squeezed.

“Did they give you the good stuff?”

Rio blew out a huff that was probably supposed to be a chuckle.

“No. Advil. I’m on Prussian Blue. A 1 gram dose three times a day for the next month.”

Agatha frowned.

“And the ribs? The cut?”

Rio closed her eyes, her head resting against the headrest.

“Two ribs at the impact site. The cut wasn’t deep. Just five stitches.”

Agatha drew in a sharp breath, her fingers wrapped tightly around the wheel.

“Rio–”

Rio hissed out a pained breath.

“Can you update me on the details of the case? I don’t– I just need to not talk until I’m able to lay down.”

Agatha did.

Adkins had confessed the intended plan without resistance. Hit six targets; doctors that had broken their oaths, that had pressed the boundaries of what was safe for their patients in the name of progress. He’d gotten to three, Graves not being one of them, and had changed his tactics when he’d seen Agatha and Jen.

She took the familiar route back toward Rio’s home.

“Graves is nearly hysterical and they’re letting him cool off before they attempt to get anything from him. The conference has been fully cancelled and both of its largest investors are in hot water after the near disaster.” Agatha huffed. “The hotel is threatening legal action but they have nothing to stand on.”

She fell silent a moment as she changed lanes, avoiding the series of metal plates lain over the road in a construction zone.

“The three victims attacked individually are in critical care. They received a rather excessive blast of Cesium powder directly to the faces. We’ll know a bit more in the coming days but none of them will get out unscathed.” As they neared the familiar neighborhood, Agatha tried not to overthink. “I’ll walk you in and get you settled.”

Rio groaned as they turned into the cul de sac, the wheels bumping over a groove in the road, and Agatha slowed the vehicle to a crawl as they neared the destination. She gently eased the SUV into the driveway.

Agatha turned off the vehicle and circled the car to help Rio onto the pavement. She kept a hand on her back to steady her as they made their way to the front door.

Agatha’s hands shook as she pressed the key into the lock and let herself into the house. Rio had her hand held against her injured ribs as she stepped inside, her head hanging slightly. She looked like she was about to fold into the couch and Agatha caught her carefully.

“Upstairs.”

Rio’s lips turned down into a pout, the facade of the Director entirely faded. It had been a shocking discovery early in their relationship: Rio Vidal was a massive baby when injured or sick and she made it everyone’s problem. Everyone being Agatha.

Seeing that now, the sad little scrunch in her nose and the tragic line of her frown, Agatha’s emotions from the waiting and worrying threatened to overrun her.

Agatha didn’t let Rio’s dragging feet hinder her as she guided them up the steps and past Nicky’s room. She carefully leaned Rio against the large bed in her room before she left her to walk into the closet. She returned with a pair of thick socks and dropped them on the comforter.

“Are you going to brush your teeth?”

Rio frowned petulantly.

“No.”

Agatha chuckled, heart warm, and nodded.

“Fine. Up you go.”

She helped Rio to the side and pulled back the covers. The gasp that left Rio’s lips as her hand slipped on the way up had Agatha’s spine tingling in sympathetic pain. As soon as Rio managed to lay back, Agatha pulled off the cheap socks from Rio’s time in decontamination and tossed them toward the hamper. She gently replaced them with the warmer ones and let her hand settle on Rio’s ankle.

With every task completed, Agatha felt as if she should leave. She wanted nothing less.

“Can I do anything else, Rio?”

Rio’s eyes were already blinking against exhaustion but she refocused in order to find Agatha’s gaze.

“You should probably try not to jostle me as you get in the bed.

Agatha’s spine and chest and limbs seemed to relax at the words, her jaw finally releasing with a painful burn.

“Let me brush my teeth.”

When Agatha slipped back into the room, her thoughts were floating between the magnitude of climbing into-and sleeping- in this bed and room that had once belonged to both of them, and the banality of whether she needed to text Wanda an update or go through the details of the case.

She found Rio already fully asleep, her lips parted slightly, her hair messy around her face, and Agatha climbed carefully beside her and settled into the sheets. She placed a hand on Rio’s arm, needing reassurance that she was there and well, and Rio let out a quiet sound. The whine curled through Agatha’s skull, traveled along her spine, and thudded into her chest.

She closed her eyes and, for the third night in a row, fell asleep beside Rio.

Chapter End Notes

Ignore all my comments about how many chapters are left. I'm a useless planner.

Hope y'all enjoyed!

Chapter 27

Chapter Notes

This is shorter than I wanted it to be, but I got swamped this weekend and had zero time to sit down and write. I figured a shorter chapter was better than waiting an entire week!

Twitter: @adimnoss

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Agatha blinked against the bright sunlight streaming through the room and for a moment, she was a wife again. A mother. The way the sunlight soaked the comforter had her stretching like she’d done a thousand times before. She listened for Nicky’s cry and felt a serenity at the silence, the few precious moments she’d be able to stay in bed.

The silence curdled, the hammerstrike of reality rumbling through her. She sucked in a breath and pushed through the disorienting pain. Agatha blinked as the events of the day before slunk back in, her eyes traveling to Rio’s still sleeping form. She was tucked almost entirely under the covers, the only parts of her face visible were the bridge of her nose and her eyebrows.

Agatha’s stomach growled and she felt sick from hunger, her belly coiled and small. She carefully slid from the covers and set her feet to the sun-soaked floors.

With quiet steps, Agatha slipped from the room.

It felt right to relegate herself to the guest bathroom, to use a toothbrush that wasn’t really hers. There was a gnawing sense that she was overreaching, that extending so far would leave her open to a strike to the ribcage.

She padded down the steps, phone in hand, and entered the kitchen.

She had a text from Wanda telling her to take the day and make sure Rio didn’t attempt to come into work. Agatha almost laughed. Rio was a disaster when she was sick or hurt or had the smallest of stomach aches. She couldn’t imagine, even with her new position, that she’d changed so much in the past five years. Especially not if her behavior the night before had been an indication. The very first time Agatha had been around Rio while she was sick, she’d nearly lost her mind with the drastic one-eighty Rio had performed.

Rio had texted her an hour prior that she wasn’t feeling well, that she was skipping trivia to try and sleep off whatever had her under the weather. And Agatha, because they were trying this, because they spent their nights together more times than not, had decided to skip trivia too.

She’d gone to the store and purchased a few too many items that Rio likely wouldn’t need before packing it all in her car and making her way toward Rio’s apartment.

Now she was standing in front of the door, the welcome mat with black and white images of iconic horror movie killers and the words ‘The Psycho Bunch’ under her feet.

She knocked twice and waited.

And waited.

She knocked again and frowned, a slight rush of concern filling her as she once more received no response. She pulled out her phone and dialed Rio. She was nearly ready to pick the lock, the phone ringing endlessly, when Rio answered with a weak:

”Agatha?”

“Rio, I’m outside.”

She expected to hear footsteps or an explanation and received neither. Rio groaned on the other end.

”I think the window is unlocked.”

Agatha’s brows lifted, her eyes flicking over to the walkway and the small window beside the door.

“What?”

Rio made a pathetic sound and Agatha’s brows inched further onto her head.

”The window–”

“Rio, I’m not climbing through the window of my fucking girlfriend’s apartment. Where are you?”

There was a pause.

”On the couch.”

Agatha considered hanging up. Instead, she began knocking again, her fist banging against the door.

“Open the door, Rio.”

Rio’s moan on the other end had Agatha worried that she was deeply ill, and she waited impatiently for the lock to turn.

The door opened into a dimly lit living room with the blinds drawn and the only light coming from the television. Rio looked… fine. Her face was somewhat pale and her hair was a mess, but Agatha had seen sicker geese at the park. She stepped inside with her two bags and glanced at the television screen. Tom and Jerry was playing, the image grainy, and Agatha returned her attention to Rio.

“Should I call you an ambulance?”

Rio’s lips turned down, her arms crossing over her chest as she moped back to her nest of blankets on the couch.

Agatha fought back a startled laugh. Rio was the picture of control in nearly every aspect of her life. To see such a drastically different figure was almost alarming. Agatha set the groceries on the kitchen table and walked to sit down beside Rio as she tucked herself back into her pile.

“Is it terminal?”

Rio’s expression fell further and she looked away.

“You didn’t have to come.”

Agatha snickered and dug under the blankets for Rio’s feet so she could pull them onto her lap.

“I wouldn’t miss this if you paid me.” She scratched lightly at Rio’s calf. “Who knew Agent Vidal was a massive baby.”

Rio, instead of pulling away or snapping back, slid lower and pressed her legs further into Agtha’s lap.

“Did you bring me gatorade?”

Agatha grinned, her heart soft at the hopeful look in Rio’s eyes. She wanted to make fun of her, to pick at the sensitive layers, but she couldn’t bring herself to do anything but feed into it.

“Three whole flavors.”

Rio’s smile was worth the decision to skip the jokes.

“And soup?”

Agatha huffed.

“Chicken noodle.” Rio’s face fell and Agatha laughed. “And lentil soup you absolute freak.”

Rio interlocked their fingers then, her eyes falling back to the television, and proceeded to use her pout to coerce Agatha into doing her will.

The first test of Agatha’s will to resist Rio had been an utter failure on her part, and a sure sign on Rio’s that she had Agatha wrapped around her finger.

From then on, on the incredibly rare occasions that Rio got sick or hurt, Agatha would find herself heeding the whims of a petulant, barely-functioning brat. They’d curl into each other and watch old cartoons, and Agatha would cook and clean and provide endless back scratches until Rio passed out or got better.

She figured she’d play the part now before she was asked.

Searching Rio’s pantry and fridge yielded far more results than Agatha’s had for Rio. She gathered a pair of russet potatoes and, on the same shelf, found barely used bags of all kinds of flour besides regular. Agatha rolled her eyes, retrieved the almond and oat flower, and set both on the counter. She wandered through the baking cabinet for vanilla extract and baking powder, then tugged the fridge door open and located the eggs and almond milk.

She had just finished measuring and pouring the ingredients into a mixing bowl when her phone began to blare. She glanced at it to find Rio’s number, her name still replaced by a skull, staring back at her. She was smiling before she answered.

“Yes?”

Rio didn’t say anything for several moments.

”Are you downstairs?”

Agatha could hear the restraint in Rio’s voice.

“I am.”

Another pause.

”Okay.”

Agatha’s adoration for this woman, while returning in waves and surges, seemed to triple. She felt so much of it that it hurt.

“Can I get you something?”

”No, it’s okay.”

Agatha looked at the batter as she mixed. She felt like she was bottle feeding a baby goat.

“Do you want to come down?”

Rio sighed and it held just the smallest twinge of self-pity.

“Yeah.”

Agatha grinned.

“Okay, be careful.”

She waited to see how Rio would respond. Instead there was just silence, like Rio was trying to work against her basest of wounded instincts. Agatha laughed.

“I’ll come up. Would you like me to call the medics? Get the stair chair again?”

Rio hung up the phone and Agatha set the whisk down in the bowl. She made her way back up the steps and slowed to a stop at Rio’s door.

Rio was sitting against the headboard with a frown on her face and her hands held in her lap. She seemed like she was attempting to feign normalcy, like she was fully aware that what they were doing here, what they’d been doing the past few days had been like slapping duct tape on a crack in a dam.

Agatha felt it too. Felt the split of wanting to do this right and wanting to do this right now. She walked to her side and held out a hand.

“Come on, sweetheart.”

Rio’s facade fractured, her eyes widening at the endearment. She looked like she might cry and Agatha gripped her elbow to keep her moving.

This time–unlike Rio’s mild cold where she’d asked Agatha to climb through a window– Rio was clearly in a serious amount of pain. Her startled expression twisting as she pulled her feet over the edge of the bed. Agatha helped her stand and Rio sucked in a sharp breath.

Agatha frowned.

“Ribs or shoulder?”

Rio spoke through clenched teeth.

“Ribs.”

Agatha hummed her acknowledgement and turned Rio to the bathroom. This time, Rio didn’t refuse. She stepped past the banana plant, the leaves tickling the top of her head, and brushed her teeth with her uninjured arm.

She didn’t hold onto Agatha as they headed toward the stairs but she hesitated at the top.

“I’ve changed my mind. How soon until the stair chair arrives?”

Agatha chuckled and stepped back up to insert herself as a support. They moved down the steps slowly and Rio held her breath for a large portion of it. When they reached the landing, Rio gasped.

“For fucks sake.”

Agatha walked beside her to the kitchen table and helped her sit down before scouring the medicine cabinet for Advil. She poured Rio a glass of ice water and set both on the table. She cleared her throat. She pulled an ice pack from the freezer, one with a large, velcro strap, and helped Rio hook it around her torso.

“Are they displaced?”

Rio grunted out a negative as she tried to relax in the chair.

“No.”

Agatha didn’t want to fuss over her, didn’t want to hover, and she returned to the counter to continue mixing.

When she searched for a pan, her eyes fell on the charred remains still in the sink. She reached forward and lifted the pan into Rio’s view.

“This makes me worried about what you’ve been eating.”

Rio rolled her eyes, her frown deepening.

“I was seasoning the pan.”

Agatha’s brows lifted and she glanced at the husk of bacon that was still glued to the metal.

“Oh with charcoal? Is that a new trend? Charcoal and soap suds?” She shrugged. “I have to say, I’m not certain I’m on board.”

Rio groaned, the sound hitching as it rattled her ribs.

“I’m unwell and I’m being harassed in my own kitchen.”

Agatha grinned as she scrubbed the metal clean, the two days of soaking enough to make it an easier job.

She set the clean pan on the stove and peered at the coffee maker they’d received for their wedding.

“This was from Bohner, right?”

Rio huffed.

“Best thing he ever did.”

Agatha grinned as she fiddled with the machine, her hands falling into practiced motions as she set about making two cups. She finished and popped open the fridge to find Rio’s inordinately expensive creamer to pour in.

When she placed it on the table, Rio was watching her with an expression that sent a pang through Agatha’s heart. She cleared her throat and returned to mixing the batter. She twisted the stove on, pulled down a plate, prepared several tabs of butter, and only then did she return her gaze to Rio.

Rio who was still watching her. Rio who still had that look on her face.

Agatha felt a flare of panic and veered away from another intense conversation with a prod of humor.

“If you cry I’m leaving.”

It did the trick. Rio’s soft expression churned into defensiveness, her brows drawing together.

“I’m not going to cry. What the fuck?”

Agatha huffed and dropped a tab of butter in the pan and watched it melt.

“I’m just saying. If you do–”

Rio sputtered.

“I’m not!”

Agatha grinned as she scooped up enough batter to make a truly massive pancake.

“Great.”

Rio stewed in silence and Agatha waited until the bubbles had overtaken the raw side before she flipped it. Out of practice, the batter splattered across the edge of the pan and the glass of the stove. She subtly wiped it away.

Rio snorted, then groaned.

“God, oww– I saw that. You’re making a mess.”

Agatha rolled her eyes.

“Do you want to starve or shut up?”

Rio chuckled, the sound catching.

“Okay, please don’t be funny, I can't.”

Agatha slipped the pancake from the pan and poured in the next.

“Like asking water to be dry.”

Rio sighed and Agatha felt a gentle warmth, a simmer of easy hope floating in her chest as she finished creating a too-tall stack of almond and oat pancakes. She tugged open the pantry and searched. And searched.

“Rio, where’s your syrup?”

“I don’t have syrup.”

Agatha turned around, her brows lifting.

“Oh. And you waited until I’d spent thirty minutes making you food to tell me that?”

Rio flushed.

“I wasn’t really thinking about it.” She frowned. “I’m in pain.”

Agatha rolled her eyes and grabbed the honey.

“You’re about to be in more.” She returned to the fridge and pulled out a half-eaten carton of blueberries, an unopened package of raspberries, and set them on the counter. “You’re about to be out of fruit too.”

Rio’s voice was nearly a whine.

“But what about my yogurt?”

Agatha poured the berries into the still-warm pan, added the honey, a touch of vanilla extract, and returned her attention to Rio.

“I’ll get you more yogurt.”

Rio’s brows rose but she refrained from answering as she lifted her coffee to her lips.

By the time Agatha was finished, a berry compote-ish sauce to pour over the pancakes, she carried them to the table.

Rio shifted.

“Patio room?”

Agatha’s breathing stuttered. She still hadn’t seen it, hadn’t peered into the room that they’d spent years of their lives lounging within.

“Okay.”

Rio carefully stood, face tense, and began a slow path toward the hallway. She’d left her coffee.

Agatha rolled her eyes.
