“Yeah, of course, no, I’ll carry everything. Don’t you worry.”

Rio frowned back at her.

“I’m injured.”

Agatha moved ahead of Rio despite her hesitation, her eyes flicking around the hallway as she stepped into it.

The pictures were endless, proudly placed, prominent; Nicky next to his ‘treehouse,’ standing with the widest smile beside the sticks he’d leaned against a tree in the backyard, Agatha and Rio at a banquet for their cohort a year after graduation, Nicky holding Wanda’s hand as they stood atop a large boulder; she was pointing toward a bird, Agatha remembered. Nicky had been enthralled.

He’d taken on Rio’s love of camping, much to Agatha’s chagrin, and they’d made a tradition of going with Wanda and Vision whenever their time-off happened to align; weather permitting.

She stared at his chunky boots he’d insisted on wearing because they matched Agatha’s. They were tan and purple and he’d barely been able to walk in them for the first several attempts. He’d sobbed when they’d attempted to put him in tennis shoes.

Rio came to a stop beside her.

“He fell every three steps for a week and wasn’t phased because they made him ‘tough like mama.’”

Agatha let out a sharp breath.

“He was the toughest kid.” She smiled. “Definitely tougher than you. He barely slowed down when he had a cold.”

Rio’s lips curled up even as she pushed on, her steps fragile.

They turned into the mudroom and Rio pushed through the screen– a cat door installed near the bottom– that led to the covered patio.

Agatha forgot herself for a moment.

It had always been beautiful, a place for comfort and rest, but Rio had turned it into a sanctuary. Rio’s new rug was the color of the sunset, of warm clay and ochre. The removable doors were perfectly clean, no little handprints to smudge the glass, and sunlight drenched the space. The furniture was the same, if more worn, and Agatha ached to curl into the large, wicker chairs and sink into the sage cushions.

Plants dominated the space. A massive fiddle leaf fig stood in the corner, its leaves splayed out as it curled toward the sun. Succulents, lavender plants, coleuses, peperomias, begonias, pathos; all of them sewn into the tapestry the room created. There were dozens of air plants hanging from twine in mismatched glass jars and vials.

Set near the largest window was a cat tree that blended well with the plants and Boggle was currently curled into the tallest platform, his body almost too large for it. He barely acknowledged them.

Agatha turned toward the far corner and smiled.

“Your hammock.”

Rio flushed slightly.

“I like to feel like I’m camping even though I can’t find the time to go.”

The hammock was attached to two of the metal supports, metal rings drilled in to give it something to attach to. It was sun-bleached and old, but the synthetic, orange material had held up well.

“It’s beautiful, Rio.”

Rio smiled like she agreed. She stared at her creation with a proud shine in her eyes.

Agatha loved her hopelessly.

“You don’t camp anymore?”

Rio shrugged, her shine dimming slightly.

“I think going alone lost its appeal a long time ago.”

______

Agatha sat glumly in the fading sun, eyes on the ring of stones around what would become their campfire.

Rio was kneeling beside it with a pile of twigs to her right and four plastic-wrapped bundles of firewood at her back. She was smug and her lips were twitching with the effort of hiding it.

Agatha glared into the side of her face with hopes of setting her on fire.

“I’m cold.”

Rio bit the side of her cheek as she piled twigs and a newspaper at the center of the pit.

“I told you to bring an extra jacket.”

Agatha slumped further into the camping chair and grimaced as the edge of it cut into her thighs.

She’d lost the bet fair and square according to Rio. In reality, she’d lost the bet while cheating and that made this situation far worse. Projection was always a good defense.

“I know you cheated.”

Rio finished placing the firewood over the piled tinder and finally looked at her.

“Agatha, you spent the entire game stealing money from the bank.”

Agatha feigned offense, her mouth dropping open.

“I did not!”

She had.

Rio rolled her eyes and turned further toward her, her fingers lacing together against her knees.

“I told you not to challenge me to Monopoly of all games. Grim and I had access to the shittiest fucking copy you can imagine, but we played it almost every day for two years.”

Agatha hated losing.

“It’s all luck.”

Rio chuckled as she focused in on the tinder.

“Whatever you need to believe to help you sleep tonight. It’ll be pretty cold. Are you sure you don’t want my coat?”

Agatha did want her coat.

“I’m sure.”

Smoke began to rise and Agatha hid her grudging admiration behind her frown. It probably wasn’t even that hard to make a fire.

Rio leaned down, back arching as she blew a slow stream of air into the flickering embers. Agatha stared at her ass and it made her mood marginally brighter.

Once the flames jumped up slightly, the peaks of it licking the larger sticks, Rio stood and stared down proudly. She turned and smiled at Agatha, and Agatha was caught in the innocent joy there. Rio in nature was a softer creature; seemingly untouched by the lashes she’d been dealt by a shitty world. It was likely enough to balance out Agatha’s distaste for being stuck without the luxury of air conditioning and a bed, but she’d die before she told Rio that.

Rio walked toward her car, the black paint and wheels coated in a fine layer of dust, and popped the trunk. She pulled out a large cooler, several smaller bags, and the two backpacks that carried all of their gear; bringing each one to set closer to the fire. She returned one last time and pulled out a large, puffy, black coat. Agatha’s coat.

“Do you still want to sit there in your sweatshirt or would you like to stop pouting?”

Agatha stood and snatched the coat. She shoved her frozen arms into the sleeves and felt immediately better. She narrowed her eyes at Rio, unsure if her expression was even visible as night truly fell.

“I wasn’t pouting.”

Rio grinned, not rising to the challenge, and gripped the edges of the coat to pull Agatha closer.

“I’m going to ask you something. It’ll be really hard. You might want to refuse just to spite me.”

Agatha softened at Rio’s proximity, at the playful look in her eye.

“I do plan to refuse.”

Rio nodded, feigning gravitas.

“Of course.” She leaned in, pressing her lips to Agatha’s once before pulling back. “I really love camping, Agatha. Can you try to have fun? I’ll do everything, you don’t even need to help me set up the tent.”

Agatha could see she meant it; under the layer of Rio’s easy smile and humor, this was important to her. She huffed.

“Fine.”

Rio’s answering smile was brighter than the growing fire. She kissed Agatha again, leaned down to the cooler, and retrieved a beer that she pressed into Agatha’s hands.

“Okay, sit down, relax, and make a note of all the things you’ll want to bring next time to make this more manageable.”

Agatha’s eyes widened.

“Next time!”

Rio pretended not to hear her as she lifted a square bag and began to meander in the dark a little ways from the fire. A headlamp came on and Agatha bit her lip to stop her smile at the sight before her.

Rio, in dusty jeans, worn, brown boots, and a heavy flannel, was crouched down over a stack of synthetic canvas and metal poles. Her headlight stood out from her forehead and she looked like a fucking dork.

Agatha cracked her beer, significantly happier now that she was warm, and sat down with the full intention to only have a little bit of fun.
___

Agatha was crying, her eyes blurry as she laughed harder than she had in ages. She couldn’t breathe, and she was certain she was going to pass out before she found a way to use her lungs again.

Rio was in a similar state, curled limply over both sleeping bags, her eyes closed as she laughed silently.

They were hammered. They’d drank an entire twelve pack of PBR as they sat beside the fire, Agatha easing into and past the buzz as Rio forced her to skewer her own hot dog on a roasting stick and hold it over the flames.

Agatha was hungry enough that she was actually looking forward to it. Rio had finished first and was in the process of adding condiments, when Agatha’s fell off of her stick and into the fire.

They’d both stared, Agatha in complete dismay, until Rio had begun cackling.

Agatha hadn’t thought, hadn’t questioned herself. She’d picked up Rio’s perfectly made hot dog and threw it into the fire too.

The extended silence, followed by both of them wheezing into a fit of laughter, had carried the tone for the rest of the night.

Rio managed to gather herself momentarily, heaving as she tried to speak through her gasps, her head lolling back on the sleeping bag.

“I– I… can’t…. believe you just threw it…. into the– the fire… with… absolutely… no… hesitation! That’s— insane.”

Agatha held her stomach, the pain there nearing unbearable as she pulled in a lungful of air and lost it almost immediately.

“Oh.. my god…. sh–shut the… fuck… up.”

Rio groaned and took several near-violent, deep breaths, letting out little “whoooos” as she tried to stabilize her breathing. Agatha followed suit, her hand wiping at her eyes. They’d nearly succeeded when Rio giggled.

The next fit of laughter continued on until Agatha reached out and slapped weakly at Rio.

“Okay….shhh….. shhhhh. Please.. be quiet…. Oh my god.”

By the time they’d stopped their cackling, both of them nearly boneless, Agatha was almost certain she was in love with Rio Vidal. It wasn’t nearly as frightening as she’d thought it would be. She reached out and linked her hand with Rio’s.

“I am going to be really grumpy tomorrow when I wake up hungover and have to piss in the dirt.”

Rio grinned sleepily.

“Thanks for the head’s up.”

Agatha nodded.

“I wanted to say sorry now. I’m not going to say it tomorrow.”

Rio adjusted slightly, the sleeping bags a mess beneath them, and tugged at Agatha.

“I understand. Come here.”

Agatha shifted closer, letting herself be tucked into Rio’s body, her head pressing under Rio’s jaw. She pressed her lips against Rio’s throat.

“Shouldn’t we get in the sleeping bags?”

Rio nodded against her but did nothing to initiate the arduous task of moving something you were actively laying on.

They fell asleep like that, Agatha still in her puffy coat, Rio in her jeans, and they made it about an hour before they were shivering and drunkenly shifting around in the dark to stuff themselves into their sleeping bags.
______

Agatha had set down the plates and helped Rio sit in the spot that she’d worn in with years of favoritism. Agatha returned to the kitchen for their coffees. She hesitated for only a moment before claiming the cushion that had once been her own.

Rio was breathing slowly, her body leaning against the backrest, and she looked longingly at the plate sitting on the table.

Agatha blew out a breath and selected the largest pancakes, drizzled them with the compote, and placed the plate in Rio’s hands.

“A literal child.”

Rio’s eyes gleamed as she rested the plate precariously on her chest and painstakingly cut herself a piece. She looked pathetic and Agatha couldn’t breathe.

“If you make me cut up your food for you I’m going to start having regrets.”

Rio pulled her plate closer and pouted as she struggled to cut herself another piece.

Agatha stared at Rio until it became hard to watch. She groaned loudly, far more dramatically than she needed to, and reached for the plate.

Rio twisted away instinctively and the plate nearly dropped as she sucked in sharply.

Agatha caught it, her feigned irritation slipping away as Rio hissed through clenched teeth. Her eyes squeezed shut as the pain coursed through her.

Agatha set the plate down and reached out, her fingers pressing softly against the furrow in Rio’s brow.

“Breathe.” She pushed Rio’s hair from her forehead. “Just breathe through it.”

Rio’s face slackened, her chest rising and falling slowly after a few moments. She turned her head into Agatha’s hand.

Agatha let her nails trail along Rio’s scalp, scratching lightly, before curling behind her ear and pressing her palm against the warmth of Rio’s jaw and neck. For a moment she simply stared, her thumb gentle on Rio’s cheekbone. The motions and the words fell into place as if there’d been no break from the last time Agatha had been allowed to truly take care of Rio to this moment.

“You’re okay, sweetheart.”

Rio’s expression pinched again, but this time Agatha saw moisture gather in her lashes as her jaw trembled.

Agath’s chest jumped, her free hand cupping the other side of Rio’s face.

“Do you want to lay down?”

Rio’s mouth curved into a deep frown and she sniffed.

“I’m fine.”

Agatha ran her thumbs under Rio’s eyes to catch the few tears that fell.

“I was mostly kidding about leaving if you cried.”

Rio let out a wet huff of laughter, her chin dropping.

“Shut up. I know.” She pulled back and wiped at her own eyes. “I’m really okay.”

Rio leaned away and Agatha felt the withdrawal like a dull thump against her chest. She’d overstepped. This wasn’t five years ago. This was now, and they had canyons between them still needing to be traversed.

Rio blew out her cheeks, her mouth opening to speak, but the sound that left was nearly a sob. Agatha barely refrained from reaching again, her fingers tingling with inaction as she searched for the right words.

“I didn’t mean to–”

Rio groaned, her head leaning back as she reached out toward Agatha’s and caught her hand.

“Agatha.” Rio steadied her voice. “The only person that’s been around for these moments the past several years has been Wanda. She’s more the ‘ply you with medicine and supplements’ type.” She squeezed Agatha’s hand. “I’d forgotten how good—” she lifted a finger tiredly and motioned, “...how good this felt. I got overwhelmed. I’m not upset.”

Agatha tightened her grip.

“I know we keep saying we’ll talk. We keep trying to talk. But I don’t mind if we don’t for a little bit longer.”

Rio peaked one eye open, her brow lifting.

“I’m not in any shape to be doing that.”

Agatha rolled her eyes.

“No. I don’t mean sex. I mean…” She trailed off, uncertain, before forging ahead. “If you want to make popcorn and watch your stupid cartoons and play a game. Or something.”

Rio grinned.

“Or something?”

Agatha crossed her arms, immediate regret filling her.

“Never mind. I’ll send Wanda over with her supplements.”

Rio moaned dramatically, her hand tightening on Agatha’s.

“Please don’t. Last time she made a bone broth protein shake and I threw up.” Rio moaned again, this time quieter. “Just leave me here to rot.”

Agatha rolled her eyes as she retrieved Rio’s plate.

“No. You’re eating first. Then we’re maneuvering you to the couch and we’re paying out of our asses to watch Looney Toons.”
______

It took three google searches and the purchase of two streaming services to access the specific cartoons Rio was set on watching. Agatha had piled blankets around her to support her sides and allow her to relax. She’d made popcorn, brought in a massive bottle of water, and buried herself in the couch beside Rio.

She found herself watching Rio more than Foghorn Leghorn, a particular favorite for sick days. Every time Rio laughed too loudly at something that was arguably not funny, Agatha felt something like tranquility begin to soften her muscles and leaden her bones. For the first time she could remember, she felt blissfully content, her mind quiet.

Chapter End Notes

As always, thanks to everyone who reads and interacts with me on here and on twitter. I'm truly motivated by your words!

And thank you to my perfect gf who always reads and edits these chapters for me :)

Chapter 28

Chapter Notes

SORRY IT TOOK SO LONG.

I got distracted by a new short-fic about succubus Agatha and then was dealing with some life stuff.

This chapter is dedicated to my lovely gf who loves blue gatorade.

Twitter and bluesky: @adimnoss

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Agatha still sat deep in the cushions of the sofa, her eyes aimed in the direction of the television, but unseeing the grainy footage of the Roadrunner bright on the screen. The light coming through the windows was a warm orange.

Rio had fallen asleep sometime after the start of The Bugs Bunny show, her head leaning heavily on Agatha’s shoulder, and Agatha was not inclined to wake her.

The high intensity of emotion from the case, from being exposed to radiation, to Rio getting hurt, to waking up in this house once more, had eased away for a time. The familiarity of Rio being the worst patient, the biggest baby, had allowed Agatha to push aside any thoughts that might have sent her spiraling.

Thoughts about how she was supposed to do this, if she’d be able to do this, if she’d hurt Rio again without intending to. She chewed on the skin of her lip, worrying it between her teeth.

What if Rio decided it wasn’t worth the risk? She’d said she hadn’t seen any other path forward, but what if they stepped onto it and nothing clicked? Their relationship from their first run at Quantico up until Nicky got sick had felt like an inevitability, like Agatha and Rio, the two of them, could do nothing but choose one another.

What if they weren’t made to weather hardship and the distinct challenges that lay before them? The tough conversations, the regaining of trust, the overcoming of grief and anger and disappointment that seems to vacuum them hollow on their bad days.

Agatha felt the surge of something looming and cold, the icy fingers of fear that had no mercy for her desperate grabs at happiness, at anything other than sorrow.

She swallowed against the sensation and looked down at Rio’s slack expression. She was still bundled in blankets and she had a few bits of popcorn scattered across her chest. Agatha closed her eyes and drew in several breaths.

With careful movements, she adjusted Rio’s head to lean against the back of the couch. She gently extracted herself and let her feet guide her toward the stairs. She paused outside of Nicky’s room when she reached the top landing and breathed.

Vicious thoughts careened through her skull, judgements and accusations: that she wanted to leave him behind, that she didn’t deserve to.

She shook her head because that wasn’t it, that wasn’t what she wanted, but the voice persisted like an oppressive wave, a drowning of reason that caught her so off guard that her recently attained coping methods ceased to exist.

Agatha couldn’t breathe very well at all. She moved numbly into the master bedroom, raided Rio’s closet, and found the borrowed tennis shoes from two days before.

Was it wrong to move on from any of it? Was it the burden of a mother who lost her child to feel that suffering in excruciating measure, to account for the loss of innocence and brightness in the world? It almost made sense. Maybe the shell of the woman she’d been for the past five years was serving a purpose. Maybe she was not meant to belong to herself anymore. Maybe her body and her mind were not for her, but a vessel meant to carry such tragedy until it was buried in the ground.

Agatha moved quickly down the steps, her stomach churning, and slipped out the front door in a state of severe dissociation.

She didn’t pause to stretch, her stride picking up as she reached the bottom of the porch, shoes whispering through the slightly tall grass of the yard. Her body felt tilted, off-balance, as it tried to orient itself to activity from hours of being sedentary.

She hit the pavement, felt the twinge of age in her knees as they protested the hard surface, and set out to burn through the suffocating disposition of her mind.

She ran hard, pushed herself to the point of near dizziness, but this time she could find no escape. There was no glimpse of light, no understanding that her thoughts were falsities. They solidified like magma to sulfurous rock and Agatha was losing the ability to fight against the blanket of harsh truths.

She was, in her nature, a coward. She’d always been afraid. She’d never been strong enough to stand up to her mother. She’d masked her fear with indifference and abrasion, but it had always just been a mask.

She’d taken Rio, a self-sufficient, guarded, aspiring agent, and dragged her down, cut her open, bared her heart to tragedy. Only to leave her to stitch herself together alone. And when she finally had, when she’d done the work and extended an olive branch to Agatha, Agatha had done it all over again.

She’d bulldozed through years of therapy and took what did not belong to her. She’d let her words and actions raze Rio, tear her open once more, and then she’d had the audacity to worm her way back, to put herself in a place of comfort she did not deserve.

Rio was special. Rio was good and she deserved good.

Agatha was not good.

Agatha ran for nearly an hour. She lost track of the miles and the route until she was in an unfamiliar neighborhood with mansions that stood starkly against a now-darkening sky.

Agatha slowed, her heart scrabbling to keep up, her breathing more like a violent wheeze that rattled in her chest.

She put her hands on her hips, dropped her head back, and she cried.

She needed Wanda. Or Alder. She pressed shaking hands to the sides of the leggings she borrowed and frowned. She tried to remember if she’d brought her phone, if she might have dropped it, but the haze of the past hour made her memory finicky and dishonest.

Agatha heaved in lungfuls of air and looked around, trying to place herself so that she could figure out how to get back. A seeping silver of sanity returned as a mild concern filled her.

She didn’t know how long she’d been gone, didn’t know if Rio was awake. The thought that Rio might assume she’d left her without a word pierced Agatha’s chest and wouldn’t dislodge itself.

She began to walk, her eyes peeled for any familiar landmark or sign. It took her five minutes to find one and she grimaced as she realized she was nearly a thirty-minute walk from the house and currently going the wrong direction.

She doubled back and picked up her pace, her legs nearly jello as she half-walked, half-jogged back.

It was entirely dark outside by the time she reached the street. Her heart dropped.

Wanda’s car was sitting in the driveway, and there, sitting in the sage rocking chair, was Wanda herself.

Agatha expected anger. She was convinced she deserved it, her mind still prickling with shame.

Instead, she noted a lilt of concern on Wanda’s face.

Agatha slowed at the bottom of the steps and stared. She didn’t know what to say.

Wanda stood and met her where she was at.

“Talk to me, Agatha.”

Agatha felt the crack of a dam in her chest.

“Am I supposed to be sad forever? For Nicky? If I carry it, does that mean Rio doesn’t have to?”

In retrospect, the words didn’t make sense. At that moment, she believed them entirely.

Wanda’s eyes widened, her hands reaching out to pull Agatha to her chest so tightly that neither of them could breathe.

“No, you idiot.”

Agatha laughed and it was truly a sob. She pressed her face into Wanda’s shoulder and let her weight transfer further to the other woman.

Agatha pulled back and wiped her eyes.

“Fuck. Did Rio call? I left my phone—“

Wanda lifted said phone and passed it over.

“It had fallen between the couch cushions.” She glanced toward the house. “I called, actually. The boys were very adamant that they come and visit Rio. They made her cards and helped Vis bake some of the scones Rio likes.”

Agatha’s heart completed a pirouette in her chest.

“They’re inside?”

Wanda looked like she was attempting to gauge Agatha’s reaction.

“When I called, Rio said you’d left while she was asleep.”

Agatha’s throat tightened, the shame doubling down.

“I didn’t mean to—“

Wanda squeezed her arm.

“I know, Agatha. You know how Rio gets when she’s not feeling well. She’s grumpy.”

“But I should have known—“

Wanda shook her head.

“Stop. I can literally see you beating yourself up. I’m not worried about you going for a run. I’m worried about why you went. And what your brain is telling you.”

Agatha hated Wanda just a little bit. Even the recognition by another person that Agatha’s careen into panic was not only predictable, but also likely distorted, peeled back the veil just enough for her to breathe.

She blew her hair from her face. It was stringy with dried sweat and she probably looked feral.

“It’s telling me only good, productive things.”

Wanda snorted.

“Right. And Vision is an excellent storyteller.”

Agatha chuckled, the overlay of dread sloughing off of her slightly.

“That’s fucking rude.”

Wanda grinned back and released Agatha’s arm.

“Do you want to go in? The boys are very excited and confused that you and Rio know each other.” She looked at the rocking chairs. “We can also sit down for a moment if you need it.”

Agatha was itching to see Rio, to subvert any thoughts she might be having about Agatha leaving her alone.

“I’m surprised they don’t know anything.”

Wanda’s brow raised.

“Are you? They’re the most inquisitive children on earth. You don’t think, if I’d told them, one of them would have asked a question or two hundred you didn’t want to answer?”

Agatha blew out her cheeks as she took the steps toward the front door.

“Fair point.”

As she placed her hand on the door, Agatha heard the soft squeals of laughter coming from the twins. The veil peeled back further, the blackout curtains splitting to let in light.

She twisted the knob and stepped inside. As soon as she became visible, both boys— now currently on either side of Rio— gasped and launched themselves from the couch.

It was clear that the movement was jarring enough to Rio to feel it. Her face tensed but otherwise remained neutral. She didn’t quite look at Agatha and Agatha felt it harshly.

Billy hit Agatha’s legs.

“Agatha!”

The double F in her name brought Agatha further back from the brink as she placed a hand on Billy’s back.

Tommy was quicker, offering a one-armed hug to her thigh before he moved back toward Rio. Agatha noted that Vision was sitting in the L of the couch, his straight-leg jeans and striped sweater standing out against the cushion.

He smiled at her as she walked, Billy attached, toward the couch.

Rio finally looked at her and Agatha swallowed. She lifted her phone ruefully.

“I didn’t realize it wasn’t on me.”

Rio’s shuttered expression faltered and a relief near desperation became visible.

“I figured.”

It was an admission of overreaction, however slight, and a needed reminder that they were okay.

Agatha was careful as she sat down on Rio’s other side. Billy climbed up next to her, then proceeded to kneel across her thighs, his sharp bones digging in like the paws of a cat.

“Auntie Rio told us she got to ride in a king chair down lots of stairs.”

Agatha chuckled.

“A king chair? Did she tell you she was also asleep through most of it?”

Billy gasped and Tommy looked imploringly at Rio.

Rio shot her a glare and continued her story.

“I was not asleep. I was a little bit drowsy. Besides, it’s way cooler to go down in a chair. Agatha had to walk.”

Tommy nodded.

“That is cooler.”

Wanda sat down beside Vision and seemed content to watch this play out.

Billy shifted, the pain of his knees in the muscle of her thigh nearly unbearable.

“Agatha?” He looked up, his eyebrow furrowing like he had a very deep thought. “Do you live with Auntie Rio now?”

Agatha’s eyes widened.

“No— I just— I was making sure she was okay.”

He shrugged.

“Okay. So you’re coming back?”

Agatha smiled softly.

“I’ll be back. Have you been visiting Scratchy?”

Billy jolted in excitement and Agatha nearly doubled over as he slid off of her to run to his dad.

“Dad! Let me show her!”

Vision opened his phone and pressed it into Billy’s hand.

Billy ran back and Agatha subtly blocked him from launching into her again. He clambered onto the couch.

“I taught him a trick!”

Agatha watched as the camera followed Billy, the boy running from one wall of the guest house and watching with bright eyes as Señor Scratchy bounced after him. Billy giggled and sprinted to the other wall, and some meandering moments later, Scratchy hopped in the same general direction.

It looked like a coincidence rather than a trick, but Agatha nodded solemnly.

“That is very impressive work, Billy.”

He beamed and then leaned forward.

“Auntie Rio, have you met Scratchy?”

Rio smiled, her eyes panning to Agatha for a brief moment.

“I have! He’s very sweet.”

The visit continued similarly into the evening, both boys bouncing topics of conversation around, some questions cutting very close to open wounds.

Agatha found herself staring often, watching the easy way Rio engaged with the boys, the genuine, warm smile tinged with devastating loss.

Rio looked at Tommy and Billy with intention, with understanding that time was fleeting and fickle and cruel. The recognition of it burned in Agatha’s nose and throat and she felt herself considering what Nicky would have been like right now. Would he have been interested in the boys, would he have sat beside Wanda and Vision and watched?

Agatha was running on a very, very fine thread of sanity. The distortions, the could-have-beens, the reconnection that felt both impossible and easy; all making themselves known in the pulsing thump of Agatha’s chest and the harsh clench of her jaw.

Around eight, Wanda alerted the boys that they had five more minutes, and both fell into a state of disarray. Tommy’s sleepy eyes flooded with tears, his voice wavering as he’d clambered into Rio’s lap. She’d gone white as a sheet, her jaw clenching as he bumped into her ribs and settled his weight on them.

Wanda moved to intervene but Rio shook her head. He’d cried for two minutes before promptly passing out, his mouth agape and his cheek squished into her shoulder.

Billy had become obstinate, his little arms crossing, his face pinching dramatically as he tried to bargain.

“But story time first!”

Vision held out a hand toward him and smiled.

“We can have story time at home.”

Billy let out a frustrated, near-tears groan and leaned further into Agatha’s side.

“And Agatha comes?”

Vision glanced at Agatha, then back.

“That is up to Agatha, Billy. If she doesn’t come tonight, you’ll still see her soon.”

He fell dramatically onto the couch and wailed, his fists pressing into his eyes, snot starting to run down his nose.

Agatha spoke softly, hoping the sound conveyed more than the words.

“I’ll come back tonight, Billy.”

Billy’s tantrum took a sharp left, his cry petering out, his watery eyes brightening despite the continued sniffles.

“Will you sit with me?”

Agatha thought about being squished between the two car seats.

“I can do that.”

Agatha glanced at Wanda, the words unspoken but understood, and Wanda stood.

“Okay, Billy, let’s make sure there’s nothing in Agatha’s seat.”

Billy scrambled off of the couch and ran toward the door as Wanda followed. She glanced back at Vision and tilted her head toward Tommy.

Vision rose and offered Rio a painfully sincere smile.

“Tommy told me the other day that you were his third best friend.”

Rio smiled and she let Vision pull Tommy gently away from her. She looked somewhat nauseous.

“Bronze is still medaling.”

Tommy woke, adjusted, and fell back to sleep in Vision’s arms.

Vision grinned.

“Billy and Elise are his first best friends but Elise seems like a tenuous second.”

Rio pressed a hand against her abdomen.

“I’ll have to work harder then.”

Vision said his goodbyes and walked toward the door.

Rio’s head fell back and she let out a pained groan. Her breathing was strained.

“Tommy is so heavy.”

Agatha forced herself to bite back the offer to stay, to help. She needed to right the ship. She needed to talk to Alder and do her job, she needed to put in the work to make sure the oppressive fears that painted the inside of her skull did not come to fruition.

“I can help you up the stairs before I go.”

Rio’s lips pursed.

“Okay.”

Agatha slipped her arm beneath Rio’s and gently lifted them both from the couch. She could feel Rio’s muscles trembling with effort and she stayed in place, the warmth of their sides radiating into one another as they walked toward the stairs.

It was slow moving, Rio’s ribs aggravated by a weight crushing into them. Agatha tried not to take it personally that Rio was putting on a brave face, that the sheer amount of pain she knew she was in was being kept under wraps.

She waited while Rio brushed her teeth and then helped her into the bed.

“I want to stay, you know? I just—“

Rio nodded.

“I know, Agatha. It wouldn’t be— I know you can’t just stay here.” She closed her eyes and was quiet for so long that Agatha was only sure she was still awake due to the frown tugging at her lips. “I’m scared you won’t come back.”

Agatha sat down, her fingers sliding against Rio’s soft skin as she stroked her cheek.

“I will. I pro—“ Agatha’s words choked off. It felt wrong to make promises when the biggest one she’d ever made, she’d broken. “I’m going to come back. Maybe tomorrow? After work? We can try to have that conversation?”

Rio’s eyes opened, the dark brown so filled with worry and hope, and her cheeks puffed out as she blew out a breath.

“Okay.” Her head tilted to the side. “And today? What happened?”

Agatha’s heartbeat felt like static.

“Can we talk about that tomorrow too?”

Rio nodded.

When Agatha stood, she regretted her decision entirely. It felt like a string that connected them through everything— their training, marriage, separation— had suddenly pulled taut. It felt like leaving would hurt; like leaving was wrong.

She gathered the string and tried to slacken it to no avail.

With only a moment of hesitance, Agatha leaned down and pressed her lips against Rio’s cheek. She lingered for too long: Rio smelled like home.

Fingers slid into the thick mane of Agatha’s hair and tangled at the nape of her neck when she pulled away. She felt herself tugged, felt Rio’s mouth on hers with a desperation that was mirrored and multiplied.

Agatha gasped weakly, her lips parting as Rio’s tongue teased but didn’t press. Agatha’s heartbeat pounded in her ears and throat as her abdomen clenched.

By the time Rio released her, Agatha was in a daze.

Rio looked pained, the fear still lingered, but she spoke with a confidence that Agatha clung to.

“I just wanted you to keep that in mind.”
_______

Agatha found herself sitting beside Wanda two hours later, both of them rocking on the porch swing of the guest house. They had polished off a bottle of wine together and were sitting in a pleasant buzz.

The boys had both fallen asleep in the car and it had only taken a minute of reading for them to fall back asleep once in their beds.

Vision had offered a game of chess and Wanda had groaned goodnaturedly and uncorked a Pinot.

As expected, Agatha was losing.

She stared at the position with an irritated frown. It was a relief to be using her full mind for a task, to be analytical and precise and decisive. Losing, however, was never an experience she enjoyed.

Sometimes she wondered if Vision was actually a computer.

She pushed her pawn to a3 to prevent the incoming pin.

Wanda was sitting at the table with a bowl of chips and her computer open, but her eyes rarely left the game. She crunched a stack in her mouth and tilted her head at the move.

“Can’t Vis just—“

Agatha’s eyes snapped up.

“Don’t finish that sentence or I’ll see how many chips fit in your mouth at once.”

Wanda blinked, Vision stared, and then both fell into a fit of laughter as Agatha glowered at the board.

Because yes, Vision just could. And Vision just did. And he didn’t need Wanda’s help in finding it.

Agatha waited until hope was lost, until Vision sacrificed his Queen and she saw the impending checkmate from six moves away, before resigning.

She stood with a scoff.

“I’m never playing with you again.”

Wanda had pushed the bowl to the side and she rose with the unfinished bottle of wine.

“You said that last time, right? And the time before?”

Vision set about putting away the pieces. He was never smug; Agatha wasn’t sure he had the capability. But he was pleased, and that was just as offensive to her.

“I’m moving out. I’ll be living in my car.”

Vision nodded solemnly.

“Understandable. If you need a location for parking, we have a rather sizable driveway.”

Agatha narrowed her eyes at him.

“I hope your next batch of scones burn.”

Vision’s eyes widened.

“Oh dear.” He closed the clasp on his chess set. “The next batch was meant for you. Incredibly unfortunate.” He pulled his board under his arm and smiled at her. “Goodnight, Agatha.” He pressed a kiss to Wanda’s lips. “Goodnight, darling. Do try to come to bed soon.”

As he walked away, Wanda had tilted the bottle of wine toward the door. They’d settled into the porch swing, both of their legs rocking them slowly, and sat in an easy silence for several minutes.

Agatha felt her body decompressing, her chest loosening, her anxiety slipping into exhaustion.

“I got in my head.”

Wanda nodded, passing her the bottle.

“I know. It’s okay too, you know? The knowledge of how to manage our emotions and the actual practice of it doesn’t always come hand in hand.”

Agatha tilted the bottle against her lips. It was classless, drinking straight from the mouth, but it allowed Agatha to sink back into nostalgia. She passed it back.

Wanda’s lips curled up.

“God, do you remember when I moved back to DC and we started hanging out? The first time we closed a case together, you, Rio, and I sat on the floor in her living room and finished three bottles of wine without a glass in sight.”

Agatha groaned, her body softening to the alcohol.

“We were so fucking drunk. I think you suggested we have a threesome.”

Wanda laughed, her smile bright.

“I was joking. Mostly.”

Agatha barked out a laugh, her eyes closing as she leaned her head back.

“I remember I was the only one that had to go into work early the next day. I hated both of you.”

Wanda blew out a breath and handed the bottle over.

“You were lucky. I think I spent three hours curled over Rio’s toilet. At one point, she threw up in the bathtub.”

Agatha grimaced.

“Jesus. Single-bathroom apartments should not host celebratory parties.” She picked at the paper label. “I threw up in my trash can at work.”

Wanda snorted.

“I know. Ralph heard you and thought it was so funny. He texted me and half of our cohort.”

That was news. Agatha looked over at Wanda’s smug expression.

“What did you say?”

“In between intimate moments with the porcelain, I told him that he should try ever having enough fun to do the same.” She huffed. “I spelled most of the words wrong but my point got across.”

Agatha grinned down at the peeled label.

“Maybe he took your advice.”

Wanda hummed her agreement, the two of the falling into a contemplative silence. Agatha stared at the sky, the clouds partially hiding the stars.

Wanda breathed out a sigh.

“I told you I learned so much from you as a mother, but I never told you how much I learned from you as a partner.”

Agatha felt the scoff before she could curb it. It was hard to consider herself good.

Wanda shook her head.

“Shut up and listen.”

“I didn’t say anything.”

Wanda shushed her loudly, giving a meaningful pause before continuing.

“You and Rio, even in the early days at Quantico where all of us were run ragged, always found a way to exist together.”

Agatha tried to understand what she meant, her brow furrowing.

“We didn’t really have to try.”

Wanda smiled.

“I know. You guys adapted to one another like breathing.”

Agatha stared, unseeing.

“I think Rio adapted. She moved where I moved. Her patience was extraordinary.”

“Agatha, your entire world changed for her. You softened every part of you so that she could get close and then you kept her there.” Wanda huffed. “When she came to Quantico, I knew she was going to be a success. She is the smartest fucking person I know. But she was…” Wanda trailed off. “She was alone. By choice, I know. But then she chose you. She found you so worthy of her attention and care and you never once made her regret that.”

“Wanda, I–”

“No. Ask her. Ask her if she regrets any part of meeting you. Of choosing you. Of waiting for you. She will say no.” Wanda turned toward her suddenly, her hands lifting, pressing Agatha’s cheeks together as she looked at her hard, her eyes glassy. “She will always choose you, Agatha. No matter what you do to her or what the world does to you both. The only thing you have to worry about is how you will choose her too. Do you understand?”

Agatha stared at Wanda’s flushed face and felt a gentle amusement in her chest. Her words were mumbled through her squished cheeks.

“I understand. You’re drunk.”

Wanda dropped her hands and shrugged.

“So what if I am. I have two children of my own and two adult children that seem dead set on flinging themselves through windows, being irradiated, and generally making stupid choices. They might be worse than the toddlers.”

Agatha laughed as a pang of gratitude throbbed in her chest.

“You really are putting in the work.” She swallowed her pride. “You’re a great friend, Wanda. Thank you for putting up with me despite… everything.”

Wanda waved dismissively.

“Please. Vision and I don’t have any other couple friends nearby. It’s purely for selfish reasons.”

Agatha grinned.

“Of course.”
_______

Agatha glanced up for the fourth time, her eyes narrowing in on the sound of William’s fingers where they drummed against the desk.

He caught her eye and flushed, his drumming falling silent.

“Sorry.”

Agatha rolled her eyes. She waited a few moments, closed out the case file on her screen, and returned her attention to William. He looked like he was about to explode.

“What?”

He looked back up, his relief palpable, and she was reminded once more that he needed a less expressive face.

“Eddie has been acting weird.”

Agatha frowned.

“Weird how?”

William, without invite, stood and rolled his chair over to her desk as if she’d agreed to a therapy session. He dropped down and sighed.

“I feel like he’s going to dump me.”

Agatha’s brows rose.

“What makes you say that?”

William pursed his lips and he leaned forward to pick up a stack of sticky notes. He began to idly run his finger along the edge, a quiet, repetitive flutter sounding.

“He’s been kind of distant this week?”

“Is that a question?”

William sighed.

“He’s been distant. We were supposed to have a movie night last night. I got everything set up and made our snacks and he texted me from work that he’d be home later than expected. He asked if we could do it today instead.”

Agatha waited for more. When nothing followed, she gave him a look.

“And?”

William crossed his arms.

“That’s basically it.”

Agatha wasn’t sure she could get away with smacking the intern.

“There better be more or I’ll take your vape where you keep it in your desk and throw it out the window.”

William’s eyes shot toward his desk, then back to her alarmed.

“No! I need that. For my nerves.”

Agatha scoffed.

“Tell me what else.”

William threw up a hand.

“I don’t know! I feel like he’s been on his phone a lot. And he got a package Monday that he didn’t even open. He just took it to our room.”

“What was it?”

William looked confused.

“I just said he didn’t open it.”

Agatha frowned, shrugged.

“I just figured you looked later.”

William’s confusion turned to shock.

“I’m not going to go through his things!”

“Because you trust him?”

“Obviously!”

Agatha nodded, her point made.

“So why don’t you just ask instead of spinning out?”

The irony was not lost on her.

William pulled off the top sticky note.

“I don’t want to know the answer.”

Agatha almost laughed.

“Did you consider it might be literally anything else before jumping to this conclusion?”

William frowned at her.

“I don’t enjoy you being logical.”

Agatha’s mouth dropped open.

“Excuse me!” She reached out and snatched back her sticky notes. “I’m logical. Go back to your desk.”

“Wait! No, okay you’re so logical. The most logical. Can you help me please?”

Agatha rolled her eyes.

“Maybe he’s going to propose.”

William blanched.

“We’re twenty!”

Agatha shrugged, leaning back in her chair as she realized this was turning into a longer conversation.

“Listen, Will. Has Eddie ever given you a reason to believe that something is wrong? Outside of this one week?”

“No.”

“Then stop assuming the worst. Just talk to him.”

William blew out his cheeks.

“Fine.”

Agatha should have known that wasn’t going to be the end of the conversation. She turned back to her computer to pull a file Alice had sent to the entire team. She’d barely read the email’s greeting before Will was rolling into a new topic.

“How are things with you?”

Agatha groaned.

“This is not a tit for tat situation. Go do the work you're paid for.”

Will scoffed.

“Barely.” He picked up another stack of sticky notes and began to fiddle. “How’s Director Vidal?”

Agatha narrowed her eyes.

“And I’d know that, why?”

Will offered her a cheeky look, his brows lifting.

“You stayed behind when everyone left.”

Agatha pointedly did not look at him.

“Somebody needed to be present on the scene.”

Will chuckled.

“Okay. Sure.”

He kicked his feet into the floor to send himself back toward his own desk.

Agatha frowned into her computer screen and didn’t read a single word. Several minutes passed before she offered him a begrudging response.

“She’s recovering.”

She ignored Will’s wide grin as he noisily rounded his desk, the wheels of the chair clacking and bouncing off of the wood.
_____

The rest of the day was slow; normally, they were the kinds of days that Agatha hated. Today was a strange mix of needing a moment to breathe and feeling desperate to get back to Rio. It was similar to the feeling of leaving something important behind. After several days of close proximity, of relearning, of remembering, being without her made everything feel sterile.

Agatha was nearly chafing as lunch came around, her eyes flicking to her phone every thirty minutes. Then every ten. Now she was simply staring at it.

She huffed and pulled it into her hands.

She opened Rio’s contact, changed the skull emoji to her name, and typed out a message before she could overthink it.

How’s it going?

It showed as delivered and Agatha made the mistake of looking at the last message from Rio. The time stamp was from two years prior.

Just let me know if you’re okay. Please.

Agatha pressed her lips into a tight line.

She blocked the swell of a memory before it could overtake her, her chest tight as she waited for any kind of response. Three dots appeared. Agatha expected hesitation, but a message came through almost immediately.

Rio: Everything hurts and Boggle knocked over my plant. I can’t pick it up :(

Agatha’s chest surged, her lips pulling up.

I’ll pick it up when I come over

Rio: You’re coming then?

I said I would. Is that okay?

The response was so quick Agatha nearly laughed. She bit it back at the last moment, her eyes finding William working diligently across the office.

Rio: Yes. I want you to.

Okay. Can I get you anything?

Rio: Gatorade? The blue one.

Rio: A frozen pizza.

Rio: And a package of basswood blocks.

Agatha reread the last message.

What

Rio: The internet says the infirm should take up a hobby.

You’re not infirm. Where would I even get basswood blocks? Why do you need them?

Rio: I’m going to learn to whittle.

You’re not going to learn to whittle, Rio.

Agatha’s heart nearly melted out of her chest at the photo response that followed.

Rio was sitting in her nest of blankets on the couch with somewhat messy hair and one of Agatha’s old t-shirts rumpled on her chest. She was frowning pathetically at the camera, her lips turned down, her eyes sad.

Agatha typed back quickly.

Stop that.

Rio: But Agatha! I need basswood.

Oh my god, fine. I’ll buy you basswood. I’m not getting you a frozen pizza. You need real food.

Rio: Okay :)

Chapter End Notes

We're getting there, everyone. I still love these two and this story and I won't leave y'all hanging!

Chapter 29

Chapter Notes

Hello! Long wait, but at least this is a long one. Big talks, flashback to some good times with a much-requested scene.

The socks stay on during sex.

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Rio, where the fuck do I buy basswood?

Agatha had been to Home Depot wandering around in her suit for thirty minutes because she refused to ask for help. When she’d finally swallowed her pride, the bored employee had led her to a section with monotone quips and comments about it being poor for construction and DIY projects.

The smallest pieces they’d had were 12” x 12” squares of plywood. Forty-eight pieces for one hundred and fifty dollars. She had walked away from the employee mid-sentence and left the store.

Rio: They say the best place to buy is online.

Agatha was going to strangle her. She was in the middle of saying so when another text came through.

Rio: Oh! Craft stores

Agatha growled and punched in the closest Michael’s.

An hour later, Agatha was driving to Rio with groceries and a pack of basswood blocks that she was certain Rio would never touch. Every mile closer, the white dashed lines passing by, Agatha’s irritation faded into relief.

It was nearly seven and she had packed a bag. Just in case. She didn’t want to presume, but she wasn’t going to miss an opportunity if it was offered because she wasn’t prepared.

She parked in the driveway and made her way to the door.

It opened before she’d reached the steps, Rio was standing in the same outfit from her earlier picture. She looked tired and relieved and hopeful, and Agatha felt a sharp pang of regret that she’d missed out on this for so fucking long.

She slowed as she reached the top step.

“You look like you should be lying down.”

Rio pouted, leaning heavily against the door.

“I don’t want to.”

Agatha laughed, easing herself through the small gap Rio had left open. She slid her arm around Rio’s back.

“Too bad.”

Rio let herself be guided, swinging the door closed as Agatha walked her back to the living room.

There was a bottle of painkillers, a laptop, a half-finished glass of water, and about a dozen random snacks scattered on the table and couch.

Agatha frowned. She looked at Rio.

“Is this all you’ve eaten?”

Rio pointedly avoided her gaze.

“No.”

Agatha huffed and guided Rio to the couch.

“Sit down.”

She left no room for argument, and Rio listened even though she looked like she didn’t want to.

Agatha set the bags on the table and pulled out one of several blue Gatorades. Rio’s eyes lit up and she took it from Agatha’s outstretched hand.

Agatha pointed at her.

“Stay put.”

Rio tried to lean forward, but her face twisted in pain and she dropped back onto the nest of blankets.

Agatha rolled her eyes and picked up the package of basswood. Setting it in Rio’s lap, she gave her a look.

“You don’t know how to whittle.”

Rio scoffed, scowling back at Agatha disbelievingly.

“Obviously. That’s why I signed up for a class.”

Agatha’s throat closed, her eyes filling with tears before she could register the influx of emotion racing through her. She had missed this. She had missed Rio and her ability to absorb knowledge. She knew if Rio signed up for a class, she would, in fact, learn.

Agatha blinked away tears and leaned down to start gathering the snacks to put them away. She’d collected half of them and turned to the kitchen when Rio’s voice spoke quietly, questioningly.

“Agatha?”

Agatha cleared her throat, chest rising and falling in an effort to control her elevating emotions.

“I’m okay. Let me just clean up.”

Cleaning up turned into tidying Rio’s entire kitchen, preheating the oven, and standing in place for five minutes with her heart lodged in her throat.

The oven beeped and Agatha slid in the lasagna she’d purchased as an easy meal that would at least feed Rio for a few days if she wasn’t here.

Without any other methods to stall, Agatha returned to the living room and found Rio covered in wood shavings with a familiar knife in one hand and a block of basswood in the other. Her brow was furrowed, eyes deeply focused and leaning toward agitation as the knife cut what was likely too large a chunk.

Agatha breathed through the clawing ache.

Agatha glanced back at a brooding Rio as she attempted to keep her amusement from her face. Nicky was asleep in his stroller and he had been for the better portion of their walk. They’d been on an easy, smooth trail with views of the Potomac. The season was turning, but there were still enough red, orange, and yellow leaves on the trees to make it beautiful.

Before Nicky had conked out, he’d been thrilled every time they’d stopped to let him down and wander around.

One such time, he’d been eager to dig through the fanny pack they kept on the stroller and find a baggie of snacks. He’d also managed to grab Rio’s folded pocket knife. It was locked, the strength-based mechanism keeping him from accidentally triggering it open.

He’d squealed and giggled as he walked toward Rio with the pocket knife held out to her.

Both had taken steps to intercept him.

He dropped the knife before Rio could reach him, which would have been fine if they hadn’t been standing on a bridge over the river.

The knife had bounced and skittered right across the peeling wood and through the slats into the rushing water below.

Rio had stared after it as Nicky started bawling his eyes out.

Agatha had swooped in to press Nicky to her chest and Rio had put on her bravest face as she stepped into his view.

She’d tapped his nose with a smile.

“It’s okay, Nic. It’s just a silly thing. No need to worry.”

Nicky had sniffled and his chest had shuddered sadly a few more times before he calmed down.

They’d spent the next hour with Agatha rocking Nicky to sleep while Rio waded into the shallows of the Potomac with a hopeless look on her face.

Agatha had placed Nicky gently in his stroller and eventually called Rio back.

“I think it’s gone, love.”

Rio had nodded and followed after Agatha as she led them back to their car.

As Agatha buckled Nicky into his carseat, Rio climbed in the passenger side, slumping dejectedly.

Agatha gently closed the back door and made her way to Rio, propping the passenger door open and waiting patiently for Rio to look at her.

“Rio, we’ll get you a new one.”

Rio sighed.

“Okay. That one was special though.”

Agatha linked their hands and squeezed.

“I know. You bought it after we graduated from Quantico.”

Rio nodded.

Agatha smiled at her, body alight with love and a need to do anything to make her wife smile too.

“I’ll make sure the next one is special too, okay?” She squeezed Rio’s hand. “It’ll commemorate the first of many things Nicky will accidentally destroy.”

Rio’s lips twitched.

“Drawing all over the bathroom didn’t count?”

Agatha chuckled.

“No, remember, that was art.”

Rio blew out a slow breath, her head nodding as she shook off the melancholy.
____

Agatha had spent days researching and had eventually spent far too much money on the Benchmade folding knife with a scimitar blade and carbon fiber handle in Rio’s hands. She’d paid a little extra to engrave ‘A+N+R’ into the blade.

Rio looked up and found Agatha watching. She flushed and tugged uselessly at her shirt, sending the shavings further around her and all over the floor and couch.

Agatha choked out a laugh and joined her on the couch. She sat down against Rio’s pile of blankets.

Rio closed the knife and set it on the table along with the malformed block, refocusing on Agatha.

“Are you okay?”

Agatha wiped at the tears in her eyes.

“I’ve missed you so much, Rio.”

Rio’s eyes widened, tears gathering on her lashes. She swallowed and tried to clear her throat.

“I’d actually gotten to the point where I believed you’d never say that. That you didn’t feel it.”

Agatha leaned back and drew her knees up. She felt small, fragile. But she also felt safe knowing that Rio wouldn’t take advantage of that.

“I’d convinced myself too.” She pulled her eyes away, the connection too intense. “I thought the pain that I felt, the pain that never stopped, was just the loss of Nicky.” Agatha closed her eyes, the waves of memories of feeling so alone and so hopeless rushing through her. “Rio, I ripped out the half of my heart I still had left and didn’t realize why it hurt so badly.”

Agatha felt a soft hand on her forearm, the light weight of Rio’s fingertips on her skin grounding her.

She continued, needing to expel the sudden pressure in her chest.

“I don’t know how I stayed away for so long.”

She refocused her attention on Rio just in time to catch a sharp flicker of insecurity, of doubt, in Rio’s eyes.

Rio tried to clear her expression but the wound remained, steady and throbbing.

“I had–” She sighed. “I expected, at least for the last several years, that you’d moved on. You didn’t respond or reach out… I felt so pathetic. Sitting here, waiting for you, knowing that I would never be able to do the same.” Rio’s hand slipped off Agatha’s arm limply, the words taking their toll as she spoke them. “I thought about you every single day. Some mornings I would wake up and I’d expect to see your hair tangled around your head beside me or hear you downstairs slamming the cabinet doors.”

Agatha let out a wet laugh, the words eviscerating her.

“I wasn’t that loud.”

Rio’s pained face lilted toward amusement.

“You were never delicate.”

Agatha sighed, the words carrying far too many meanings.

“No. I… I wasn’t strong enough to be delicate.”

Rio caught the direction of her thoughts, her head shaking lightly.

“You were for Nicky. For me.”

Agatha offered a rueful smile.

“Nothing left for the cabinets.”

Rio chuckled, her eyes softening as she tried to make herself more comfortable in her nest. She tweaked her ribs and huffed pitifully, her lips turning down.

Agatha wondered how many times her heart would need to break over their missed time, over Rio dealing with all of this alone, before it hurt a little less. She helped adjust the pillows and blankets until Rio’s frown faded.

Agatha turned toward her, knees still pressed into her chest.

“I never moved on, Rio. I never even considered it. I spent every moment alone, with a genuine belief that I’d die that way.”

Rio’s jaw clenched and she looked prepared to say something. Instead, a single word slipped out.

“Yeah.”

Agatha shook her head.

“Tell me.”

Rio’s eyes filled with fresh tears.

“I just–” Her voice broke, frustration lacing it. “I don’t understand how that was better than coming home.” Rio drew in a sharp breath. “I don’t know why I wasn’t enough to make you fight for me. For us.” She looked overwhelmed, her shoulders drawing up toward her ears. “I would have done anything, Agatha. I would have–”

She broke off, her voice failing her as she tried not to sob.

Agatha wasn’t sure she was breathing. She lifted her hands to hold Rio’s face, her thumbs wiping at the tears even as her own painted her cheeks.

“Rio.” Her voice was imploring, reverent. “Darling, it was never better. It was never about you not being enough for me.” Agatha tried to put together words that would make Rio understand. “I was just empty. I couldn’t see you, couldn’t touch you, couldn’t bear to let in your memory for the fear of what it would do to me.” She said her next words with so much sincerity that they resounded loudly in her skull. “You have always been enough. For me, for Nicky, for everyone that relies on you. You’ve never given a half measure of your effort.”

She could see Rio trying to grasp the words, her perfect, strange mind piecing through the claim.

Rio sniffed.

“But–”

Agatha shook her head.

“No. Rio, you saved me. You have to understand.” She let out a wet laugh. “I know that I fought you every fucking step. I dug in my heels and bit and scratched and bled to try and stay in that shitty fucking apartment. In the job that I hated. But if you hadn’t dragged me back here I never would have found my way.”

Rio’s eyes met hers, searching and hopeful. Then they fell.

“I should have come sooner.”

Agatha was entirely certain that that wouldn’t have worked.

“Rio, my love, you would have destroyed yourself trying. I wasn’t–” Agatha let her hands lower to curl around one of Rio’s. “You had to put your pieces back together before you could look at mine.”

Rio looked at their intertwined hands, her jaw trembling.

“It was so hard, Agatha. The last five years felt infinite. There was so much emptiness.”

Agatha rubbed soothing patterns on Rio’s skin. She offered a soft smile.

“I know.” She drew in a steadying breath. “Can I ask you something?”

“Of course.”

Rio said it like it was so easy. To give Agatha everything she wanted without a thought for herself.

“Wanda said something to me last night…” She lowered her head to find Rio’s eyes. “She said that you wouldn’t regret anything. That even-” Her voice faltered. “That despite everything, you wouldn’t have regretted meeting me. Is that true?”

Agatha wasn’t given a moment to worry over the answer.

“I’d live our life a thousand times. Even if it ended the same way. Even if you never came back to me.”

A fresh wave of tears torrented down Agatha’s cheeks and she let the words encompass her, settling soft and warm over every brittle part of her. She squeezed Rio’s hands hoping that her words were clear enough.

“Do you know that it’s the same for me?”

Rio looked startled, her eyes widening. Like she didn’t know that she was everything.

“It is?”

Her voice was so fragile.

Agatha laughed desperately.

“Rio, my only regret is the amount of time I let pass before telling you.” She huffed. “And that I have enabled your ridiculous request to whittle.”

Rio folded into her, her face pressing into Agatha’s throat, her hands clinging to Agatha’s shirt. She made a pained sound but didn’t withdraw, her breath warm on Agatha’s chest.

Agatha adjusted them into a better position for Rio’s ribs and held her as tightly as she could without causing her discomfort. She tangled her fingers in Rio’s hair and continued speaking, her voice gentle.

“All that I want, all that I need now, is you. Whatever that looks like, whatever pace you need to set, I’m here. I’m not fucking going anywhere unless you tell me to.”

The statement settled between them and Agatha felt serene. Her tears dried, her limbs felt warm and pliant, and the tangle in her chest that had choked her for years and years loosened. She let Rio feel it, let her cry, and thought about the future for the first time since Nicky’s diagnosis.
____

Agatha chuckled as Rio pouted at the stairs.

It was far too late for either of them to be awake. Agatha had work and Rio needed rest to recover. But they’d stayed folded together until the lasagna was finished. Agatha’s trip to withdraw, plate, and store the remaining food had been the only time Rio’s hands weren’t on her.

Since then, they’d been intertwined, a giddiness that came from relief– from release– surging through them as they’d eaten on the couch amongst irritating shavings of Rio’s woodblock. Rio hadn’t stopped looking at her, something Agatha would have pointed out if she’d been any different.

Now, she wrapped an arm around Rio’s back.

“You can do this, Director.”

Rio’s pout turned into a pathetic glare.

“I know that.” She didn’t move, her brow furrowing. “We could sleep on the couch.”

Agatha smirked.

“You’re supposed to keep yourself moving. It’ll be good for you.”

Rio took her first slow step.

“I didn’t realize you’d gone to medical school.”

Agatha moved with her.

“You can call me doctor if it moves you up these stairs faster.”

Rio groaned.

“Don’t. I can’t think about Doctor Agatha right now.”

Agatha laughed, steadying Rio’s next step as she tilted slightly.

“Why not?”

Rio frowned, her arms crossing petulantly over her chest.

“I’ll stand on these steps all night if you keep laughing at me.”

Agatha bit back her smile for approximately half a second before she lifted her brows.

“I forgot how bratty you got when you were injured. What would people think?”

Rio’s expression went through a tumultuous roll of emotions before it sank into a look of warning.

“I’m going to remember this. I might not be able to deal with you now, but when I can move properly?” Her pout had vanished, her eyes were sharply observing Agatha’s face. “You’ll pay for every fucking word.”

Agatha felt the burn begin low in her belly, her heartbeat kicking up. She could not fucking wait for Rio to move properly. She offered her a dismissive shrug.

“Whatever you say, sweetheart.”

She moved to replace her guiding hand.

Rio caught her wrist, the grip firm, unyielding. Her voice was an octave lower, her eyes were all challenge.

“You look a little flushed, Agatha.”

Agatha felt a whine crawl up her throat and she cut it off just before it could betray her.

“I don’t know what you mean.”

Rio dropped her wrist.

“You will.”
___

Rio had brushed her teeth in silence, her posture tight, her jaw rolling.

Agatha knew if she pressed her fingers under the band of Rio’s boxers she’d find her soaked. She also knew, body permitting, Rio would already have her bent over the counter of the sink.

It felt a little bit like whiplash, going from tears to laughter to wanting to get railed in the span of a few hours. She hadn’t forgotten how to push Rio’s buttons, but she also hadn’t expected it to snap Rio out of her pity-party quite so sharply.

Even Rio seemed a little disoriented by the abrupt change, her brow furrowed as she put her toothbrush away. Agatha leaned her hip on the counter and circled her fingers around Rio’s wrist.

“Hey tough guy.” She waited for Rio to look at her. “Soon, okay?”

Rio’s eyes searched, then softened.

“Right. Okay.” She blushed. “Sorry, that kind of caught me off guard.”

Agatha shifted, her core aching.

“Tell me about it. You– fuck Rio, I really missed you.”

Rio smiled, her eyes sleepy but bright with joy.

“You don’t have to anymore, you know? I think that’s what we’ve settled on.”

It was a cheeky response and Agatha thought her lungs might burst with how full she felt.

“Come on, sleep. I have to wake up at five and I know you’re going to throw a fit.”

Rio’s feigned offense.

“Maybe try being quiet and I won’t have anything to complain about.”

Agatha grinned as she walked with Rio to the room. She helped her under the covers and walked around the side that had once belonged to her. She felt every step, her feet tracing the patterns that had ingrained in her: the soles of her feet sinking into the warm rug, five paces across as she rounded the foot of the bed, the brief sink of cool hardwood as she reached the edge.

She crawled into bed beside Rio and pulled the covers up her body, her nose catching the achingly familiar scent, her body sinking into what was likely a newer mattress than the one they’d shared. She turned, hair already tangling around her head, and tucked her knees up as she faced Rio.

Rio was already watching.

“It would be crazy to ask you to do this every night, right?”

Agatha felt the instantaneous response leap to her mind. Not crazy at all. Please ask me. But there was so much to heal, so much to work on still. She grinned softly.

“I think we’ll get there, Rio. But this is your space right now. I’m not going to take that away from you. As we figure this out, you deserve to have a place to unwind.”

Rio sighed, her lips turning down.

“I’m unwound already.” She nudged the back of Agatha’s hand. “I know you’re right, but I want you here. When you can be here, I mean.”

Agatha linked their fingers.

“I will be.”
_____

The next week was hectic, their team investigating a sudden influx of wire transfers hitting small banks around the DC area and spreading into parts of the midwest. It took up a significant portion of their time. They worked through a Sunday night and found the case-breaking lead within the early hours of the morning. It had been a small tech team at a megacorporation that had tried to develop AI to mimic banking behavior and carry out wire fraud.

Wanda sent the team home with two days of mandatory time off and Agatha felt as if she were sleepwalking into the guest house.

She wanted nothing more than to sleep, but she let Scratchy out of his cage and sat on the floor for thirty minutes. He darted around, his fluffy body a streak of fur as he flung himself through the rooms.

Agatha’s phone buzzed in her pocket and she withdrew to a text from Rio.

Rio: Congrats on closing the case, Agatha.

They’d been in near-constant contact since their conversation. Agatha had found herself stepping across the threshold of her once-home nearly every evening, only having gone to the guest house a few times to get new clothes and spend time with Scratchy.

She’d told Wanda she wanted to pay Billy in some way for his continuous help in taking care of Scratchy, but Wanda’s response had been a simple, “He loves your rabbit, Agatha. I don’t want to spoil that.”

Agatha typed a quick response.

I haven’t slept in fifty-four hours. I can feel my eyes in their sockets.

Rio: Gross.

Rio: Home safe?

Agatha looked around the guest house. It still felt welcoming, still felt warm, but the sense of it being ‘home’ had begun to fade sometime between Rio’s “I want you here” and Agatha’s fourth night tucked against her side.

They’d decided a small break would be good. That Agatha would go home for a night and rest. It felt like the worst idea she’d ever had. She left Scratchy to wander around and padded her way up the steps. She frowned at the pile of laundry stacked on the chair in the corner, her clothes pulled from her go-bag and tossed aside. Her bed was made but rumpled and various clean clothes were set on the corners of it from when she’d packed her go-bag.

She needed to clean. And do laundry.

I’m back

Home wasn’t the word for it; it felt wrong to type.

She started pulling the clean clothes from her bed and returning them to the closet. As she knelt to return a pair of shoes to the rack, her eyes fell on the box that had stayed with her, had been a thorn in her chest, for five years. Every year it had felt heavier, had carried more grief, more dread. Now, Agatha stared and felt something entirely different.

She pulled the box from the floor and walked it to the bed.

With steady hands, she withdrew the green, leather album and flipped the first page. The flowers had been preserved well. Rio had taught her when Agatha had questioned the significant amount of dried bouquets tied and hanging from the ceiling.

Agatha expected pain as she looked at the bright colors and deep greens. She found herself, instead, reluctant to look through it alone.

They hadn’t talked about the letters. Agatha knew that they would need to. There was so much to cover about what happened while they were apart. There were still so many things that had been left unsaid. Agatha wanted to know about Grim, about how Rio had found him, what he was like, if they spoke often. She wanted to know about the relationships Rio had formed in her absence. She wanted to know if Rio had found temporary hands to cradle her perfect heart, if she’d been able to find moments of peace.

She didn’t feel jealous, not truly. That others had time with Rio when she did not, of course. That others were able to touch when she could not, yes. But she didn’t begrudge Rio her connections. It gave her a sense of hope that Rio might have found temporary fixtures and allowed herself to be taken care of.

Her expression held mild interest and the beer in her hands was empty within a few minutes. Her knee was bouncing steadily beneath the table and her jaw hadn’t stopped clenching from the moment they’d sat down.

Agatha couldn’t keep her eyes from Rio for long.

She placed a hand on Rio’s back and watched her shoulders drop slightly, her head tilting down as she closed her eyes for a moment.

She stood, pressing against Rio’s side.

“Do you want another drink, darling?”

Rio tensed and straightened, her expression molding into something hard. And Agatha… for the first time, did not believe it. Glee coiled in her gut as she lifted a brow for Rio’s answer.

Rio nodded.

“Same thing.” She caught Agatha as she turned to walk away. “Last drink, Agatha. We’re leaving at half.”

Agatha smiled in acquiescence and moved to the bar, ordering a beer for herself and an Old Fashioned for Rio.

She placed it on the table and watched as Rio took in the tumbler beside her empty beer bottle. Her eyes lifted to Agatha and she lifted the glass to her lips without a word. She looked ready to explode, her throat contracting with the pull of the drink.

She set it down and leaned toward Agatha, speaking low under the murmur of the bar.

“You were working toward some relief, Agatha. Are you sure you want to lose the opportunity?”

Agatha slid into her set and pressed her knees into Rio’s thigh.

“After how bad I’ve been, I never believed it was in the cards.”

Rio drew in a sharp breath, her eyes holding conflict, flickers of desperation bleeding through her tightly held control. Rio feigned dismissal and returned to her drink, downing half of it before she willingly returned the glass to the table with a too-loud clunk.

The power coursing through Agatha had become intoxicating. She spent the next ten minutes playing with the metal cocktail pick that had come with Wanda’s Martini, spinning it delicately, expertly through her fingers.

Near the end of it, her drink empty once more, Rio had pushed away from the table with a polite “excuse me” and made her way toward the bathroom.

Agatha took the opportunity to order herself a Cherry Whiskey for the simple reason that it would hold her next method of torment.

Rio arrived just as the glass was set in front of Agatha, and Agatha played like she hadn’t seen her.

She plucked the cherry from the glass, popped it in her mouth, and twisted off the long stem. She felt Rio’s gaze on her as she pressed the stem between her lips and drew it onto her tongue.

She’d barely begun the process of tying it before she heard Rio’s rough voice in her ear, her hand gripping tight to Agatha’s bicep.

“Agatha.”

Agatha offered her most innocent look.

To Agatha, it looked like victory. She finished tying the stem and slipped it between her lips, placing it on the napkin that held her drink.

___

They called an Uber, their car at Wanda’s a problem for another time. Rio had dragged Agatha into the back seat and held her close. She was nearly vibrating with energy, her eyes glued to the headrest of the driver’s seat.

There were no promises of enduring pain, no quips on Agatha’s continuous, aggravating acts, no rough hands or words at all.

She could think of nothing else as she let her own hand settle on Rio’s arm, stroking the soft skin on the underside of her wrist.

It wasn’t until Agatha stepped through the door that Rio whirled on her, gripping her wrists and pinning them by Agatha’s head. Her mouth was needy, her pace far less decisive than normal, her breathing already ragged as she devoured Agatha.

She spoke as she tightened her grip, barely pulling her mouth away.

“You fucking brat.”
